episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy Mills – Premise file dated 04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills. Re: Mills v. Forcht Bank; Knox Circuit Court; Case No.: 20-CI-00112.

This note records a sequence of email exchanges in January 2022 among counsel and staff regarding the Knox Circuit Court case Mills v. Forcht Bank. The participants include Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm (agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com), Betsy R. Catron, Associate Attorney at WHT Law (Vine Center, 333 West Vine Street, Lexington, KY 40507), Renee Day (Legal Assistant to Betsy Catron and colleagues), and others CC’d on the thread, including Sarena Tuttle and the Amy Mills Premise email alias. Aaron also notes his new email address in the thread. The subject line repeatedly refers to Mills v. Forcht Bank, Knox Circuit Court, Case No. 20-CI-00112.

On January 11, 2022, at 4:07 PM, Renee Day sent an email to counsel attaching the Notice of Withdrawal of Motion to Compel Only that had been filed with the court that afternoon in the above-referenced case, asking to (please) let them know if there were questions or concerns. Later that same day, at 4:23 PM, Aaron Whaley replied to Betsy Catron (and cc’d Renee Day and agwhaley@louisville-accident-lawyer.com), joking, “I am not lazy but care to draft? You can bill that.” On January 11 at 6:12 PM, Betsy Catron responded, “That is fine with me.”

At 10:03 PM on January 11, 2022, Aaron Whaley sent another message to Betsy Catron (cc’ing Renee Day and agwhaley@louisville-accident-lawyer.com) noting: “Received, thank you. I know the Court won't let us extend the deadline by agreed order but you want to file something like a ‘Proposed Agreed Order’? It is just an Agreed Order along with a Motion to adopt. As grounds we can say that Plaintiff has only recently been released from active treatment and extending the deadlines another 6 months will allow counsel to complete record retrieval, consult experts and mediate the case. Something like that.” 

Earlier that same day, January 11, at 4:23 PM, Renee Day had been corresponding about the matter, and at 4:07 PM she had advised that the Notice of Withdrawal of Motion to Compel Only had been filed with the court earlier that afternoon. Betsy Catron replied later that day (at 6:12 PM) that this approach was acceptable.

The following day, January 12, 2022, at 7:21 PM Betsy Catron wrote: “No problem. I’ll get it done tomorrow. Thanks!” and signed her message as Associate Attorney from Vine Center.

On January 13, 2022, at 2:48 PM Betsy Catron sent, “Hi Aaron – please see attached. Let me know if you approve to file.” In that message she again referenced the attachment and sought approval to file the proposed course of action. Aaron Whaley responded about five minutes later (at 2:53:30 PM) with, “Looks good, Note my new email address. Thanks.”

Throughout the thread, standard firm contact details and disclosures appeared in signatures, including the Vine Center address and phone numbers, and the typical confidentiality notice was included in the messages from Renee Day. The thread confirms the progression toward filing an agreed order and a motion to adopt, with the goal of extending deadlines to permit record retrieval, expert consultation, and mediation, in connection with Mills v. Forcht Bank, Knox Circuit Court, Case No. 20-CI-00112.
episodes.author: Aaron Whaley

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy Mills premises file dated 04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills. Re: FW: Mills v. Forcht Bank; Knox Circuit Court; Case No. 20-CI-00112. This record is drawn from an email thread in January 2022 among Amy Mills’ counsel and their colleagues, regarding the Mills v. Forcht Bank case in Knox Circuit Court, and specifically about drafting and filing a proposed order to extend deadlines, as well as updates on court scheduling.

The chain begins with an email exchange on January 11–13, 2022 among Aaron Whaley (Whaley Law Firm), Betsy Catron (Whitt, Catron & Henderson / WHTLaw), Renee Day (legal assistant to several colleagues), and others cc’d in the thread, including Sarena Tuttle and Amy Mills’ Filevine recipient. In one early exchange, Aaron Whaley wrote on January 11, 2022 at 4:23 PM to Betsy Catron and Renee Day (and cc’d others) that he was not lazy but would be willing to draft, and that she could bill that time. Betsy Catron replied on January 11 at 6:12 PM that “That is fine with me.” Later that same evening, at 10:03 PM, Whaley reiterated the sentiment about drafting.

Earlier that day, Renee Day sent a message (January 11 at 4:07 PM) to counsel attaching the Notice of Withdrawal of Motion to Compel Only that had been filed with the court in the above-referenced case, asking to be informed if there were questions or concerns. The thread shows Betsy Catron’s replying correspondence over the next days. On January 12, 2022 at 7:21 PM Betsy Catron wrote, “No problem. I’ll get it done tomorrow. Thanks!” and included her standard firm signature and contact information.

On January 11, 2022 at 4:23 PM, Aaron had also exchanged messages with Renee Day and others about the approach to filing, specifically suggesting the possibility of a “Proposed Agreed Order” accompanied by a Motion to Adopt, and outlining grounds such as the Plaintiff having recently been released from active treatment and the need for more time to retrieve records, consult experts, and mediate. He noted that while the Court would not extend deadlines by agreed order, they could pursue such a filing with the appropriate grounds.

On January 13, 2022, Betsy Catron indicated progress by writing at 2:48 PM: “Hi Aaron – please see attached. Let me know if you approve to file.” Aaron Whaley responded at 2:54 PM: “Looks good, Note my new email address. Thanks.” The thread shows that Aaron’s new email address was agwhaley@louisville-accident-lawyer.com, and Betsy acknowledged approval to file the attached materials. The email traffic on January 11–13 also includes Betsy’s prior communications in which she indicated she would handle the filing the following day, with Aaron later confirming his new contact address.

Over the ensuing days, the thread includes Renee Day’s communications and standard firm email footers, including the confidentiality notice and multiple cautionary notes regarding external emails. The thread also shows the firm’s ongoing exchange about drafting and filing the necessary documents to extend deadlines and adopt an agreed order.

On January 19, 2022, Betsy Catron sent an email noting a development from the Knox Circuit Court Clerk’s office: “Judge Caperton’s Knox Circuit Court has been cancelled for tomorrow 1/20/22. All cases will be rescheduled for 2/14/22 at the regular time. If you have any questions, please call the clerk’s office at 546 3075.” Aaron Whaley replied with a brief, handwritten sentiment: “thank god.” Betsy then circulated the update to the chain, and the matter remained pending in light of the rescheduling.

In sum, the January 2022 correspondence reflects a coordinated effort among Amy Mills’ counsel and associated staff to draft and file a proposed agreed order to extend deadlines in Mills v. Forcht Bank (Knox Circuit Court, Case No. 20-CI-00112), with discussions about extending deadlines by six months to complete record retrieval, consult experts, and mediate, alongside the procedural steps already taken (including the withdrawal of a prior motion to compel), and an interim court scheduling change due to cancellation of a hearing scheduled for January 20, 2022, with the next date set for February 14, 2022 at the regular time. The thread includes references to the parties’ drafting and filing process, the new contact information for Aaron Whaley, and the various cc’d participants and assistants, as well as the standard firm email disclosures and external email cautions.

episodes.natural_language:
This note documents an email thread about the Mills v. Forcht Bank matter in Knox Circuit Court, Case No. 20-CI-00112, on behalf of client Amy Mills. The involved parties were Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm and Betsy R. Catron of Vine Center/WHT Law, with Sarena Tuttle and the Amy Mills Filevine alias copied on various messages.

On January 19, 2022, Aaron Whaley sent the latest message in the thread to Betsy Catron, with Sarena Tuttle and Amy Mills’ Filevine address CC’d, and the subject line referencing Mills v. Forcht Bank and the Knox Circuit Court case. In his email, Whaley wrote a single line: “thank god.” This followed Betsy Catron’s earlier note about the Knox Circuit Court scheduling issue (described below).

Earlier in the week, Betsy Catron had written on January 19, 2022 at 3:01 PM that she had just seen a posting on the Knox Circuit Court Clerk’s Facebook page informing that Judge Caperton’s Knox Circuit Court had been cancelled for January 20, 2022. All cases would be rescheduled for February 14, 2022 at the regular time, and she provided the clerk’s office phone number (546 3075) for questions. She signed as Betsy R. Catron, Associate Attorney at Vine Center, with the firm’s Lexington, Kentucky contact details.

The thread shows a longer back-and-forth spanning January 11–13, 2022, concerning filing documents and drafting. On January 13, 2022 at 2:54 PM, Aaron noted his new email address and said, “Looks good, Note my new email address. Thanks.” Earlier that same day, at 2:48 PM, Betsy had written, “Hi Aaron – please see attached. Let me know if you approve to file.” The previous day, January 12, 2022 at 7:21 PM, Betsy had responded, “No problem. I’ll get it done tomorrow. Thanks!” On January 11, 2022 at 10:03 PM, Aaron had quipped, “I am not lazy but care to draft? You can bill that. ????,” to which Betsy had replied earlier that day, “That is fine with me.” Earlier still, at 4:23 PM on January 11, 2022, Renee Day had forwarded to counsel the attached Notice of Withdrawal of Motion to Compel Only that had been filed with the court that afternoon, inviting any questions or concerns. Renee Day signed as Legal Assistant to Jillian House, Betsy Catron, Catie Coldiron Joseph, and Kaylee Collins, at the Vine Center, with the firm’s standard disclaimer at the bottom of the message.

In the sequence of these communications, Betsy later confirmed, “No problem. I’ll get it done tomorrow. Thanks!” and the correspondence continued toward filing an item described as a “Proposed Agreed Order” and a “Motion to adopt.” Aaron had suggested drafting such an Agreed Order, with grounds stating that the plaintiff had only recently been released from active treatment and that extending deadlines by another six months would allow counsel to complete record retrieval, consult experts, and mediate the case. The exchange noted that the court would not permit extending the deadline via an agreed order, and they discussed filing the Proposed Agreed Order along with the Motion to adopt.

The sequence also includes a formal attachment in Renee Day’s January 11, 2022 email, which is the Notice of Withdrawal of Motion to Compel Only, filed with the court in the above-referenced case. The thread closes with the standard firm email signatures and confidentiality notices. The final details show Aaron Whaley at Whaley Law Firm in Louisville, Kentucky, with his contact information provided for further correspondence.

Hi Aaron,

The Court has entered our proposed Agreed Order on extending all deadlines in the case by using a reference date of January 1, 2023.

Attached are records we recently received from Norton Orthopedic. Based upon our previous discussions, it appears your client's last treatment was December 16, 2021. Please advise if she does continue any fall-related treatment.

Next, as you had previously advised that your client was making a claim for impairment of her ability to earn money in the future, we will need her tax returns as requested in discovery. We are missing returns for the years 2016, 2018, and 2020. Please provide those to me as soon as possible.

Lastly, once you have had an opportunity to review the new deadlines, give me a call to let me know what your thoughts are with regard to setting the case for mediation.

Thank you,

Catron of WHT Law to acknowledge the invitation to schedule mediation in the above-referenced case and to inquire whether both sides would be agreeable to Hon. Thomas Knopf as the mediator, and what dates would be available. If Hon. Knopf was not agreeable, she requested a selection of other mediators of WHT Law’s choosing. She concluded by expressing a desire to work toward an amicable resolution for all parties and invited any questions, providing contact details for further discussion. The Whaley Law Firm information listed included the firm’s Louisville, Kentucky office, and the standard contact details for Sarena Tuttle (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 365-9435; O: (502) 583-4022; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com; and noting a new email address). There is also an external caution note about emails from external senders.

On March 4, 2022, Sarena Tuttle replied to Betsy Catron and attached the 2018 tax documents that had been requested. She explained that their client did not file a tax return in 2020 because she did not work due to the accident, and that the client was having trouble locating the 2016 tax documents; if the 2016 documents could be located, they would be forwarded upon receipt. In the same message, Sarena asked Betsy to confirm whether her office was agreeable to Hon. Thomas Knopf as the mediator and to provide dates when they were available. If Hon. Knopf was not agreeable, she requested that Betsy supply a selection of other mediators of WHT Law’s choosing. She reaffirmed their intention to work toward an amicable resolution for all parties and invited questions or discussion as needed. The email was signed by Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s Louisville address listed again, and included her direct line and general office line, and noted the new email address. The message was cc’d to Aaron Whaley and to AmyMillsPremiseZ995806@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com.

Earlier still, on February 23, 2022, Sarena Tuttle had written to Mrs. Catron with the same mediation scheduling request. She thanked Mrs. Catron for the opportunity to schedule mediation in the above-referenced cases and reiterated the request to know whether the parties were agreeable to Hon. Thomas Knopf as the mediator and to provide available dates; she also asked for alternative mediators if Knopf was not agreeable. She closed by expressing a commitment to an amicable resolution for all parties and inviting any questions, providing the same contact details and noting the newly provided email address. The message carried the Whaley Law Firm contact information: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 365-9435; O: (502) 583-4022; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS). The note also carried an external email caution banner.

On March 10, 2022, Betsy Catron responded to Sarena, apologizing for the delayed reply and stating that WHT Law was agreeable to Judge Knopf as the mediator. Betsy asked Sarena whether a July mediation could be scheduled and closed with her thanks. Betsy’s signature identified her as Associate Attorney at WHT Law, with the firm’s Lexington, Kentucky address listed as Vine Center, 333 West Vine Street, Suite 1100, Lexington, KY 40507, and her contact details: P 859.422.6000, F 859.422.6001, and the firm’s website www.whtlaw.com. This message was CC’d to Aaron Whaley and AmyMillsPremiseZ995806@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com.

In summary, between February 23 and March 10, 2022, The Whaley Law Firm and WHT Law exchanged multiple emails to schedule mediation for Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank, Knox Circuit II, with a preference for Hon. Thomas (Thomas) Knopf as mediator, consideration of July as a mediation date, and with the client’s tax documents (2018 attached, and notes about 2016 and 2020 filings) discussed for production as needed. The communications included the parties’ official contact details and noted a new email address for Sarena Tuttle.

In the meantime, Sarena asked Betsy to advise whether they were agreeable to Hon. Thomas Knopf as the mediator and to share available dates; if Hon. Knopf was not agreeable, to provide a selection of other mediators. Sarena’s signature again included The Whaley Law Firm details and a reminder of the new email address (PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS).

Earlier still, on March 10, 2022 at 1:39 PM, Betsy Catron replied. She apologized for the delayed response and stated that WHT Law was agreeable to Judge Knopf as the mediator. She asked Sarena whether they could attempt a July mediation and thanked her.

In sum, the email dialogue established mutual openness to mediation in July, with Hon. Thomas Knopf (Hon. Thomas Knopf/Judge Knopf) identified as the preferred mediator, and a scheduling window that becomes available after July 11, with the exception of July 19. The discussions included references to tax documents (2018 attached, 2020 non-filing due to not working from the accident, difficulty locating 2016) and a plan to forward missing documents if located.

Case: Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank, Knox Circuit II, Mediation Scheduling. Client: Amy Mills. The matter centers on arranging mediation for the above-referenced case, with the discussions spanning February and March 2022 between Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm and Betsy R. Catron of WHT Law, regarding a mediator, dates, and logistical details.

The scheduling dialogue began with an email from Sarena Tuttle dated February 23, 2022. In that message, she thanked Mrs. Catron for the opportunity to schedule mediation and asked whether the office would be agreeable to Hon. Thomas Knopf as the mediator, and what dates were available. If Knopf were not agreeable, she requested a selection of alternative mediators. She noted that the client’s 2018 tax documents were attached and indicated that Amy Mills did not file a tax return in 2020 because she was not working due to the accident, and she was having trouble locating 2016 tax documents; if 2016 documents could be located, they would be forwarded upon receipt. She concluded by expressing a desire to work toward an amicable resolution and invited further questions. The email included contact details for Sarena M. Tuttle and carried a note about the new email address.

A follow-up email from Sarena Tuttle on March 4, 2022 reiterated the request to schedule mediation and confirmed the attachment of the 2018 Tax Documents. She again explained that Amy Mills did not file in 2020 due to not working after the accident and was having trouble locating 2016 documents, with a commitment to forward 2016 documents if located. Sarena asked whether the office was agreeable to Hon. Thomas Knopf as mediator and requested available dates; if Knopf was not agreeable, she asked for a selection of other mediators. She closed with a positive note about working toward an amicable resolution and encouraged direct contact for questions. This March 4 email was CC’d to Aaron Whaley and included the case file email address AmyMillsPremiseZ995806@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com.

On March 10, 2022, Betsy Catron replied that WHT Law was agreeable to Judge Knopf and asked whether July mediation could be attempted. Separately that same day, Sarena Tuttle acknowledged receipt of the tax documents, apologized for any confusion, and stated that she would review the file again. She indicated that July sounded great for mediation, that they were pretty open that month, and that she believed Judge Knopf was as well. She asked if there were any specific dates preferred.

Later that day, Betsy responded that they were pretty open, with availability anytime after July 11, and that July 19 should be avoided. On March 11, 2022, Sarena proposed July 14, 2022 as a great day and asked whether a full-day or half-day would be necessary, noting a preference for the afternoon if a half-day was acceptable.

Finally, on March 11, 2022 at 16:52:45, Betsy confirmed that July 14, 2022 could work and indicated that a half-day would be sufficient, with the afternoon also being acceptable. The correspondence closed with Betsy’s standard contact information and the firm’s branding.

In summary, the parties pursued mediation scheduling for Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank before Hon. Thomas Knopf, with July 14, 2022 identified as the preferred date and a preference for a half-day session in the afternoon, while remaining flexible about the exact duration. The exchange also documented the client’s tax document status (2018 provided; 2020 not filed due to lack of work; 2016 to be located if possible) and included the attachment of the 2018 tax documents in the March 4 communications.

episodes.natural_language:
This file, labeled Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019, concerns client Amy Mills and relates to the civil action Amy Mills v Forcht Bank in Knox Circuit Court, Division II (Civil Action 20-CI-00112).

On March 11, 2022, at 12:20:30 PM Eastern Time, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm in Louisville sent an appointment request to Retired Judges Mediation and Arbitration Services regarding scheduling Hon. Thomas J. Knopf (Ret.) for the afternoon of Thursday, July 14, 2022. The location was to be by video conference. The request was sent on behalf of Sarena Tuttle, representing the plaintiff, Amy Mills, in the matter of Amy Mills v Forcht Bank (Knox County). The full case caption requested included the plaintiff and defendant, and the addresses and email addresses of counsel.

Counsel for the case were identified as follows: For the plaintiff, Aaron G. Whaley, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; email AGWhaley@WhaleyLawFirm.com; counsel for Plaintiff Amy Mills. A request was also made to cc the paralegal at Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (noting this as a new email address). For the defendant, Betsy R. Catron, Esq., Ward, Hocker & Thornton, PLLC, 333 W. Vine Street, #1100, Lexington, KY 40507; email Betsy.Catron@WHTLaw.com; counsel for Defendant Forcht Bank. Sarena M. Tuttle’s contact details were provided as The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with direct and office phones D: (502) 365-9435; O: (502) 583-4022, and email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (noting the new email address).

Earlier that same day, Debbie Shahayda, Administrator of Retired Judges Mediation and Arbitration Services, replied to the message. She stated that she had Hon. Knopf on the calendar for July 14 at 1:30 PM and requested that the sender provide the full case caption, including the names, addresses, and email addresses of counsel.

Separately, an automated message from the National Academy of Distinguished Neutrals (NADN) confirmed a new appointment request. The NADN email, sent to Debbie Shahayda, notified that there was an online request for Hon. Thomas J. Knopf (Ret.) for the afternoon of Thursday, July 14, 2022, with location listed as By Video Conference. The appointment request was submitted by Sarena Tuttle, on behalf of the attorney Sarena Tuttle, representing the plaintiff, The Whaley Law Firm, at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, telephone 502-365-9435 and fax 502-364-9363. The case name listed was Amy Mills v Forcht Bank (Knox County). The NADN note also indicated that defense counsel/attendees were in agreement for the appointment. NADN Kentucky Chapter and NADN’s national site were provided, along with contact details for NADN support.

In summary, the file documents a mediation/arbitration appointment request for July 14, 2022, at 1:30 PM (afternoon) by video conference with Hon. Thomas J. Knopf (Ret.) for the case Amy Mills v Forcht Bank, Knox County, Civil Action 20-CI-00112, Knox Circuit Court – Division II. The request incorporates the full case caption details, counsel names, addresses, emails, and contact information for both plaintiff and defense counsel, and notes that defense counsel were in agreement for the appointment. It also records the communications from Debbie Shahayda requesting the full caption and the NADN’s automated confirmation of the appointment request.

episodes.natural_language:
In the case of Amy Mills v Forcht Bank, Knox Circuit II, mediation was being scheduled in 2022. The client is Amy Mills. The Whaley Law Firm, represented by Sarena M. Tuttle, coordinated the mediation scheduling with Betsy R. Catron, Associate Attorney at Vine Center. The communication trail began with requests to confirm a mediator and to gather available dates, with Hon. Thomas J. Knopf proposed as the mediator and other mediators to be offered if Knopf was not agreeable. The parties discussed July as a potential mediation month, with a preference for afternoons and half-day sessions if possible. The email chain shows input from multiple participants and includes a note that the Notice of Mediation would be attached when finalized, and that the mediation would be conducted via Zoom, with Zoom login details to be provided by the National Arbitration and Dispute Association (NADA) closer to the date. The correspondence also included copies to NADA so that they could be cc’d on any mediation-related communications.

Chronologically, on February 23, 2022, Sarena Tuttle sent a message to Betsy Catron asking whether the office was agreeable to Hon. Thomas Knopf as the mediator and requesting available dates, with a suggestion to provide alternatives if Knopf was not agreeable. The message, which cautioned recipients about external emails, also indicated the correspondence would be forwarded to a wider audience, including Aaron Whaley and the Amy Mills filevine address, and noted that NADA would be cc’d on mediation communications. On March 4, 2022, Sarena followed up with attached 2018 Tax Documents; she explained that Amy Mills did not file a 2020 tax return because she did not work due to the accident and that she was having trouble locating 2016 tax documents; if the 2016 documents were located, they would be forwarded. She asked Betsy to indicate whether Hon. Thomas Knopf was agreeable as mediator and which dates were available, and if Knopf was not agreeable, to propose other mediators. This message also included the Whaley Firm’s contact details and stated that they looked forward to an amicable resolution.

On March 10, 2022, Betsy replied that she was agreeable to Judge Knopf and asked whether July mediation would work, noting they were pretty open and suggesting a half-day in the afternoon if possible. Later that same day, Sarena responded that July sounded great and asked Betsy to confirm whether a full day or half day would be needed, reiterating a preference for an afternoon half-day. By March 11, 2022, Betsy stated that they were good with July 14, 2022 and that a half-day would be fine, with the afternoon also acceptable. Sarena then confirmed that she would get the mediation scheduled and noticed.

Subsequently, on March 11, 2022 at 12:43 PM, Sarena sent a final, formal notice confirming the mediation details: Hon. Thomas J. Knopf would serve as mediator for Amy Mills v Forcht Bank, with the mediation set for July 14, 2022 at 1:30 PM via Zoom. The Notice of Mediation would be provided by the NADA, which would supply Zoom information closer to the mediation date. The Whaley Law Firm reported that the NADA had been provided Amy Mills’ contact information to cc them on any mediation correspondence. The notice was attached, and the email included Sarena’s updated contact details, including her new email address, along with the Whaley Law Firm’s address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222) and direct and office phone numbers (D: 502-365-9435; O: 502-583-4022). It also included her email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com.

For reference, Betsy Catron’s contact details were also present in the correspondence: Associate Attorney at Vine Center, 333 West Vine Street, Suite 1100, Lexington, KY 40507; P: 859-422-6000; F: 859-422-6001; website: www.whtlaw.com. The emails demonstrate a coordinated effort to schedule a July mediation session, confirm the mediator, address tax documentation issues, and arrange Zoom access through NADA, with all relevant parties kept informed and CC’d as appropriate.

episodes.natural_language:
The case at hand is Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank, Knox Cir II, with mediation scheduling discussions spanning February and March 2022 between The Whaley Law Firm and the Vine Center, on behalf of Amy Mills. The participants in the emails were Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm and Betsy R. Catron, Associate Attorney at Vine Center, with the matter noted as Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019 and client Amy Mills. Sarena’s signature repeatedly notes the Whaley Firm’s Louisville office and includes a new email address, Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, along with direct-dial and main phone numbers.

On February 23, 2022, Sarena opened the mediation scheduling discussion with Betsy Catron, asking whether the parties were agreeable to Hon. Thomas Knopf as the mediator and requesting available dates. She also asked Betsy to provide a selection of alternative mediators if Knopf was not agreeable. Sarena’s email included guidance about external emails and attached her firm’s contact information.

In a March 4, 2022 email, Sarena advised that she had attached the 2018 tax documents requested. She explained that Amy Mills did not file a tax return in 2020 because she did not work due to the accident and that Mills was having trouble locating 2016 tax documents; if Mills located the 2016 documents, they would be forwarded. She reiterated the request for consent to Judge Knopf as mediator and asked what dates were available, inviting Betsy to provide a selection of other mediators if Knopf was not agreeable. The message closed with the standard offer to discuss any questions further and repeated the contact details for Sarena and her new email address.

By March 10, 2022, Betsy replied that they were agreeable to Judge Knopf and asked whether a July mediation could be scheduled. The exchange continued with Sarena acknowledging the need to review the tax documents and confirming that July appeared to be a suitable month for mediation, noting that her office was fairly flexible that month and that they believed Judge Knopf was as well. She also asked whether Betsy had any specific dates in mind.

Later that same day, March 10, Sarena responded again, stating that July sounded great for mediation and that her team was open to scheduling within that month and believed Judge Knopf was as well. She asked Betsy to share any specific date preferences.

On March 11, Betsy replied that they were pretty open after July 11, with the exception of July 19. She asked for confirmation of availability and continued the dialogue about July mediation.

That same day, March 11, at 11:03 a.m., Sarena proposed July 14, 2022, as a target date, asking whether a half-day would be sufficient or if they would prefer a full day. She indicated a preference for the afternoon if a half-day schedule was acceptable.

At 11:52 a.m. on March 11, Betsy confirmed that they were good with July 14 and that a half-day would be fine, with the afternoon also acceptable.

Finally, at 12:04 p.m. on March 11, Sarena expressed appreciation and stated that she would get the mediation scheduled and noticed. She signed off with her contact information once again, reinforcing that the arrangement would be set and communicated to the parties involved.

In sum, the parties converged on Hon. Thomas Knopf as the mediator, settled on July 14, 2022 for a mediation session, and negotiated a preferred half-day timeframe in the afternoon, with both sides indicating flexibility around exact timing and confirming the plan to schedule and notice the mediation accordingly.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills.

In the matter of a NeuroSurgery Appointment, correspondence between Amy Mills and Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm occurred in April and May of 2022 regarding updated neurosurgical imaging as recommended by Dr. Gregory Nazar. On April 26, 2022, Sarena sent Amy an email instructing her to contact her neurosurgery provider to request updated imaging per Dr. Nazar’s addendum (which Sarena attached for the provider’s review). The message also included Sarena’s contact information and a note to reference her new email address, with the firm’s Louisville, Kentucky location and phone numbers.

Later on April 26, 2022, Amy replied that May 3rd at 5:30 p.m. would be her first available appointment, and she would send a follow-up email attached to let Sarena know when the MRI appointment set up by her neuro team would occur. She expressed thanks. Sarena responded to that update later that day with, “Sounds good, thank you,” and signed off with her firm’s details, including address, direct and office phone numbers, and her new email address.

On May 6, 2022, at 8:46 a.m., Amy wrote again, stating that she had attended her appointment with Teresa on Tuesday, and Teresa had ordered the necessary scans, but they had not yet been able to schedule her in; she noted that they were cutting the appointment with the neurosurgery doctor close and asked whether they should reschedule that appointment for not this coming week but the next, or something else.

Later that same day, at 9:14 a.m., Amy provided an update that she had just scheduled the MRI-related appointment for May 26, 2022, at 1:30 p.m. She explained that the imaging center is very backed up and that she would need three procedures conducted together, which would take longer; that timing reflects the earliest availability she could secure at the diagnostic center to obtain the MRI.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

episodes.natural_language:
This note covers communications between Amy Mills and Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm regarding Amy’s neuroSurgery appointment and related imaging. The thread begins with an email from Sarena on April 26, 2022, in which she advised Amy to contact her neurosurgery provider and request updated imaging as recommended by Dr. Gregory Nazar, attaching a copy of Dr. Nazar’s addendum for the physician’s review. In reply, later that same day, Amy indicated that May 3 would be “a week from today” and that May 3 at 5:30 p.m. was her first available slot; she planned to send a follow-up email confirming when her MRI appointment would be set. Sarena acknowledged with “Sounds good, thank you!”

Earlier that same day, Amy had written that the May 3 appointment was the first available, and she intended to send an email attaching the MRI appointment details once they were set. In response, Sarena again confirmed and Amy reiterated her plan to notify once the MRI appointment was scheduled.

Subsequently, on May 6, 2022, Amy reported that she had attended an appointment with Teresa, who ordered the scans but, as of that time, they had not been able to schedule her in yet; Amy asked whether they should reschedule the neurosurgery appointment that week or the following week. Later on May 6, Sarena requested the location information for the scheduled imaging, providing her firm’s Louisville contact details (The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: 502-365-9435; O: 502-583-4022; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com; note the new email address).

Amy answered, informing that the imaging was scheduled for May 26, 2022 at 1:30 p.m. She explained that the imaging center was very backed up and that she would require three scans to be completed together, which would take longer, but that May 26 was the soonest available slot at the diagnostic center to obtain the MRI.

On May 7, 2022, Amy clarified to Sarena that the imaging center is Corbin Imaging and Diagnostic Center, which is part of Corbin Hospital.

Finally, on May 9, 2022 at 10:20:28 a.m. Eastern Time, Amy reported that the Louisville neuroSurgery appointment had been rescheduled for July 25 at 11:00 a.m. She noted that the clinic had called her back after she had left a message the previous week regarding her MRI appointments and their scheduling. The thread as a whole shows ongoing coordination about updated imaging per Dr. Nazar’s addendum, scheduling updates for MRI imaging (including three scans to be done together at Corbin Imaging and Diagnostic Center on May 26 at 1:30 p.m.), and the rescheduling of the Louisville neuroSurgery appointment to July 25 at 11:00 a.m.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

 We attempted to contact you this morning. Unfortunately, the call went

status of your claim and to review your medical treatment to date.

accepting clients. Please locate and/or request copies of these documents

Case: Amy Mills. This case file, titled Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019, concerns the client Amy Mills. The latest correspondence is a June 20, 2022 email from Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm to Amy Mills (bellabeautyinstitute@gmail.com), with Aaron Whaley copied. The subject was “Re: Case Update - Additional Documents & Information Request.” The message states that the firm had attempted to reach Amy again that day, but the recording indicated her voice mailbox was full and no message could be left. They had also emailed with no response, and Sarena emphasizes that, at this stage of litigation, communication is imperative and there is urgent information to discuss. She asks Amy to contact the office as soon as possible regarding her claim. The signature block includes The Whaley Law Firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, the direct line (502) 365-9435, the office line (502) 583-4022, and the email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note indicating this is a new email address.

Earlier in the same case, on June 10, 2022, at 12:29 PM, Sarena Tuttle sent an email to Amy. In that message, Sarena wrote that they had attempted to contact Amy that morning and the call went to voicemail but the voicemail was full, so they could not leave a message. She asked Amy to contact them as soon as possible to discuss the current status of her claim and to review her medical treatment to date. Sarena also reminded Amy that they had discussed tax information several times and that the Defense still needed Amy’s 2016 and 2018 tax documents, as well as the date that Bella Beauty closed and stopped accepting clients. She requested that Amy locate and/or request copies of these documents so the Defense could provide them, noting that these documents are required to calculate any lost income and loss of future earnings to which Amy may be entitled. The email closed with Sarena’s standard signature and contact information, including the new email address.

Approximately an hour later, on June 10, 2022 at 1:23 PM, Sarena Tuttle sent another message to Amy. This time, she acknowledged that Amy had been having issues locating past tax information and explained that they had located an IRS website that would allow Amy to either request or download copies of past tax information. Sarena provided the link to the IRS site (https://www.irs.gov/individuals/get-transcript) and invited Amy to set up an account and request the missing documents for the Defense Counsel. The message concluded with Sarena’s signature block, again listing The Whaley Law Firm’s address, the direct and office phone numbers, and the email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, along with the note to “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”

In the Amy Mills case file (Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019), the client, Amy Mills, was scheduled for a Functional Capacity Evaluation (FCE) to be conducted at BioKinetics in Louisville, Kentucky. The appointment was set for Monday, July 25, 2022 at 11:00 a.m., at 9900 Corporate Campus Drive, Suite 2400, Louisville, KY 40223. This was confirmed in an FCE Appointment Reminder for July 25, 2022 at 11:00 a.m.

The reminder originated in an email sent on Tuesday, July 5, 2022 at 10:26:10 a.m. Eastern Time from Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm to Amy Mills (bellabeautyinstitute@gmail.com), with Aaron Whaley CC’d (agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com). The message thanked Amy for speaking with the sender that morning and stated that appointment details were attached. It noted that the FCE would be held at BioKinetics at the address above, and it requested that Amy execute a HIPAA authorization sent via DocuSign so they could request updated medical records. The sender indicated she would update Amy as soon as she learned more about an outstanding health insurance issue, and she invited Amy to contact them with any questions. The note included the sender’s contact information: Sarena M. Tuttle, The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 365-9435; O: (502) 583-4022; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a parenthetical note to “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”

Separately, the record shows that the FCE appointment was rescheduled. The entry notes: “Appointment Rescheduled for The Whaley Law Firm Amy Mills (606) 304-0342,” with the specifics that the appointment was for a Functional Capacity Evaluation (Louisville, KY) Biokinetics. The old time was Monday, May 9, 2022 at 11:00 a.m., and the new time became Monday, July 25, 2022 at 11:00 a.m., with the same location: 9900 Corporate Campus Drive, Suite 2400, Louisville, KY 40223. The note confirms that the appointment has been successfully rescheduled. Additional options listed include Change/Cancel Appointment and the ability to add the event to iCal/Outlook, Google Calendar, or to unsubscribe.

Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019
Client: Amy Mills

Called Client this morning - She advised she is having a Bone Scan w/Dye today - PCP has requested 3 additional images, neck, shoulder & arm - PHI would only approve 1 so MRI of arm only was completed - something was noted on her arm and is now having bone scan to determine origin - She will call us w/additional information once determined - She agreed to complete HIPAA emailed to her and requested Email Reminder of FCE location - Sent #cc
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on April 26, 2019, with Amy Mills. This morning she called to report that she is having a bone scan with dye today. Her PCP had requested three additional images—neck, shoulder, and arm—but PHI would only approve one, so an MRI of the arm only was completed. Something was noted on her arm, and she is now having a bone scan to determine its origin. She will call us with any additional information once it is determined.

She agreed to complete the HIPAA form emailed to her and requested an email reminder of the FCE location. A copy was sent to #cc.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

Case: Amy Mills – Premise file dated 04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills. Re: FCE Appointment Reminder for July 25, 2022 at 11:00 a.m.

Between July 5 and July 17, 2022, an email thread circulated between Amy Mills and Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm regarding an upcoming Functional Capacity Evaluation (FCE) and related documents. The subject indicated a reminder for an FCE appointment scheduled for July 25, 2022 at 11:00 a.m., to be held at BioKinetics, located at 9900 Corporate Campus Drive, Suite 2400, Louisville, KY 40223. The thread also references HIPAA authorization and requests for updated medical records, as well as a health insurance issue.

On July 5, 2022, Sarena Tuttle sent Amy Mills appointment details and noted that Amy should execute the HIPAA authorization sent via DocuSign so the firm could obtain updated medical records. Sarena stated she would update Amy as soon as more information became available about the health insurance issue. In her signature, Sarena provided her contact information for The Whaley Law Firm—712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222—with direct and office phone numbers and her email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, and she reminded that this was a new email address.

On July 7, 2022 at 2:06 p.m., Amy Mills replied that she believed the information was correct and that she would review it, adding that she would confirm and provide details as she thought she had done so.

Later that same day, at 2:57 p.m., Sarena responded that she appreciated Amy’s note and that the HIPAA document would have come from DocuSign; she offered to resend it in case it had gone to spam.

On July 11, 2022, at 12:50 p.m., Amy Mills wrote that she believed the DocuSign item had been sent, and that she thought she had signed it, but she would verify and let the firm know if all needed items were in order.

At 1:00 p.m. that day, Sarena replied that she had received the HIPAA item back and thanked Amy. She then requested confirmation of whether Amy had applied for a PPP loan and, if so, what the outcome was.

On July 15, 2022, at 11:16 p.m., Amy Mills responded that she thought she had completed what was required but was not completely sure and would check, asking to be informed for certainty and any needed details.

Finally, on July 17, 2022, at 6:41 p.m., Sarena signed off asking Amy to confirm the outcome once more.

Signature blocks in the exchanges repeatedly identified Sarena M. Tuttle as The Whaley Law Firm representative, with the firm’s Louisville address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222) and contact numbers (D: 502-365-9435; O: 502-583-4022) and Sarena’s email (Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com). The thread also shows Amy Mills’ primary contact as bellabeautyinstitute@gmail.com. The messages reference a new email address for Sarena, noted in her signature as part of the firm’s contact details.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills. This note documents the email correspondence regarding an FCE appointment reminder for July 25, 2022 at 11:00 a.m., and related HIPAA authorization matters.

On July 15, 2022, Amy Mills sent an email from bellabeautyinstitute@gmail.com to Sarena Tuttle at Whaley Law Firm (sarena@whaleylawfirm.com) with the subject “Re: FCE Appointment Reminder - 07/25/2022 11am.” In her message, Amy wrote: “I think so but I’m not sure I will check And let u for for sure and details (I think I did tho).”

Earlier in the thread, on July 11, 2022 at 1:00 p.m., Sarena Tuttle replied: “Good afternoon Amy, I did receive the HIPAA back. Thank you. I just need to confirm whether or not you applied for a PPP loan and if so, what was the outcome?” At the time, Sarena’s contact details appeared as: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, D: (502) 365-9435, O: (502) 583-4022, E: Sarena@Whttps://www.google.com/maps/search/712MAIL ADDRESS) (note the garbled email address line).

Earlier still, on July 11, 2022 at 12:50 p.m., Amy Mills wrote: “I think that it did. I think I have it signed now Just check it and let me know you have all you need and then we will go from there.”

On July 7, 2022, at 2:57 p.m., Sarena Tuttle replied: “Your welcome. It would have come from Docusign but I will resend it in case it went to spam or something.” In that message her signature stated: Sarena M. Tuttle, The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, D: (502) 365-9435, O: (502) 583-4022, E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS).

Earlier still, on July 7, 2022 at 2:06 p.m., Amy Mills wrote: “Thank you for your email on tha Appointment details for July 25th. You mentioned signing a new medical release form but I have not seen an email on that.”

And on July 5, 2022 at 10:25 a.m., Sarena Tuttle wrote: “Good morning Amy, Thank you for speaking with me this morning, please find your appointment details attached. Your FCE will be held at BioKinetics located at 9900 Corporate Campus Drive, Suite 2400, Louisville, KY 40223. As discussed, please execute the HIPAA authorization sent to you via DocuSign so we can request your updated medical records and I will update you as soon as I am able to find out more about the health insurance issue. If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact us to discuss them in further detail.” The signature block for that message again listed Sarena M. Tuttle, The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, D: (502) 365-9435, O: (502) 583-4022, E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS).

In summary, the case involves Amy Mills coordinating an FCE appointment for July 25, 2022 at 11:00 a.m., with follow-up regarding HIPAA authorization (DocuSign), whether Amy had applied for a PPP loan and the outcome of that application, and related questions about a medical release form. The FCE was scheduled to be held at BioKinetics, 9900 Corporate Campus Drive, Suite 2400, Louisville, KY 40223. The ongoing communications include confirmations of HIPAA back, discussions of DocuSign actions, potential spam concerns, and references to updated medical records and health insurance issues.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills.

On August 19, 2022, at 10:10 a.m., Amy Mills wrote to Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm, asking for an update on progress. In her message, she stated she was glad the PPP loan information had been obtained, noting that since she is no longer in business she would have to file bankruptcy because the loans were based on the 2019 tax year. She also mentioned that she had been able to obtain more PPP funds but was unsure whether she would be medically able to be healed in time to continue. She expressed the view that this information should not be entered into her case, and she complained that she had not been given an updated report for the FCE or its findings. She alleged that the defense was grasping for anything they could to minimize the amount they would have to pay. She referenced an MRI report stating a current acute tear in her arm, but said doctors were not on the same page to obtain treatment. She further asserted that the defendants should be held responsible for medical malpractice due to a misdiagnosis at the initial ER treatment, which she claimed prolonged her treatment, pain, and suffering, and she argued that such consequences would not have happened if the misdiagnosis had not occurred in the first place. She stated that this has been ongoing for almost four years, during which she has had days when she cannot get out of bed and experiences migraines so severe that she feels she is dying. She concluded that she primarily receives medication and continued symptoms but no remedy to the problem. Her signature included the line: “The heart of a fool is in his mouth, but the mouth of a wise man is in his heart.” — Benjamin Franklin.

At 10:15 a.m. the same day, Sarena responded to Amy, explaining that they had received the FCE Report and that Aaron had forwarded it to the defense for their review. She also noted that documents from Hometown Bank regarding Amy’s PPP loans had been received and were under review. She acknowledged that Aaron had been in correspondence with the defense, but she did not have the details of those conversations and would reach out to him for a more detailed update. Her message included the firm’s contact information and a note to their client, including the firm’s Louisville address and phone numbers, and the reminder to note a new email address: sarena@whaleylawfirm.com.

Earlier that same day, at 10:10 a.m., Amy had sent another brief message to Sarena asking for an update on progress, signing as Amy Mills and reiterating the quoted Franklin line in her signature.

Later, at 11:08 a.m., Amy continued to correspond, reiterating her concerns and elaborating on the lack of an updated FCE report and the ongoing dispute over the handling of the PPP loan information, the possibility of bankruptcy based on the 2019 tax year, and the medical issues including the MRI-documented arm tear, the need for coordinated medical treatment, and the alleged medical malpractice stemming from an ER misdiagnosis that she claimed has continued to cause pain and suffering for nearly four years. She reiterated that her condition includes days when she cannot get out of bed and severe migraines, and that she has primarily received medication without a lasting remedy.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills.

On August 19, 2022, in a communication from Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm to Amy Mills, the firm acknowledged Amy’s concerns and explained the defense’s rights in this matter. Sarena stated that the defense is entitled to know whether Amy recovered lost wages during her recovery and, if so, from whom. Because Amy had obtained a Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) loan to cover lost wages, Sarena understood that the defense would not be responsible for those “lost wages,” since they were funded by the loan. The defense would likely have to subrogate, reimbursing Hometown Bank for the funds provided. Sarena also indicated she would forward Amy’s email to Aaron for a more detailed address. She attached a copy of the FCE Report received on August 16, 2022 and apologized for not sending it sooner. The message included the Whaley Law Firm’s contact information and note of Sarena’s new email address: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com.

Earlier that day, at 10:10 AM, Amy Mills had sent a message containing a link: https://www.google.com/maps/search/712get an update on where we r with the progress. She wrote that she was glad the PPP loan information had been obtained, noting that because she was no longer in business, she would have to file bankruptcy since they used 2019 tax year data, and she had also been able to obtain more PPP funds but was not sure whether she would medically be healed in time to continue. Amy asserted that this information should not be brought to the defense or entered into her case. She complained that she had not received an updated FCE report or its findings, and she expressed concern that the defense was “reaching” to find anything at all to reduce payment. She referenced an MRI report indicating a current acute tear in her arm and described difficulty getting doctors aligned to provide treatment. She also claimed potential medical malpractice due to misdiagnosis at her initial ER treatment, which she believed prolonged her pain and suffering, arguing that this would not have happened if the accident had not occurred. She described her situation as ongoing for almost four years, with days when she could not get out of bed and migraines so severe she felt like she was dying, and she lamented that she was receiving only medications and persistent symptoms without a remedy.

At 10:15 AM, in reply to Amy’s earlier message, Sarena acknowledged receipt of the FCE Report and advised that Aaron had forwarded it to the defense for their review. She confirmed that documents from Hometown Bank regarding Amy’s PPP loans had also been received and were under review. Sarena noted that Aaron had been in correspondence with the defense, but she did not have the details of those conversations at that time; she stated she would reach out to him for a more detailed update. The message included Sarena’s signature block with the firm’s address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222) and direct lines, and again reminded that the new email address should be used.

Later, at 11:08 AM, Amy replied again, reiterating her position that it was beneficial to have the PPP loan information but highlighting personal circumstances. She explained that since she was no longer in business, she would need to consider bankruptcy because of the 2019 tax year, and she noted she had obtained additional PPP funds but remained uncertain about her medical prognosis. She insisted that this information should not affect her case, expressed dissatisfaction with not receiving an updated FCE report or findings, and criticized the defense for trying to locate anything to minimize their liability. She reiterated the MRI findings of a current acute tear in her arm and the lack of consensus among doctors regarding treatment. She pressed for accountability regarding alleged medical malpractice from an initial ER misdiagnosis, asserting that the misdiagnosis had prolonged her pain and suffering. She emphasized the ongoing nature of the ordeal—nearly four years—with days when she cannot get out of bed and debilitating migraines, and she complained that she continues to receive only medication and symptoms without a proper remedy.

The thread also included the exchange’s closing quotation from Amy Mills, quoting Benjamin Franklin: “The heart of a fool is in his mouth, but the mouth of a wise man is in his heart.” The communication chain reflects the ongoing efforts to update Amy on FCE-related findings, PPP loan documentation, and potential liability considerations, while also documenting Amy’s concerns about medical treatment, alleged medical malpractice, and the impact of these issues on her case. The case file preserves all names, dates, documents, and contact details, including the instructive note about Sarena’s new email address and the various ways to reach the involved parties.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills.

On August 19, 2022, Amy Mills emailed her attorney, Sarena M. Tuttle, regarding an update in the case. In her message (sent at 1:49:25 PM), Amy explained that she will have to pay bankruptcy because she was unable to keep the business open, and she noted that a bank representative also said the electric bill that had been paid would count toward the balance to be forgiven on the PPP.

Earlier that same day, at 11:36 AM, Sarena replied to Amy. She explained that the defense is entitled to know whether Amy recovered lost wages during her recovery and, if so, from whom. Since Amy had received a PPP loan to cover lost wages, the defense would not be responsible for those lost wages because they were not truly lost. The defense would most likely have to subrogate, meaning reimburse Hometown Bank for the funds provided. Sarena also said she would forward Amy’s email to Aaron for further address, and she attached a copy of the FCE Report received on 08/16/2022, apologizing for the delay in sending it.

Earlier still, at 11:08 AM, Amy had written expressing some frustration. She noted that it was good the PPP loan information had been obtained, but since she is no longer in business she would have to file bankruptcy because the bank’s determination used the 2019 tax year. She also indicated she had been able to obtain more PPP funds but was not sure if she would medically be able to be healed in time to continue. She stated she did not believe the PPP information should be entered into her case or presented to the defense. She complained that she had not received an updated report for the FCE or its findings, and she asserted that the defense appeared to be grasping for any possible means to avoid paying as much as possible. She referenced an MRI report indicating a current acute tear in her arm, but said doctors were not aligned to agree on treatment. She claimed medical malpractice due to an initial misdiagnosis in the ER, which she believed prolonged treatment, pain, and suffering. She wrote that this situation had been ongoing for almost four years, with days when she could not get out of bed and migraines so severe she felt as if she were dying, and that she mostly received medication with continued symptoms and no real remedy.

At 10:15 AM, Sarena sent another update to Amy. She stated that the FCE Report had been received and forwarded to the defense for their review. She noted that documents from Hometown Bank regarding Amy’s PPP loans were also under review. She acknowledged that Aaron had been in correspondence with the defense and that she would obtain a more detailed update from him.

Earlier, at 10:10 AM, Amy had messaged asking for an update on progress, signing off with her name and a Franklin quotation: “The heart of a fool is in his mouth, but the mouth of a wise man is in his heart.” The exchange also included further repeated signature lines from Amy Mills with the same Benjamin Franklin quotation.

This sequence of communications reflects the ongoing handling of reported lost wages, PPP loan implications, potential subrogation to a bank, and concerns about medical issues, misdiagnosis, and malpractice in the context of the case.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

Hi Aaron,
I wanted to follow up on a few things in this case. We requested records and bills from Ms. Mills' Norton providers as it was our understanding that she underwent an MRI at the end of May. None of those providers have any records for recent treatment for her. We are still waiting on her records and bills from Baptist Health Corbin. We will provide copies of those to you upon receipt. Please advise if there is any other recent medical treatment of Ms. Mills.
Further, you had previously advised of a FCE occurring in late July. Did this occur as planned? What are your thoughts on when you will be able to get us a demand?
We have also requested your client's tax returns for 2016, 2018 and 2020 several times. The lack of this information significantly limits our ability to evaluate her future earning impairment claim. We also need to know the last day that Bella Beauty was in business.
If you have any questions or would like to discuss the above in further detail, please do not hesitate to contact me.
Thank you,
Betsy R. Catron

On August 22, 2022, a pair of email messages regarding the case were exchanged between Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm and Betsy Catron of Vine Center, Lexington, KY, with the original messages copied to Sarena Tuttle and to Amy Mills Premise’s file email address. The subject of the correspondence was the Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank matter.

In Betsy Catron’s 10:10 a.m. email on August 22, 2022, she noted that she had requested records and bills from Ms. Mills’ Norton providers and understood that Ms. Mills underwent an MRI at the end of May; however, none of those Norton providers had any records of recent treatment. She asked Aaron to advise if there was any other recent medical treatment of Ms. Mills. Betsy further inquired about the delayed late-July Functional Capacity Evaluation (FCE) and when they would be able to obtain a demand. In the later 12:29 p.m. email that same day, Aaron Whaley responded to Betsy, saying he would forward any records they might be missing. The message was addressed from Aaron Whaley at Whaley Law Firm (712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222; 502-583-4022) to Betsy Catron at WHT Law, with cc to Sarena Tuttle and the Amy Mills Premise file address. work. Sedentary work is basically low level physical work that involves
mostly sitting, some walking/standing on occasions and nothing that
requires lifting over 10lbs. The report acknowledges that while you are
limited in the work you do, you are able to perform jobs that are not
physical in nature, examples would be a desk job or running your business
(handline paperwork) while employees actually perform the services.

financial impact these restrictions will have. Once we hear from the

well as the official date that Bella Beauty closed its doors. We understand
that your equipment and products are still in your location and you still
have possession of the location, however, we need the date of the last
services performed. We also understand your concern with providing all this
financial information but as we explained it is required in order to
determine the proper amount of compensation you should receive.

out to the IRS and/or your tax preparer and obtain copies as soon as

Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills. Update communications were sent and exchanged in August 2022 between Amy Mills and attorney Sara(ena) M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm regarding a work-capacity assessment and financial documentation, with the most recent update dated August 24, 2022.

On August 24, 2022 at 12:20 p.m. Eastern Time, Sara(ena) M. Tuttle wrote to Amy Mills with an update. In the body of the message, she explained that the FCE (functional capacity evaluation) report indicates Amy is able to perform sedentary work. She defined sedentary work as low-level physical work performed mostly while seated, with occasional walking or standing, and with no lifting over 10 pounds. The report also notes that, despite restrictions on the types of work Amy can perform, she is able to undertake jobs that are not physically demanding—examples given were desk-based employment or running her business (handling paperwork) while employees actually provide the required services. An economist has been arranged by Aaron to evaluate the financial impact of Amy’s restrictions, and a further update will be provided once the economist’s assessment is available.

The update also states that the firm is awaiting certain documents: Amy’s tax returns for 2016 and 2017, as well as the official date on which Bella Beauty ceased operations. The note acknowledges that Amy’s equipment and products remain at her location and she retains possession of the premises, but it requires the date of the last services performed. The message reiterates that while Amy may have concerns about providing financial information, the requested information is necessary to determine the proper amount of compensation she should receive. The firm advised that if Amy does not currently possess the tax documents, she should contact the IRS and/or her tax preparer to obtain copies as soon as possible. The message closes by inviting Amy to contact them with any questions. The email signature provides Sara(ena) M. Tuttle’s contact details and notes a new email address: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, along with the firm’s address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222), direct line (502) 357-9971, office line (502) 583-4022 ext. 104.

The message thread shows an email sequence surrounding the same topic. Earlier on August 24, 2022 at 10:11 a.m., Amy Mills replied with a query: “What exactly does that report mean?” seeking clarification about the contents and implications of the FCE report.

In the same thread, on August 19, 2022 at 1:49 p.m., Amy Mills wrote that she understood she might have to file bankruptcy because she could not remain in business, and she mentioned that a bank representative indicated the paid electric bill could count toward a balance forgiven under the PPP. She remarked that she was unable to stay open and questioned the relevance of these items to her case.

Earlier on August 19, 2022 at 11:36 a.m., Sarena Tuttle responded to Amy. She explained that the defense is entitled to know whether Amy recovered lost wages during her recovery and, since a PPP loan was received to cover lost wages, the defense would not be responsible for those “lost wages” if they were not actually lost (i.e., they were offset by the PPP funds). She indicated the defense would likely subrogate, meaning reimburse Hometown Bank for those funds. She said she would forward Amy’s email to Aaron for further addresses and attached a copy of the FCE Report received on August 16, 2022, apologizing for not sending it sooner.

Later on August 19, 2022 at 11:08 a.m., Amy Mills replied with several concerns. She stated she was glad the PPP loan information had been obtained but that, since she was no longer in business, bankruptcy would be necessary because the bank’s calculations were based on the 2019 tax year; she noted that she had been able to obtain additional PPP funds but was unsure whether she would medically be able to continue. She stressed that the PPP information should not have been entered into her case. She also complained that she had not received an updated FCE report or its findings. Amy expressed frustration that the defense might be attempting to minimize payments and referenced an MRI report indicating a current acute tear in her arm, but that doctors were not aligned on treatment. She described ongoing medical issues, including four years of symptoms with days she cannot get out of bed and migraines, and she criticized the medical care she received as a result of misdiagnosis, arguing that this prolonged pain was caused by earlier errors. She claimed to be receiving only medication and continued symptoms without a satisfactory remedy.

On August 19, 2022 at 10:15 a.m., Sarena Tuttle replied that they had received the FCE Report and that Aaron had forwarded it to the defense for review. She also stated that documents from Hometown Bank regarding Amy’s PPP loans were under review and that she would contact Aaron for a more detailed update.

Finally, on August 19, 2022 at 10:10 a.m., Amy Mills asked for an update on the progress of the matter.

Throughout these communications, the parties discussed the functional capacity assessment, the status and handling of PPP loan information, potential bankruptcy considerations, the need for tax documents from 2016 and 2017, the date Bella Beauty closed, and the ongoing medical issues, with requests for last services data and copies of tax documents to determine appropriate compensation. The correspondence included the Whaley Law Firm’s contact information, and the new email address for Saraena Tuttle.

Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills. This update concerns communications between Amy Mills and Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm regarding the status of the case and associated documents.

On August 24, 2022, Amy Mills emailed Sarena Tuttle with the subject “Re: Update,” asking, “What exactly does that report mean?” This appeared to be a follow-up to the ongoing discussion about recent documents and their implications for the case.

Earlier that week, the day before, on Friday, August 19, 2022 at 1:49 PM, Amy Mills wrote that she would have to file bankruptcy because she was unable to keep the business open. She also indicated that the bank determined the electric bill that had been paid would count toward the balance to be forgiven under the PPP. In her words, she noted: “Okay bc I will have to pay bk bc I was unable to stay open but the guy at the bank also said that the electric bill that was paid would also count toward that balance to be forgiven on the ppp.”

Also on August 19, 2022, at 11:36 AM, Sarena Tuttle responded. She explained that the defense is entitled to know whether Amy recovered lost wages during her recovery and, if so, from whom. Since Amy had received a PPP loan to cover lost wages, the defense would likely not be responsible for those “lost wages,” as they were not truly lost in light of the PPP funds. Sarena suggested that the defense may have to subrogate and reimburse Hometown Bank for the funds provided. She also stated that she would forward Amy’s email to Aaron for further address and appended a copy of the Functional Capacity Evaluation (FCE) Report received on August 16, 2022, noting an apology for the delayed sending.

That same day, at 11:08 AM, Amy Mills sent another message expressing concern: she was glad the PPP loan information had been obtained, but since she was no longer in business she would have to file bankruptcy based on the 2019 tax year. She indicated she had been able to obtain more PPP funds but was unsure whether she would medically be able to heal in time to continue. She asserted that none of this should impact the defense or be entered into her case. She also complained that she had not been given an updated FCE report or findings. She further described ongoing medical issues, including an MRI report showing a current acute tear in her arm, difficulties getting doctors aligned on treatment, and a belief that medical malpractice occurred due to misdiagnosis at the initial ER visit. She claimed the situation had persisted for almost four years, with ongoing days in bed, migraines, and only medication without a remedy, despite continued symptoms.

Earlier on August 19, 2022, at 10:15 AM, Sarena replied that the firm had received the FCE Report and that Aaron had forwarded it to the defense for their review. She also noted receipt of documents from Hometown Bank regarding Amy’s PPP loans, which were under review. She said Aaron had been in correspondence with the defense, but she did not have the details of those conversations and would contact him for a more detailed update.

At 10:10 AM on the same day, Amy had sent a brief message to Sarena asking for an update on progress: “Hey Sarena I was just wanting to get an update on where we r with the progress. Thank You, Amy Mills.” Her signature included a set of Benjamin Franklin quotations, culminating in the line: “The heart of a fool is in his mouth, but the mouth of a wise man is in his heart.” This quotation appears multiple times, reflecting her habitual closing, including variants and repetitions of the Franklin quotes.

In summary, the communications document ongoing efforts to interpret the FCE report, locate and review PPP loan documentation with Hometown Bank, and address broader concerns about bankruptcy, medical issues, alleged misdiagnosis and medical malpractice, and the potential impact of these items on the defense and the case. The team discussed potential subrogation to Hometown Bank, and Amy sought clarification on the meaning and implications of recent reports and updates, while also reaffirming her positions regarding the relevance of certain financial and medical documentation to the case.
