This case note, titled Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019 and pertaining to client Amy Mills, records a sequence of email exchanges in August 2022 between Amy Mills and Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm regarding updates to a functional capacity evaluation (FCE), related financial issues, and the status of Amy’s business and potential claims. On August 25, 2022 at 14:29:36 Eastern Time, Amy wrote to Sarena to contest elements of a prior report. She stated that she had been bedridden for two days after that appointment and had messaged Aaron; she noted that the doctor had identified the dominant hand incorrectly, insisting she is left-hand dominant, not right-handed. She reported that the pain level at the time she left the appointment was an eight, and she did not see that reflected in the report. She said she could hardly stand or sit before leaving, and that nothing in the report accounted for her chronic migraines. She described being barely able to leave her home, unable to run her business, which she described as a teaching institute for which there was no one qualified to do the work other than herself, and she claimed the business is bankrupt. She expressed concern about how she could work when she could barely write her name and noted memory and head-injury-related issues, including getting things mixed up. She recalled having someone drive her to the appointment and characterized her life as one she had built with significant effort, including a master’s degree, as having been effectively taken from her. She criticized the suggestion of a desk job as disregarding her acute, debilitating migraines and suggested that others did not care because it was not their life to live.

Earlier, on August 24, 2022 at 12:20 PM, Sarena replied to Amy with a summary of the FCE findings. She explained that the report concluded Amy is able to perform sedentary work—defined as low-level physical work requiring mostly sitting, with occasional walking or standing and no lifting over 10 pounds. The message stated that although Amy has work limitations, she can perform non-physical jobs such as a desk job or continuing to run her business (with others handling the services while she handles paperwork). Sarena noted that Aaron had arranged an evaluation with an economist to determine the financial impact of these restrictions, and that they would update Amy once the economist’s input was available. She added that they were awaiting tax documents from 2016 and 2017, as well as the official date Bella Beauty closed its doors. She acknowledged that Amy’s equipment and products remained at the location and that Amy still had possession of the site, but they needed the date of the last services performed. Sarena emphasized that financial information was required to determine the appropriate amount of compensation and urged Amy to contact the IRS or her tax preparer to obtain copies if she did not have the documents in her possession. The message concluded with Sarena’s signature and contact information for The Whaley Law Firm (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: 502-357-9971; O: 502-583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com with a note about the email address change).

Earlier still, also on August 24, 2022, at 10:11 AM, Amy asked, “What exactly does that report mean?”

On August 19, 2022 at 1:49 PM, Amy stated that she would have to repay a debt because she was unable to stay open, and she referenced a bank representative who indicated that an electric bill paid would count toward PPP loan forgiveness. She suggested that she might file bankruptcy due to the financial situation, noting that the bank’s calculations used the 2019 tax year and that she had secured additional PPP funds, though she doubted whether she would be medically able to heal in time to continue operating.

At 11:36 AM on August 19, 2022, Sarena replied that the defense is entitled to know whether Amy recovered lost wages during her recovery, and if so, from whom. Since Amy had received a PPP loan to cover lost wages, Sarena understood that the defense would not be responsible for those lost wages and that subrogation—reimbursement of the funds provided by Hometown Bank—was likely. She said she would forward Amy’s email to Aaron for further address, and she attached a copy of the FCE Report received on August 16, 2022, apologizing for its tardy delivery.

At 11:08 AM on August 19, 2022, Amy expressed frustration, agreeing that the PPP loan information had been obtained but noting that she was no longer in business and would need to file bankruptcy, with the bank’s use of the 2019 tax year complicating matters. She mentioned obtaining additional PPP funds but doubted whether she could be medically healed in time to continue. She argued that the information should not have been entered into her case and that she still possessed an MRI report showing a current acute tear in her arm, though doctors were not aligned to provide treatment. She asserted that misdiagnosis at the initial ER treatment had prolonged pain and suffering and claimed medical malpractice. She described nearly four years of ongoing symptoms, days in bed, migraines so severe that she felt as though she were dying, and a lack of effective remedies beyond medication.

At 10:15 AM on August 19, 2022, Sarena advised that the FCE Report had been received and had been forwarded to the defense for review. She noted that the bank’s PPP loans were under review and that she would reach out to Aaron for a more detailed update.

Finally, at 10:10 AM on August 19, 2022, Amy sent a request for an update on the progress.

Throughout the thread, Amy’s signature blocks include repeated quotations of a Benjamin Franklin line—“The heart of a fool is in his mouth, but the mouth of a wise man is in his heart”—appearing multiple times in her messages.

In sum, the communications document ongoing concerns about the FCE’s interpretation of her ability to work, the implications for potential compensation, the status and financing of her past business (Bella Beauty), and the interplay between medical conditions (including chronic migraines and an acute arm tear) and potential legal or malpractice considerations, alongside PPP loan matters and tax documentation requirements. The firm’s communications also reference an economist evaluation, the possibility of subrogation for loan funds, and the need for updated medical and financial records to determine appropriate compensation.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019
Client: Amy Mills

In a sequence of communications during August 2022, Amy Mills and The Whaley Law Firm, led by Sarena M. Tuttle, exchanged updates about her case. The thread begins with several messages from Amy Mills in mid-August and continues through August 25, with discussions centered on tax documents, the status of her business, medical issues, and the recent Functional Capacity Evaluation (FCE) and PPP loan matter.

On August 19, 2022, Amy Mills sent a message noting concerns about bankruptcy related to her inability to keep her business open, and she referenced information from a bank indicating that the electric bill paid would count toward PPP forgiveness. She also indicated she had obtained additional PPP funding but was unsure whether she would medically be able to continue. She expressed that she did not believe this information should be entered into her case, and she stated that she had not received an updated FCE or findings. She mentioned an MRI report indicating a current acute tear in her arm and difficulties in getting doctors to agree on treatment. She asserted ongoing issues for nearly four years, including days when she cannot get out of bed and migraines, with only medications and no remedy. She claimed to have a lingering impact from a head injury, memory difficulties, and the inability to obtain appropriate medical treatment; she criticized the lack of alignment among doctors and described the situation as ongoing pain and suffering.

Earlier on August 19, 2022, at 10:15 AM, Sarena Tuttle had replied that the firm had received the FCE Report and that Aaron had forwarded it to the defense for review. She also stated that documents from Hometown Bank regarding Mills’s PPP loans were under review and that she would obtain more detail from Aaron. She added that Mills’s case team would update her as more information became available and provided contact details for herself and the firm.

Also on August 19, 2022, at 11:08 AM, Mills responded with frustration about the PPP information and the status of her business. She reiterated that she was no longer in business and that the PPP loans were based on the 2019 tax year; she had been able to obtain additional PPP funds but was uncertain whether she would recover sufficiently to continue operating. Mills contended that the PPP information should not be entered into her case, and she criticized the lack of an updated FCE or findings. She emphasized that an MRI report showed a current acute tear in her arm and urged that medical malpractice be considered due to alleged misdiagnosis in the emergency department, which she believed prolonged pain and suffering. She argued that the ongoing situation had persisted for nearly four years, with days when she could not get out of bed and migraines, and stated that she was receiving only medications without effective treatment.

On August 19, 2022, at 10:15 AM, Sarena Tuttle responded that the firm had received the FCE Report and that Aaron had forwarded it to the defense for their review. She noted that they had also received documents from Hometown Bank concerning Mills’s PPP loans, which were under review, and that she would seek further details from Aaron. She indicated that she would provide a more detailed update once available.

By August 24, 2022, at 10:11 AM, Amy Mills asked directly, “What exactly does that report mean?” about the FCE. She was seeking clarification on the implications of the report’s findings.

Later that same day, at 12:20 PM, Sarena Tuttle explained to Mills that the FCE report indicated she was able to perform sedentary work—defined as low-level physical work involving mostly sitting, with occasional walking or standing and no lifting over 10 pounds. The message clarified that, while Mills had work limitations, she could perform non-physical duties, such as a desk job or managing her business with employees performing services. The note also stated that Aaron had arranged an evaluation with an economist to determine the financial impact of these restrictions, and that once the economist’s input was received, they would provide a detailed update. It was also noted that the team was still awaiting Mills’s tax documents from 2016 and 2017, as well as the official date Bella Beauty closed its doors. The firm understood that Mills still possessed the equipment and products at her location and that the date of the last services performed was needed to complete the file. Tuttle emphasized that the financial information was required to determine the appropriate amount of compensation Mills should receive and urged Mills to obtain copies of any missing tax documents from the IRS or her tax preparer if they were not in her possession. The firm provided contact information for Sarena M. Tuttle, including the new email address, and the firm’s Louisville, Kentucky address and phone numbers.

Also on August 24, 2022, at 12:20 PM, Mills replied seeking further clarification about the report’s meaning, indicating a need for understanding of its implications for her case.

On August 25, 2022, at 2:29 PM, Mills sent a further update in which she reiterated that she had given all tax documents to the law office and speculated that they might have been lost in the basement, given prior case manager remarks about the previous manager not being thorough and her own willingness to locate the documents. She reaffirmed that the last date of relevant events was 2019, but she refused to provide a precise date and time because she could not be certain, stating she would not misrepresent or lie. She explained that she had been hurt and pursued the process hoping to recover, but she could not physically work, noting that she had built a business through hard work and would have continued if she could. She asserted that she had given her best effort on the associated test and that she had told the truth to the best of her memory. She claimed to depend on others for everything and argued that those others should be scrutinized for failing to act on their responsibilities, linking this to the way she was treated by her bank after the injury.

Also on August 25, 2022, the thread references a prior message from Mills in which she described the physical consequences and inaccuracies she perceived in medical reporting. She indicated that she had been bedridden for two days after a certain appointment, that the doctor had misidentified her dominant hand (she is left-hand dominant, not right-handed), and that her pain at the time of leaving the appointment was an 8 out of 10, a detail she did not see reflected in the report. She stated she could hardly stand or sit before leaving and that chronic migraines had not been accounted for. She described being barely able to leave her home, unable to run her business (which she characterized as a teaching institute with no one else qualified to operate it), and claimed the business was bankrupt. She questioned how she could work when she could barely write her name and mentioned memory problems, distortions from a head injury, and the need for someone to drive her to appointments. She emphasized her educational achievements, including a master's degree, and her longstanding effort to build a life that had been taken from her, noting that others asked her to perform a desk job without considering her migraines and general impact on life.

The communications also include the firm’s standard contact details for Sarena M. Tuttle at The Whaley Law Firm, including a Louisville, KY address, direct line, office line, and a new email address, to facilitate ongoing updates and inquiries. The thread also references Bella Beauty, Mills’s business, and the need to establish the date when its doors officially closed, as well as the status of Mills’s tax documents from 2016 and 2017.

In summary, the August 2022 correspondence focused on the implications of the FCE report (which indicated the ability to perform sedentary work), the status and availability of tax documents (2016 and 2017) and the date Bella Beauty closed, the handling and review of PPP loan information, and Mills’s ongoing medical concerns, including migraines, arm injury, head injury, and related treatment challenges. Throughout, Mills conveyed concern about accuracy in medical documentation, the impact of her injuries on her ability to work, and the financial and legal ramifications of the case.

episodes.natural_language:
This note summarizes an internal case communication about Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank. The file is labeled Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019, and the client is Amy Mills. The correspondence involves Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm in Louisville and Betsy R. Catron of WHT Law in Lexington, with Saraena Tuttle and a file-link email for Amy Mills cc’d, and the subject line references the Amy Mills matter against Forcht Bank.

The August 22, 2022 exchange lays out a detailed set of discovery and damages-related tasks. Betsy Catron wrote to Aaron Whaley in the morning, explaining that they had requested records and bills from Mills’s Norton providers because she reportedly underwent an MRI at the end of May. She reported that none of those Norton providers had any records for recent treatment and that they were awaiting records from Baptist Health Corbin, promising to provide copies upon receipt. Betsy also asked Aaron to advise if there was any other recent medical treatment of Mills. She inquired about a late July Functional Capacity Evaluation (FCE) and inquired about when they would be able to obtain a demand, noting their goal of having a demand at least two months before mediation and suggesting a possible December mediation if a demand could be produced by October 7. Betsy also requested Mills’s tax returns for 2016, 2018, and 2020, explaining that the lack of this information significantly limits their ability to evaluate Mills’s future earning impairment claim. Additionally, she asked for the last day Bella Beauty was in business. The email concluded with Betsy’s signature block, listing her title as Attorney and providing the Vine Center address at 333 West Vine Street, Suite 1100, Lexington, KY 40507, along with phone and fax numbers and the website.

Aaron’s reply that same day, August 22, 2022 at 12:30 PM, stated that he would forward any records they might be missing. He noted that Mills had completed the FCE and that he had attached a copy of it. He added that he was in the process of an economic analysis. The message was copied to Sarena Tuttle and included a file-link email address associated with Amy Mills Premise, and Aaron’s own signature block followed, including his Louisville address and contact details, as well as a caution line about external email attachments. A final line in Aaron’s signature appears garbled, reading “-- Aaron Whttps://www.google.com/maps/search/333uisville, KY 40222” along with the standard external-email caution.

A month later, on September 21, 2022, Betsy sent another inquiry to Aaron: she asked when he would be able to provide a demand, noting that she would like it at least two months out from mediation and proposing that if a demand could be ready by October 7, they could set a December mediation, asking for his thoughts.

Aaron replied later that same day, September 21, 2022 at 10:03:40 AM, stating, “I am only waiting on economic report. Fingers crossed.” This indicated that the economic report was the outstanding item delaying a formal demand. The email chain shows the ongoing planning for mediation and the prerequisites (records, FCE, tax documents, and the economic analysis) being coordinated between the two firms, with the implicit goal of moving toward mediation in December pending the completion of the economic report and other documents.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank (Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019). Client: Amy Mills.

In the matter of Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank, communications between counsel progressed through late summer and fall of 2022. On August 22, 2022, Betsy Catron of WHT Law emailed Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm with several requests and updates. She reported that they had requested records and bills from Ms. Mills’s Norton providers, noting that Ms. Mills was understood to have undergone an MRI at the end of May; however, none of those Norton providers had records of recent treatment. They were still waiting on Ms. Mills’s records and bills from Baptist Health Corbin and would provide copies once received. Betsy asked for guidance on any other recent medical treatment Mrs. Mills might have had. She also inquired about a previously advised Functional Capacity Evaluation (FCE) that was to occur in late July and asked when a demand might be provided. Betsy further noted that they had requested tax returns for 2016, 2018, and 2020 several times, explaining that the absence of these documents significantly limited their ability to evaluate Ms. Mills’s potential earning impairment claim. She also asked for the last day Bella Beauty was in business and requested any information about additional recent medical treatment. Betsy concluded by inviting Aaron to contact her if there were questions or if she wished to discuss the matters further. The message was sent from Betsy to Aaron, and it did not include the lengthy signature block she later added in other messages.

Later that same day, August 22, 2022 at 12:30 PM, Aaron Whaley responded, stating that he would forward any records they might be missing. He noted that Amy Mills had completed the FCE and attached a copy of it to his reply. He also said he was in the process of conducting an economic analysis.

A little over a month later, on September 21, 2022, Betsy followed up again. In a message dated 9:19 AM, she asked when a demand could be expected, explaining their preference for the demand to be issued at least two months before mediation. She proposed that if a demand could be provided by October 7, they could schedule a December mediation, and she asked for Aaron’s thoughts on this timeline.

Aaron replied later that same day, September 21, 2022, at 10:04 AM, indicating that he was “only waiting on economic report” and that he was hopeful about the timeline (“Fingers crossed”).

On October 11, 2022, Betsy sent another follow-up, asking if Aaron knew when they could expect to receive a demand, expressing thanks in advance. That same day, Aaron responded at 11:55:59 AM, stating that he was waiting on the final report from the economist and that once that was complete, he would be able to prepare the demand, adding that it should be soon.

Throughout these exchanges, the correspondence circulated among Betsy Catron (Attorney at WHT Law), Aaron Whaley (Whaley Law Firm), and copies were distributed to the Amy Mills file (AmyMillsPremiseZ995806@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com) and Sarena Tuttle. The sequence reflects ongoing coordination around the timing of the demand and the status of medical and economic analyses in the Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank case.
episodes.author: Aaron Whaley

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy Mills — Premise, 04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills.

In January 2023, communications regarding Amy Mills continued between her and her attorney, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm. On January 13, 2023, Whaley forwarded an appointment-update email to Amy Mills Premise. The forwarded message included Amy’s reply, in which she reported that she had attended an orthopedic appointment the day before. The orthopedic specialist is scheduling six weeks of physical therapy, and if there is no improvement after that, another surgery may be required. Amy stated that she is in “terrible constant pain” and that she is in tears. She noted a scar tissue buildup, which she attributed to prolonged treatment, and she explained that the scar tissue results from both the severity of injuries to her head and neck and from the initial ER visit, where the ER report listed a muscle “strain,” but the tests performed that day showed injuries. She added a brief update on her current situation.

Earlier in the thread, on January 10, 2023, Amy wrote to Aaron describing her condition in more detail. She said she had been down for about 15 days in the last month and a week due to migraines, requiring JP to help her almost all the time. She commented on issues tied to her marital status and being a single mother. She stated that her medical records document migraines described as “suicide migraines” resulting from a traumatic brain injury (TBI); with the head injury, the migraines are worse. She mentioned discussing her situation off the record with someone who handles disability cases and who indicated she would qualify for disability, asserting that the doctor and economist’ assessments were not given full consideration. She noted concerns about a nurse’s report from a visit, pointing out that the nurse is not a doctor, and that if necessary they could pursue a nurse’s report rather than a physician’s. She referenced that the nurse from the ER visit had told her she was fine, while her own report described she was vomiting and unable to have a conversation, resulting in a loss of days she could not account for. She contended that there had been malpractice in prolonging treatment because the ER report said she was fine, yet scans and radiology results showed injuries that should have informed the diagnosis. Her primary physician has stated multiple times that the ER visit contributed to prolonged treatment and complications, and Amy stated that she is “stuck with this for the rest of my life” and that it “should have never happened.” She claimed to have video showing a situation where it was raining and something was done again, noting there were no rugs or signs. She described the situation as clearly negligent “100 percent,” and mentioned “Bobby,” described as a lady from a band, who had told her that she and multiple others had fallen there and that those involved knew it was an issue. Amy stated that the incident could have been avoided and concluded with the assertion that it was criminal.

On January 9, 2023, Aaron Whaley replied: “Ok, thanks for letting me know. I will add that to your file. Let me know how it goes. Have you put any more thought into the demand?” Earlier that same day, at 3:14 PM, Amy Mills replied that she had an orthopedic appointment scheduled for Thursday in Lexington and signed off with a quote from Benjamin Franklin: “The heart of a fool is in his mouth, but the mouth of a wise man is in his heart.”

The thread closes with Amy Mills’ contact details and her sign-off, which repeats the Franklin quote in her signature. The overall record documents ongoing medical concerns following head and neck injuries, ongoing pain and migraines, disability considerations, and disputes over medical treatment, ER reporting, and potential negligence.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills.

On January 13, 2023, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm emailed Amy Mills with a Re: Appt update. He asked, “What Ortho did you see? I have sent your records to a medical reviewer to see what the best case from a medical standpoint we can make to say your migraines are the result of the fall. I should have that review back in the next two weeks.”

Amy Mills replied later that day, describing the orthopedic appointment she had attended the previous day. She said she went to the orthopedic specialist and had been in severe pain all day, to the point of tears. The doctor reportedly scheduled six weeks of physical therapy, and if there was no change, another surgery would be required. She described terrible, constant pain that was not getting better and noted that the doctor said she had scar tissue buildup from prolonged treatment. She attributed the scar tissue to two factors: the severity of injuries to her head and neck, and her initial ER visit, where the report labeled the injury as a muscle “strain” even though the ER tests performed that day showed injuries.

Earlier messages from Amy Mills provide additional context. On January 10, 2023 at 11:17 AM, she wrote at length about her condition. She had experienced approximately 15 days of migraines in the previous month and a week, during which she was largely unable to do anything. She mentioned that JP had to help her almost all the time. She described disputes about marital status affecting support, noting difficulties related to being a single mom as well. She referred to migraines she labeled as “suicide migraines” that stemmed from a traumatic brain injury (TBI); with the head injury, the migraines were especially disruptive, preventing her from working or engaging in other activities, as her head injury exerted control over every aspect of her life. She stated she had discussed her situation with someone off the record who evaluates disability cases and who had expressed that she would actually qualify for disability. She claimed that the assessments by a doctor and an economist had not been taken into account in her favor. She criticized the nurse report discussed in their talks, arguing that the nurse was not a doctor and suggesting they could rely on a nurse’s findings if necessary. She asserted that the nurse from that ER visit was the same ER nurse who had reported she was fine, while her own report described different symptoms. She described vomiting and an inability to have a conversation, noting that she had lost a lot of time—days—that she did not remember. She described medical malpractice for prolonging treatment because the ER report had said she was fine, while the scans and radiology reports on which a diagnosis should have been based showed injuries. Her primary physician allegedly stated multiple times that the ER visit had caused prolonged treatment and complications, and she warned that she was “stuck with this for the rest of [her] life.” She contended that the event should never have happened, and she claimed to have video showing it had occurred again during rain, with no rugs or signs. She stated that this was clearly negligent, “100 percent.” She added that “Bobby the lady from the band” stated that she, she and multiple people had fallen there; they knew it was an issue and that it could have been completely avoided. She concluded with the assertion that this was criminal.

Also on January 9, 2023, at 3:42 PM, Aaron Whaley replied to Amy, saying, “Ok, thanks for letting me know. I will add that to your file. Let me know how it goes. Have you put any more thought into the demand?”

Earlier that same day, at 3:14 PM, Amy Mills wrote that she had an orthopedic appointment scheduled for Thursday in Lexington. She included the line, “The heart of a fool is in his mouth, but the mouth of a wise man is in his heart.” attributed to Benjamin Franklin, followed by contact details for Whaley Law Firm.

The correspondence concludes with the signatures of Aaron Whaley, Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, and Amy Mills, including the Franklin quote.

__Fwd: Appt update__
From: Aaron Whaley [agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com)
To: [AmyMillsPremiseZ995806@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com](mailto:AmyMillsPremiseZ995806@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com) Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019
Date: Fri, 10 Feb 2023 16:46:19 -0500

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Amy Mills 
Date: Fri, Jan 13, 2023 at 4:10 PM
Subject: Re: Appt update
To: Aaron Whaley 

I also put down that you have access to the medical records when I filled
out paperwork.
Well I had to gather the paperwork for this appt and looked at the March
appt my blood work showed a hight white blood cell count and that usually
means it’s fighting infection - I asked JP abt it and he said the best he
could remember it was a bad sinus infection and that I get them every
spring (I don’t remember bc I don’t remember a whole lot)
Buy I’m pretty sure it is impossible to be knocked out cold (have a knot in
my hair on the left side of my head, which has a sensitive bone like knot
on it still to this day) and have bladder incontinent’s, vomiting, lose
space and time for days without memory, wake up unable to move, clothes are
wet from the water in the floor, and injuries sustained that I have and NOT
have blunt force trauma to the head. (It just doesn’t add up)
Also the way the foyer is set up it’s a small space with a bench in there.
I talked to Jp about the ER visit and he said the only thing that was in

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills.

In February 2023, an appointment-update thread related to Amy Mills Premise was communications between Amy Mills and attorney Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm. On February 10, 2023, Whaley forwarded the “Fwd: Appt update” message to Amy Mills Premise, attaching prior correspondence that began earlier in January 2023.

In Amy Mills’s message dated January 13, 2023 at 4:10 PM, she told Aaron Whaley that she had indicated in paperwork that he would have access to her medical records. She explained that she had gathered the paperwork for the appointment and reviewed the records from her March appointment. The blood work from that appointment showed a high white blood cell count, which usually signals an infection. She asked her doctor, JP, about this, and he recalled that it was a bad sinus infection and that she tends to get them every spring. She added that she does not remember a great deal, and she questioned the sequence of events surrounding a fall. She asserted that it seems impossible to have been knocked out cold—she described a knot in the left side of her head that remains sensitive, along with bruising she associates with blunt force trauma—that she could have bladder incontinence, vomiting, loss of space and time for days without memory, waking up unable to move, and wearing clothes that were wet from water on the floor, all without blunt head trauma. She noted that the foyer where the incident occurred is a small space with a bench. She said she spoke with JP about the ER visit and that the only thing in question was whether she hit her head on the floor or on the bench, and if she hit her head on the bench, whether she also hit her neck on the bench. She emphasized that she is not sure about these details “1,000 percent” because, as she said, it knocked her out or rendered her unconscious.

Earlier, on January 13, 2023 at 3:49 PM, Aaron Whaley replied, asking what orthopedist Amy had seen. He also stated that he had sent her records to a medical reviewer to determine the best case from a medical standpoint to argue that her migraines are the result of the fall, and he expected to have that review back within about two weeks.

In another thread from January 13, 2023 at 3:41 PM, Amy Mills recounted that she had gone to an orthopedic appointment the previous day and was in significant pain, to the point of tears. The orthopedic doctor was scheduling six weeks of physical therapy and warned that if there were no improvement, another surgery might be required. She described ongoing severe pain and noted that the doctor said scar tissue had built up as a result of prolonged treatment. She attributed the scar tissue to the severity of head and neck injuries and to the initial ER visit, during which the report characterized the injuries as a muscle “strain,” even though the ER tests indicated injuries.

On January 10, 2023 at 11:17 AM, Amy Mills wrote again, describing that she had been down for about 15 days with migraines, to the point of being unable to do anything, with JP’s help almost constantly. She expressed frustration that she felt treated as though she were not a married person despite being a single mom. She stated that her medical records document what is labeled as “suicide migraines” linked to the traumatic brain injury (TBI), and that with the head injury the migraines are even worse. She had discussed with someone off the record about disability cases; that person had approved and denied disability cases and believed she would actually qualify as disabled, though the doctor and economist assessments had not been fully considered with respect to her head injury. She discussed concerns about a nurse’s report from a visit that suggested relying on a nurse instead of a physician, and noted that the nurse’s report came from the ER visit where she was told she was fine, which conflicted with her own report. She described vomiting, an inability to have a conversation, and significant memory gaps (“lost a lot of space and time”). She criticized what she called the malpractice of prolonged treatment, claiming the physician’s report said she was fine while the scans and radiology did indicate injuries that should have informed a diagnosis. She stated that her primary physician had repeatedly said that delaying treatment had caused prolonged treatment and complications, leaving her with lifelong issues. She asserted that this should never have happened and that she had video evidence of rain during the incident, no rugs, no signs, making the situation clearly negligent—“100 percent.” She mentioned that a woman named Bobby from a band had testified that many people had fallen there and that those involved knew there was an issue and that this could have been avoided, calling it criminal.

On January 9, 2023 at 3:42 PM, Aaron Whaley replied that he would add Amy’s information to her file and asked how the demand was progressing. He invited her to share any further thoughts about the demand.

Earlier on January 9, 2023 at 3:14 PM, Amy Mills wrote that she had an orthopedic appointment scheduled for Thursday in Lexington.

The exchange closed with signatures that repeated the familiar phrases: “The heart of a fool is in his mouth, but the mouth of a wise man is in his heart.” — Benjamin Franklin. The thread also included standard contact information for Aaron Whaley and the Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, with the phone number 502-583-4022. The closing lines also reprinted Amy Mills’s name and the Franklin quote in a loop.

This matter is the case titled Amy-Mills-Premise, filed on April 26, 2019, with client Amy Mills.

Counsel has received a District Court motion to set aside the trial scheduling order. The client has received and continues to receive the plaintiff’s certified medical records and would like additional time to review those records and to consult with experts. Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills.

In an update dated February 28, 2023 at 2:20 PM, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm sent a note to Amy Mills, Sarena Tuttle, and the Amy Mills Premise file. He stated that certified records have been requested from all of Amy’s providers. He asked Sarena to confirm that a request has been placed for the physical therapy (PT) that Amy is currently attending. He also indicated that once all the certified records are collected, he intends to send them to an expert on brain injuries to obtain their opinion.

Earlier that same day, at 2:16 PM, Amy Mills replied. She wrote: “Hey Aaron I went to my specialist appointment on Thursday and you are listed on my release of information documents. I’m continuing physical therapy and that’s about all I know at this point besides the Orthopedic specialist in Lexington stating that I had a lot of scar tissue Damage. Thanks Amy Mills” The message was signed with Amy Mills’ name and included her email signature, which quotes: “The heart of a fool is in his mouth, but the mouth of a wise man is in his heart.” — Benjamin Franklin.

The thread concluded with Aaron Whaley’s closing, identifying him as with the Whaley Law Firm located at 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, and listing the firm’s phone number as 502-583-4022. The correspondence reflects the case history and ongoing plan to obtain certified medical records for review, with the intention of consulting a brain-injury expert once those records are gathered.

The record begins with an email thread concerning Amy Mills’s personal injury claim and a new request for information. On April 28, 2023, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with contact numbers D: (502) 357-9971 and O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104 and email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (noting the new address), sent Amy Mills a message following receipt of a request from the Defense Attorney for Forcht Bank. The message asked Amy to review the attached document and provide information related to her applications for employment or participation in a practicum or internship program as a counselor or Counselor Associate, and invited her to contact them with any questions.

On April 29, 2023, Amy Mills replied. She stated that the request concerns her transcripts, which show coursework and grades, and a copy of the diploma received as a result of completing these requirements. She asked whether this documentation was substantial enough for the defense’s needs.

The following day, April 30? or April 29? The timeline shows April 29 as the day of Amy’s message; on May 1, 2023, Sarena responded again. In her May 1 message, Sarena explained that Amy’s response referenced classes, grades, and diplomas, but the defense’s request is for employment verification information—specifically, places where Amy has applied, worked, or volunteered using the new skills referenced in the request.

Finally, on May 3, 2023, Amy Mills sent a reply clarifying her understanding and next steps. She wrote that she is unsure what “new skills” refers to. She indicated she would gather what she can for the request as soon as possible, but noted that her belongings are in storage and she would need help due to physical limitations. She acknowledged that the course-required internship curriculum, as part of the requirements to obtain the diplomas, is among the requested items. She also asked for clarification on the time frame for the requested documents (e.g., 5, 10, or 15 years) and signed her name, “Amy Mills.”

Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills.

Between April 28 and May 3, 2023, a series of emails concerning a new request for information in Amy Mills’s personal injury claim were exchanged. The correspondence was initiated by Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm, acting as a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager, and circulated to Amy Mills and several recipients related to the case.

On April 28, 2023, at 10:41 AM, Sarena Tuttle sent an email to Amy Mills and others noting that the defense attorney for Forcht Bank had attached a request. She asked Amy to review that document and provide any information related to Amy’s applications for employment or participation in a practicum or internship program as a counselor or Counselor Associate. If Amy could not provide documentation, Sarena asked for a list of any places where Amy had provided services, with dates and any compensation received.

The following day, April 29, 2023, at approximately 1:30 PM, Amy Mills replied. She stated that the defense has her transcripts showing the coursework and grades completed at college, along with a copy of the diploma received upon completing those requirements. She asked whether this documentation might be substantial enough to satisfy the request.

On May 1, 2023, at 9:30 AM, Sarena Tuttle responded to Amy’s message. She clarified that the request was for employment verification information—specifically, places where Amy had applied, worked, or volunteered using the newly acquired skills. She emphasized that the request was not limited to classes, grades, or diplomas.

Amy Mills sent another reply on May 3, 2023, at about 9:17 AM. She expressed uncertainty about the meaning of the term “new skills.” She said she would assemble what she could, but noted that items were in storage and that her physical capabilities would make gathering materials difficult. She reiterated that the requested items included the course-required curriculum for internship per the course requirements needed to obtain the diploma, and she asked about the time frame for the requested documents (whether it covered 5, 10, or 15 years).

Later on May 3, 2023, at 10:20 AM, Sarena Tuttle sent a final clarification. She stated that there is no time frame. She asked Amy to provide any and all documents related to any and all employment (including internships and volunteer work) under the fields of substance abuse, behavioral health, or mental health counseling. She advised that, even if documentation is not available, Amy should provide a list of every place where she provided services, with dates and the amount of any compensation, if applicable. The email included Sarena’s contact information and noted a new email address for correspondence.

Signature details for Sarena M. Tuttle appeared at the end of the May 3, 2023 message, identifying her roles as Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager with The Whaley Law Firm, along with the firm’s address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222), direct line (502-357-9971), office line (502-583-4022 ext 104), and the email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, accompanied by a note to “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”

Case: Amy Mills – Premise 04-26-2019. This narrative records the communications concerning Amy Mills’ personal injury claim and a new information request issued in May 2023 by The Whaley Law Firm, specifically by Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, to Amy Mills. The message thread begins with an email dated May 3, 2023 at 11:50 a.m. from Sarena Tuttle to Amy Mills (and to the broader distribution list including Celia’s former contacts). In that note, Sarena explains she is confused because Amy had said she would attach information, but the only attachments were two screenshots of emails with Celia. Sarena notes that Celia is no longer with the firm and she is not privy to any conversations Amy had with Celia, so she will only accept documents as they are needed and cannot find where the information was saved in Amy’s file. Sarena points out that in Amy’s deposition, Amy stated she had training and education in substance abuse, behavioral, and/or mental health counseling, which is what the “new skills” reference means — that the new skills are counselor work rather than beautician/cosmetologist work. Sarena asks Amy to send the requested information as soon as possible, acknowledging it may take a day or two to gather everything. She instructs Amy to begin with a list or resume of any counseling-related work she has done, including dates and the method and amount of compensation. She clarifies that educational materials are not needed; what is required is information about who Amy has worked for, volunteered for, or completed internships with. The message ends with Sarena’s contact details and a note to “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”

The email thread continues with a reply from Amy Mills dated May 3, 2023 at 11:29 a.m. in which she expresses remaining confusion about what “new skills” refers to. She explains difficulties in assembling documents because items have been requested multiple times and some materials have been lost or misplaced during changes in who is handling the file. Amy states she found an email she intends to attach that contains daily notes of her work at the Trillium Center, an inpatient and outpatient facility for adolescents and adults, including details about her supervisor, the supervisor’s CV/resume, copies of licensure, scheduled sessions, and activities, among other information related to the requests and prior merit discussions. She notes that whenever she finds documents that may or may not be needed, she has forwarded them to the law office because of memory issues related to a traumatic brain injury/nerve damage from injuries in this case. She emphasizes that she is reviewing saved and sent emails to gather the required information and acknowledges that this material corresponds to one month of what had been required for two years of her master’s curriculum. She indicates she will forward this exact email separately as an attachment and closes with thanks and her name, Amy Mills.

Earlier on the same day, at 10:20 a.m., Sarena Tuttle had written to Amy with a more directive request: there is no defined time frame, and Amy should provide any and all documents related to any and all employment (including internships and volunteering) under the category of substance abuse, behavioral, or mental health counseling. If documentation does not exist, Amy should provide a list of all places where she provided services, with dates and any compensation details. Sarena provides her standard contact information and reiterates the lack of a time frame.

Earlier still, at 9:17 a.m. on May 3, 2023, Amy Mills replied that she did not understand what “new skills” meant. She said she would assemble what she could as soon as possible, though items are in storage and gathering them is hindered by physical limitations. She noted that the course’s required internship curriculum to obtain the diploma was among the items requested and asked about the time frame (e.g., 5, 10, 15 years) for the documents.

On May 1, 2023 at 9:30 a.m., Sarena responded that there is no time frame and reiterated that the request is for employment verification information. She asked Amy to identify places where she has applied, worked, or volunteered using the new skills, and to provide details even if documentation is not available.

The thread also includes prior correspondence from April 28 and April 29, 2023. On April 28, Sarena informed Amy that the office had received a request from the Defense Attorney for Forcht Bank and asked Amy to review the document and provide information related to her applications for employment or participation in a practicum or internship program as a counselor or Counselor Associate, inviting any questions. On April 29, 2023 at 1:30 p.m., Amy stated that the transcripts already show the course work and grades, and a copy of the diploma, and asked whether that documentation is insufficient.

Amy had previously written on April 29, 2023 at 1:30 p.m. that the transcripts from college prove she completed the coursework with grades and that a diploma was received as a result of completing these requirements, and she questioned whether this material was substantial enough.

The correspondence overall centers on obtaining documentation of Amy Mills’ counseling-related employment or practice experiences, including internships and volunteer work, tied to her related skills claimed in the deposition, in support of her personal injury claim. The communications reflect the firm’s need to obtain employment verification or equivalent documentation—past, present, and, if applicable, within the past several years—about where Amy worked, volunteered, or interned in substance abuse, behavioral, or mental health counseling, the absence or presence of compensation, and dates of service. The dialogue also reveals Amy’s difficulties with document retrieval and storage, her use of prior emails as sources of information due to memory concerns arising from a traumatic brain injury, and her ongoing effort to forward relevant materials to the law office.

Signature blocks in the messages identify Sarena M. Tuttle as the sender of the Whaley Law Firm communications, with the firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone numbers D: (502) 357-9971 and O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; and email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com. The correspondence also notes a “Please note new email address” reference in Sarena’s signature. The email chain includes references to Celia (a former firm member) and indicates that Celia’s conversations are not accessible to Sarena. The May 3, 2023 date line is shown in the header of the initial note (11:50 a.m.) as well as subsequent replies within the same day, and earlier messages span from April 28 to April 29, 2023.

Case: Amy Mills – Premise 04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills. This narrative summarizes the email thread regarding a new request for information tied to Amy Mills’s personal injury claim, with communications between Amy Mills and Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm dated April 28, 2023 through May 3, 2023.

On April 28, 2023 at 10:41 AM, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, wrote to Amy Mills. She noted that the defense attorney for Forcht Bank had attached a new request and asked Amy to review the document and provide information related to her applications for employment or participation in a practicum or internship program as a counselor or Counselor Associate. She also requested that, if documentation was unavailable, Amy provide a list of places where she provided services, with dates and any compensation, if applicable. Sarena’s signature included the firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with direct and office phone numbers and her new email address.

The following day, April 29, 2023 at 1:30 PM, Amy Mills responded. She stated that the documents include transcripts showing course work and grades, and mentioned having a copy of something accessible via a link that appears to reference completing the requirements (the text includes a garbled portion: “copy of thttps://www.google.com/maps/search/712pleating these requirements”). She asked whether this material was substantial enough to satisfy the request.

On May 1, 2023 at 9:30 AM, Sarena replied again, explaining that the request is for employment verification information—specifically, places where Amy has applied, worked, or volunteered using the new skills. She instructed Amy to provide information about employment or practicum/internship involvement in counseling, including any places where such work occurred, and to include dates and any compensation.

On May 3, 2023 at 9:17 AM, Amy sent another message. She indicated she did not understand what “new skills” referred to and that she would assemble what she could as soon as possible, noting that items are in storage and she would need assistance due to physical limitations. She added that the requested items include the course-required internship curriculum in order to obtain diplomas and asked what time frame was required for the documents (e.g., 5, 10, or 15 years).

Later on May 3, 2023 at 10:20 AM, Sarena replied that there was no specified time frame. She reiterated the need for any and all documents related to employment, internships, or volunteer work under the realms of substance abuse, behavioral, or mental health counseling. She requested that, even in the absence of documentation, Amy provide a list of all places where she provided services, with dates and any compensation.

That same day, May 3, 2023 at 11:28 AM, Amy responded with thanks and further context. She stated she was still unclear about what “new skills” referred to. She described going through emails to gather documentation and noted a separate issue: documentation requested multiple times had been lost or misplaced during transfers. She reported finding an email documenting daily notes of work at the Trillium Center, described as an inpatient and outpatient facility for adolescents and adults. She noted the presence of her supervisor, her supervisor’s CV/Resume, copies of licensure, scheduled sessions and activities, and other information related to this request and past discussions of merit. Amy explained that whenever she encountered documents that may be relevant, she forwarded them to the law office, due to memory difficulties stemming from a traumatic brain injury and nerve damage, depending on the doctor’s assessment. She emphasized that she is attempting to assemble saved and sent emails to gather the requested information and pointed out that one month of the work documented in this material also related to two years of her master’s curriculum, tying back to her initial email indicating the content had already been sent previously. She said she would forward this exact email separately as an attachment and closed with thanks. Her message included the line “(See attachment).”

In sum, the thread shows a back-and-forth in which the firm requested comprehensive employment-related documentation tied to counseling and related services, while Amy sought to clarify the scope and time frame, explained challenges with access to stored documents and memory, and attempted to gather and forward relevant materials, including materials from her experience at the Trillium Center and items related to her master’s curriculum. The emails include multiple signatures, with Sarena M. Tuttle’s contact details at The Whaley Law Firm (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: 502-357-9971; O: 502-583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, noted as the new email address).

episodes.natural_language:
This narrative summarizes a May 3, 2023 email exchange in the personal injury matter for Amy Mills, client of the case labeled Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019.

The thread began with an email from Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, dated Wednesday, May 3, 2023 at 1:06 PM EDT. The message was sent from sarena@whaleylawfirm.com to Amy Mills at bellabeautyinstitute@gmail.com, with copies to agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com (Aaron Whaley) and to Amy Mills Premise file address AmyMillsPremiseZ995806@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com, as well as to Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019. In the body of the email, Sarena apologized for the frustration and stated that all she needed at that time was a list of Amy’s jobs that fall under the counseling/social worker umbrella, whether internships or paid employment. She noted that she had reviewed the file and Aaron had reviewed the emails to Celia, and she requested simply a list of any and all jobs in that umbrella.

Later that day, at 12:44 PM (times indicated as approximate in the thread), Amy Mills replied with considerable frustration. She said she had sent everything she had multiple times and that emails she had sent were forwarded to the firm’s current case manager, but she questioned whether the documentation had been forwarded at all due to multiple changes in case managers. She asked for clarification on whether the information would be accepted and filed in her file for present or possible future use. Amy suggested that the confusion likely originated from the mixing of roles—cosmetologist/beautician, social worker, and certified counselor/therapist—along with training and education, or all of the above. She asserted that the email screenshots she had sent served as proof of time/date stamps, even before any deposit, and that she was attempting to locate saved emails to re-forward the information. She explained she had no control over how her information was stored or transferred within the law firm but emphasized her transparency and willingness to provide any and all information. She also referenced prior discussions with Aaron about discovery/disclosure and stated that she sent everything because she did not know what might be important or pertinent to the case, arguing that without sending everything, Aaron could not be fully aware of what to request. Amy gave an example of a confusing point in the prior correspondence: a statement that “we do not need educational material,” which, in her view, contradicted the internship material she believed to be relevant. She speculated about what practical and clinical applications were required in her educational studies to obtain degrees and certifications on file and acknowledged that gathering the requested information would take time. She closed by hoping the message clarified things.

A follow-up reply from Sarena was sent on the same day at 11:51 AM. She expressed that she was a bit confused and noted that Amy had said she was attaching information, but the only attachments were two screenshots of emails with Celia. Sarena explained that Celia was no longer with the firm and that she was not privy to the contents or context of any conversations Amy had with Celia. She stated she would only accept requested documents as they were needed and did not see where the information had been saved in Amy’s file. Sarena reminded Amy that in Amy’s deposition she had stated receiving training, education, etc., in substance abuse, behavioral and/or mental health counseling, and that “new skills” referred to Amy’s skills as a counselor rather than as a beautician/cosmetologist. She requested that Amy send the requested information as soon as possible and suggested starting with a list/resume of any counseling-related work, including dates and the method or amount of compensation. Sarena emphasized that educational material was not needed and reiterated the need to know who Amy had worked for, volunteered for, or completed internships with. The message carried Sarena’s signature with contact details for The Whaley Law Firm.

At 11:29 AM on May 3, Amy Mills replied again. She indicated she was not sure what “new skills” meant and described the process of combing through emails to save electronic documentation, noting that documentation was being requested multiple times and had been lost or misplaced during staff transitions. She mentioned a specific email containing daily notes of work at the Trillium Center, an inpatient and outpatient facility for adolescents and adults, which included her supervisor, the supervisor’s CV/resume, copies of licensure, scheduled sessions and activities, and other information relevant to the requests and discussions of merit. Amy stated that whenever she found documents that might be needed—even if they might not be—they had been forwarded to the law office due to her difficulty recalling details caused by a traumatic brain injury and nerve damage related to injuries in the case. She explained that the materials she found represented one month of a two-year master’s curriculum and again stated her intention to forward the exact email in attachments. She closed by thanking the recipient.

Earlier in the day, at 10:20 AM, Sarena replied again to Amy, reiterating that there was no defined time frame and instructing Amy to provide any and all documents related to employment (internships, volunteering, etc.) under the domains of substance abuse, behavioral or mental health counseling. She also advised that even if Amy did not have documentation, she should provide a list of all places where services were provided, with dates and any compensation, if applicable, and again reminded Amy to use the format of a list rather than educational material.

At 9:17 AM, Amy Mills had replied to the chain asking for clarification about what “new skills” referred to. She stated she would gather the necessary information as soon as possible, noting that the requested materials were in storage and that she would need assistance due to physical limitations. She explained that the requested items included the course-required curriculum of internships necessary to obtain diplomas and asked about the time frame for the documents (for example, whether 5, 10, or 15 years' worth of materials were being sought). The thread ends with a truncated line from a May 1, 2023 message, reading “On Mon, May 1, 2023 at 9:,” indicating an earlier correspondence before the May 3 exchanges.

Throughout this exchange, the communications repeatedly reference the underlying case management context at The Whaley Law Firm, the evolving list of case managers (including changes in who handles Amy’s file), and the ongoing effort to obtain a precise, comprehensive timeline of Amy Mills’s related counseling and related work experience—whether paid, volunteer, or internship—under the broad umbrella of counseling and mental health services, while navigating questions about what constitutes “educational material” versus practical work experience. The thread also highlights Amy’s perception of administrative fragmentation (switching case managers and incomplete forwarding of documents) and her efforts to supply documentation tied to her training, licensure, and practical work at relevant facilities, including the Trillium Center, in the face of health-related limitations.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills. Re: Your Personal Injury Claim - New Request for Information. From: Amy Mills to Sarena Tuttle. Date: May 3, 2023, 12:44:32 PM Eastern Time.

Chronology of the email exchange:

On April 29, 2023 at 1:30 PM, Amy Mills emailed to address the new information request related to her personal injury claim. She stated that the law firm already has her transcripts showing coursework and the diploma, and she referenced the materials tied to the request, noting that her transcripts and course work are on file with the college. She indicated that the requested items include documentation from a two-year master’s curriculum and the related diploma, and she suggested that the documentation had already been provided but that it was now being requested again.

On May 1, 2023 at 9:30 AM, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, replied that there is no “time frame” for the request and that the firm is seeking employment verification information related to the “new skills” referenced in Amy’s deposition. She explained that the firm needs information about places where Amy has applied, worked, or volunteered using those new skills, rather than educational materials, and she asked Amy to provide a list or resume of any counseling-related work with dates and compensation details, if any. She reiterated the firm’s contact details and noted that Celia, who previously handled the matter, is no longer with the firm and that Sarena was not privy to any prior conversations with Celia.

On May 3, 2023 at 9:17 AM, Amy Mills replied that she was still unclear about what “new skills” referred to. She said she would gather what she could, acknowledging that items are in storage and that her physical capabilities create a need for assistance. She indicated that the requested items include the course-required internship curriculum necessary to obtain her diplomas and asked what time frame was requested for these documents.

On May 3, 2023 at 10:20 AM, Sarena responded, clarifying again that there is no fixed time frame and restating the scope of the request: Amy should provide any and all documents related to employment (including internships, volunteering) under the areas of substance abuse, behavioral health, or mental health counseling. If documentation is not available, Amy should provide a list of places where she provided services, with dates and any compensation.

On May 3, 2023 at 11:29 AM, Amy Mills replied with further details. She thanked Sarena for the reply and admitted continued confusion about the meaning of “new skills.” Amy explained that while she searches through accessible emails to gather documents, she found an email containing daily notes from her work at the Trillium Center (an inpatient and outpatient facility for adolescents and adults), including her supervisor, her supervisor’s CV/resume, copies of licensure, scheduled sessions and activities, and other information relevant to prior discussions of merit. She stated that she has forwarded any documents she could locate because she cannot always recall everything, especially given a traumatic brain injury and nerve damage resulting from the injuries in her case. Amy noted that this effort reflects only one month of what the master’s program required over two years and that she would forward this exact email as an attachment separately. She emphasized her intention to continue gathering and forwarding pertinent documents as requested.

On May 3, 2023 at 11:51 AM, Sarena responded with some confusion and clarification: Amy had stated she was attaching information, but the only attachments were two screenshots of emails with Celia. Sarena reminded that Celia is no longer with the firm and she is not privy to those conversations. She reiterated that she would only accept requested documents as needed and did not see any of this information saved to Amy’s file. Sarena then referenced Amy’s deposition, noting that Amy had testified to receiving training, education, etc., in substance abuse, behavioral and/or mental health counseling, which is what “new skills” referred to. Sarena clarified that Amy’s counseling work, not beautician/cosmetologist work, is the focus. She urged Amy to send the requested information as soon as possible, starting with a list or resume of any counseling-related work she had performed, including dates and the method or amount of compensation. Sarena again stated that educational materials were not required, and she repeated that they needed to know who Amy had worked for, volunteered for, and with whom she completed internships. She closed with the law firm’s contact information and noted the new email address for Sarena.

Finally, on May 3, 2023 at 12:44 PM, Amy Mills sent a closing communication continuing her frustration and detailing several procedural concerns. She stated that she had sent everything multiple times and that the emails she sent were forwarded to the firm’s case manager at (@wlf) because the case had changed case managers several times, yet the documentation had not been forwarded. She asked for confirmation of whether her understanding was correct. Amy described the situation as extremely difficult given the amount of time that has passed and the circumstances directly related to the case. She argued that emails requesting documentation should be filed in her file for present or future use and suggested that the confusion around the mix of roles—cosmetologist/beautician, social worker, and certified counselor/therapist—along with training and education, likely contributed to the misfiling. Amy referenced the email screen shots as proof that she had sent the information repeatedly, noting time/date stamps already captured in those screen shots even before the deposit occurred. She indicated she was attempting to locate any saved documents to re-forward and reiterated that she has little control over how her information is stored or transferred within the law firm. She stated continued transparency about all information. Amy noted that she had previously discussed discovery/disclosure with Aaron, explaining that she sends everything because she does not know what might be important or requested; failing to do so would leave him unaware of what to request. She provided an example: a perceived contradiction in a prior email claiming “we do not need educational material,” while internship material appeared to be exactly that. She speculated on possible reasons for the confusion—what practical and clinical applications were required in her education to obtain degrees and certifications—admitting it would take time to gather the necessary items. She concluded by hoping her clarification helps.

These exchanges collectively document Amy Mills’s attempt to provide information for her personal injury claim, the firm’s attempts to constrain the scope of the requested information to counseling-related employment (as opposed to general educational materials), and Amy’s ongoing effort to reconcile different interpretations of what constitutes “new skills” and what documents are required, along with ongoing concerns about record-keeping, case-management changes, and the accessibility of her materials.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy Mills, Premise - 04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills. Re: Your Personal Injury Claim – New Request for Information.

On May 3, 2023, The Whaley Law Firm sent a new information request to Amy Mills regarding her personal injury claim. The message came from Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. Her direct lines were D: (502) 357-9971 and O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104, and her email was Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, noted as a new address. The email also copied Aaron Whaley and a case-specific email alias for Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019, and stated the recipient addresses included bellabeautyinstitute@gmail.com and Amy Mills.

The content began with an acknowledgment of thanks and an apology for prior frustration and confusion. The firm signaled that the request was a continuation of their efforts to obtain information pertinent to Amy Mills’ personal injury claim.

Earlier in the day, Amy Mills replied that she would compile a list of items and then allow Sarena to review them, indicating she would determine if anything needed modification or addition before proceeding.

Prior to that, at 10:20 a.m., Sarena had written that there was no fixed time frame and explicitly requested documentation relating to any and all employment under the counseling, behavioral health, or mental health counseling umbrella—whether internships or paid positions. She advised Amy to provide documentation for any and all places where she provided services, with dates and compensation details if any, and to supply a list if documentation was not available.

At 11:29 a.m., Amy asked for clarification about the term “new skills,” expressing uncertainty about what that phrase referred to in the context of the request.

Shortly afterward, at 11:51 a.m., Sarena responded with some confusion of her own, noting that Amy had said she would attach information, but only two screenshots of emails with someone named Celia had been received. Sarena explained that Celia was no longer with the firm and that the team would only accept documents as needed; she referenced Amy’s deposition, which indicated training and education in substance abuse, behavioral, and/or mental health counseling, clarifying that “new skills” referred to Amy’s counseling work rather than cosmetology. Sarena urged Amy to send the requested information promptly, starting with a resume or list of counseling-related work, including dates and compensation, and stated that they did not need educational material but did need information on employers, volunteer work, and internships.

At 12:44 p.m., Amy again expressed frustration, stating she had sent everything multiple times and that her documentation had been forwarded to a different part of the firm due to multiple changes in case managers, but the documentation had not followed along. She described ongoing difficulty with the case filing and what seemed to be a mix-up among roles (cosmetologist/beautician, social worker, and certified counselor/therapist) and training/education. Amy asserted she was attempting to locate saved emails with documents to re-forward and noted she had limited control over how her information was stored or transferred within the firm. She emphasized that she had been transparent and forthcoming and referenced discussions about discovery and disclosure, explaining that she was sending everything because she did not know what would be deemed important or pertinent to the case. Amy suggested the “new skills” issue might relate to the practical and clinical applications required in her educational programs, and she indicated gathering time would be needed to compile relevant material, including internship material, which could be time-consuming.

At 1:06 p.m., Sarena reaffirmed the request, explaining that there was no stated time frame and reiterating the need for any and all documents related to employment in counseling/behavioral or mental health counseling, including internships and positions. She advised that if documentation was unavailable, Amy should still provide a list of places where she provided services, with dates and compensation details if applicable.

Around 2:35 p.m., Amy responded that she would compile a list and send something for review, and that Sarena could indicate whether any items needed to be changed or added, with the understanding that they could proceed from there.

Finally, at 3:11 p.m., Sarena closed the thread with a courteous note: “Awesome, thank you so much. Again, I apologize for the frustration and confusion.” The message included Sarena’s full signature, reiterating her role and contact information, and noting the new email address.

Throughout the thread, Amy’s inbox referenced a note about daily logs from her time at the Trillium Center (an inpatient and outpatient facility for adolescents and adults), including a supervisor, supervisor’s CV/resume, licensure copies, scheduled sessions, and related activities—items she described as pertaining to past discussions of merit. Amy attributed her difficulty in gathering and forwarding documents to the TBI/nerve damage resulting from injuries in her case and to the firm’s changing personnel, which she felt had led to lost or misfiled documentation. She also highlighted a broader issue that the information she sent before had been directed to the wrong place or person within the firm’s file system, leading to several misunderstandings about what material was being requested and what was considered “new skills.”

This exchange illustrates an ongoing process to collect employment-related documentation tied to Amy Mills’ counseling and mental health-related work for purposes related to her personal injury claim, including internships and volunteer work, with an emphasis on concrete details (employers, supervisors, dates, and compensation) rather than solely on educational materials. The firm remained focused on obtaining a comprehensive list and supporting documentation, while Amy continued to navigate internal firm changes and the effects of a traumatic brain injury on her ability to recall and assemble the requested records.
