episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy Mills – Premise Incident Case Note dated 04-26-2019
Client: Amy Mills

On May 3, 2023, Amy Mills, the client in a personal injury claim, initiated contact with Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm regarding a new information request. In her first note, sent in the afternoon, Amy said she would compile a list of items, send them for review, and then ask whether anything needed to be changed or added before proceeding.

Earlier that same day, at about 1:06 p.m., Sarena responded with a focused request. She asked Amy to provide a comprehensive list of all jobs that fall under the counseling or social worker umbrella, including internships and paid positions. Sarena explained that both she and Aaron had reviewed the file and related emails, and she asked that Amy simply send a complete list of all counseling/social work roles she had held, regardless of whether they were volunteer, internship, or paid work. Sarena provided her contact details for The Whaley Law Firm and noted Amy’s new email address.

Earlier still, at roughly 12:44 p.m., Amy replied with visible frustration. She explained that she had already sent the requested information multiple times and that emails had been forwarded to the firm’s current case manager (the case had been reassigned several times within the firm). Amy expressed confusion over what would be accepted as responsive documentation and asserted that there had been mixups between descriptors such as cosmetologist/beautician, social worker, and certified counselor/therapist, including training and education. She claimed to have sent information before the deposit and to have screenshots documenting time and dates as proof. She also noted she was trying to locate other saved emails with documents to re-forward, and she described her lack of control over how information was stored or transferred within the firm. Amy emphasized her transparency and her practice of sending everything to ensure that the team could identify what might be important for discovery or disclosure, including concerns about what material might matter for the case.

Earlier in the day, at about 11:29 a.m., Amy had written to say she would send what she could, noting the ongoing confusion about what constitutes “new skills” and asking to gather documentation from storage. She mentioned an email containing daily notes from work at the Trillium Center, an inpatient and outpatient facility for adolescents and adults, including her supervisor, her supervisor’s CV/Resume, copies of licensure, scheduled sessions, and activities relevant to the request. She described having forwarded any potentially relevant documents to the law office in case they were needed later, citing her traumatic brain injury (TBI) and nerve damage as factors affecting her memory and recall. She indicated she would forward the exact email separately with attachments and thanked the recipient.

At about 11:51 a.m., Sarena replied with some confusion of her own. She noted that the only attachments present were two screenshots of Amy’s emails with a person named Celia. Sarena stated that Celia was no longer with the firm and that she was not privy to the contents or context of conversations with Celia. She explained that she would only accept documents as they were needed and reiterated that the firm might not have those materials saved in Amy’s file. Sarena referenced Amy’s deposition, stating that Amy had testified to receiving training and education in substance abuse, behavioral and/or mental health counseling, and clarified that “new skills” referred to these counseling-related capabilities rather than cosmetology. She urged Amy to send the requested information promptly and suggested starting with a list or resume of any counseling-related work, including dates and compensation, noting that educational material was not required, only information about employers, volunteering, and internships.

Earlier still, at around 10:20 a.m., Amy had written to say there was no defined time frame for the requested information. She asked for any and all documents related to employment—internships, volunteering, etc.—in the area of substance abuse, behavioral or mental health counseling. If documentation was lacking, she asked for a list of every place she had provided services, with dates and any compensation, if applicable.

Finally, at about 9:17 a.m., Amy had sent a morning note indicating that she did not fully understand what “new skills” referred to and that she would assemble what she could as soon as possible, noting that her materials were in storage.

In sum, the day’s exchanges tracing May 3, 2023, show Amy Mills attempting to respond to a formal information request concerning her counseling-related work history, education, internships, and related qualifications, while contending with repeated case-management changes, document-control issues within the firm, and ongoing uncertainties about exactly which materials would be deemed responsive or necessary for discovery and disclosure in her personal injury claim. The Whaley Law Firm’s responses emphasized the need for a clear list of counseling-related employment (including internships and volunteer work) with dates and any compensation, and they clarified that educational materials were not required. The communications also noted administrative changes within the firm (including the departure of a person named Celia) and attempted to align Amy’s documentation with the firm’s information-gathering process. Contact details referenced include The Whaley Law Firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and the firm’s phone and email channels for Sarena M. Tuttle, the Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager.

I wanted to email you to let you know a little snippet of things I deal
with on the daily that never is discussed and I feel gets over looked
The attachment is what took me hours to do from concentration, ability to
sit/stand rotation, ability to type, my ability to see/read without the
words becoming blurry and separating on the page. After which my child
needed me to write a school excuse where he was out sick and to sign a
permission slip - AND I COULDN’T EVEN DO THAT! I had to get someone else to
write it and sign my name bc I couldn’t even hold the pen (bc I’m left
handed) from complete numbness, sharp electric Zapps, muscle spasms, just
from doing this one task that I attached that took hours/all afternoon!
The frustration comes from these types of unspoken struggles that should
not be happening! And yes all this is from this accident! And at first
glance when looking at me you wouldn’t think anything but unless you are
with me every second of the day I can’t get anyone to understand and I try
to hide it because I’m so sick of people simply asking 24/7 - “are you
okay?”
Or hot always have multiple doctors looking at the exact same scans
(without my report or input! Just scans and test results) and all give a
different and sometimes conflicting report of diagnosis! How is someone
suppose to get the correct treatment if non of the doctors and specialists
can agree on the same pictures!
4 years of this and everything that comes from cause and effect…. I wish it
had never ever happened!!!! It is beyond frustrating
Thank you for viewing this I just wanted to let you know as a way of maybe
letting you see some insight. Something that shouldn’t be a big deal to
do/type and it was such an ordeal that causes mental stress, physical
stress, and pressure on me and my family! Yes, this is absolutely INSANE
but my reality I continue to work with everyday.
I feel I needed to send you this as clarification I suppose even though
it’s hard to even talk about and acknowledge out loud.
(I will send the completed document, I’m going to have someone to help me
put this together as soon as possible)
Thank you,
Amy Mills

episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact in this matter occurred on May 4, 2023, when Amy Mills sent an email to Sarena M. Tuttle regarding her personal injury claim (case reference: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019). In the message, sent from Amy Mills’s bellabeautyinstitute@gmail.com, she described a daily reality she feels is often overlooked: the attachment she included had taken her hours to complete because of concentration difficulties, trouble with sit/stand rotation, difficulty typing, and the ability to see and read without the words becoming blurry and separating on the page. She explained that after finishing the attachment, her child needed help with a school excuse for being out sick and a permission slip to sign, and she could not do it. Because she is left-handed and could not hold a pen due to complete numbness, sharp electric zaps, and muscle spasms, she had to enlist someone else to write and sign her name. She stressed that this one task took hours and that the frustration stems from these unspoken struggles that should not be happening, all tied to the accident four years prior. She emphasized that at a casual glance she might appear fine, but unless someone is with her every moment, others cannot understand, and she often tries to hide it because she is tired of being asked if she is okay. She also expressed frustration with medical reports: multiple doctors reviewing the same scans and tests without her input, producing different and sometimes conflicting diagnoses, making it difficult to obtain the correct treatment. She characterized the past four years as a continuous cycle of cause and effect, stating it is “beyond frustrating” and “INSANE” in her reality as she works through these issues daily. She thanked Sarena for viewing the note and described it as a form of clarification and insight into something that should not be difficult to perform, yet is for her due to the condition from the accident. She indicated that she would send the completed document as soon as possible, with help from someone who would assist her in putting it together. The message concluded with her thanks and her name, Amy Mills.

In the same thread, the overarching email correspondence shows that Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm acknowledged the message the next day, May 3, 2023, commenting, “Awesome, thank you so much. Again, I apologize for the frustration and confusion.” Sarena’s signature identified her as a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, with the firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and listed direct and office lines, along with her new email address, Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com.

Earlier on May 3, 2023, there was a sequence of back-and-forth communications. At approximately 11:29 AM, Amy Mills indicated that she planned to list items and send them for review, asking for feedback on any needed changes and noting that the case had changed case managers multiple times within the firm, but documentation had not been forwarded. She referenced that the documentation was initially sent to the firm and suggested there had been confusion over where information was stored within the firm, and she mentioned forwardings to the firm’s current team as the case evolved. She also described confusion arising from the mix of roles—cosmetologist/beautician, social worker, and certified counselor/therapist (training and education), and that these lists might be relevant to her case.

Sarena responded at 11:51 AM, expressing some confusion and clarifying that Celia—the person with whom Amy had previously corresponded—was no longer with the firm, and that she would only accept the requested documents as needed. She asked for a straightforward list of any and all counseling/social-work-related work Amy had engaged in, whether as an internship or paid employment, and she reiterated contact information for the firm.

At 12:44 PM, Amy wrote again to express frustration, noting that she had already sent everything multiple times and that emails had been forwarded within the Whaley firm due to changes in case personnel. She explained that there appeared to be a mix-up between cosmetologist/beautician and social worker or certified counselor/therapist roles, as well as training and education records. She provided context about having shared screenshots as proof of time/date stamps before a deposit, and said she would search saved emails to re-forward the information. Amy also mentioned that she did not control how her information was stored or transferred within the firm, but she had remained transparent and forthcoming about all materials. She referenced discussions with Aaron about discovery and disclosure and explained that she sent everything because she did not know what would be important or pertinent to the case, and she believed that not sharing could prevent others from knowing what to request. She gave an example of a point of confusion: the firm had stated that educational material was not needed, yet internship materials appeared to be exactly that. She reiterated that gathering the information would take time and that she would continue to work on it, adding that the circumstances during the intervening period had been challenging.

Later on May 3, 2023, Sarena replied at 1:06 PM with a clearer directive: she again apologized for the frustration and stated that what was needed at that moment was a list of Amy’s counseling/social-work-related jobs, including internships and paid positions, with dates and details on any compensation. She reminded Amy that she and Aaron had reviewed the file and emails to Celia, and again stressed that the requested documentation was what was needed, not educational material. She included the firm’s contact details in her signature.

Amy’s response at 2:35 PM confirmed her intention to compile the list and send it for review, indicating she would allow Sarena to review the draft and request changes if necessary, and she expressed appreciation for proceeding from there.

Finally, at 3:11 PM on May 3, Sarena wrote a concluding note to Amy, acknowledging that while Amy had said she would attach information, the only items attached were two screenshots of Amy’s emails with Celia. Sarena reiterated that Celia was no longer with the firm and that she was not privy to those conversations. She emphasized that the firm would only accept requested documents as needed and questioned where such information was stored in Amy’s file. She reminded Amy that in her deposition she had described training and education in substance abuse, behavioral and/or mental health counseling, which was the basis for the “new skills” reference. Sarena clarified that Amy’s counseling skills, not her cosmetology background, were relevant to the case. She urged Amy to provide the requested information promptly, noting that it might take a day or two to gather everything, and she asked Amy to start with a resume or list of counseling-related work, including the employers, volunteers, internships, dates, and compensation details, explicitly stating that educational material was not required. The message concluded with Sarena’s signature and updated contact information.

In summary, the case involves Amy Mills seeking information and clarification related to her personal injury claim arising from the 2019 incident, a request for documentation about her counseling- and social-work–related employment, internships, and training, and an ongoing exchange with The Whaley Law Firm to resolve inconsistencies in file handling, roles, and the specific materials required for discovery. Amy’s May 4 email adds a personal account of the daily functional impairments she experiences due to the accident, the impact on her ability to perform ordinary tasks, and her intent to provide a more complete document with assistance as soon as possible.

wish you did not have to go through this and understand that not all
conditions are evident on the outside. I understand that you are human and
are suffering from so much more than just a physical injury. This was a
life changing event that will have a lasting effect not only physically but
also mentally, emotionally, financially & spiritually. We are not trying to
make this more difficult than it has to be, if we were able to get this
information any other way we would. We understand that completing task can
have varying difficulties and try to give you as much time to complete them
as the court will allow. We know that you would like to get this matter
resolved and be able to move forward without all these reminders of what
happened. Unfortunately, in order to resolve the matter and make sure we
are able to get you everything we can, we have to ask for information.
Currently, the Defense is asking for this employment history and we can not
move forward until we receive it, however, we understand that it may take
you a couple of days to gather the information. As I explained, let's
breakdown the information requested and start with just a list of places
where you provided counseling/social work services. From there we can be
more assistive with gathering the more detailed information the Defense is
wanting. We are here to help you and are willing to do anything to help a
long the way.

Sarena M. Tuttle
Litigation Paralegal &
Workers' Compensation Case Manager

Louisville, KY 40222

O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104

episodes.natural_language:
This note documents the communications surrounding Amy Mills’ personal injury claim and a new Information Request from The Whaley Law Firm, dated early May 2023, with the case reference Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019.

On May 4, 2023 at 10:53 a.m. (the email from Sarena Tuttle, the Whaley Law Firm’s Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, sent to Amy Mills and to the firm’s additional recipients), Sarena opened with a cordial greeting to Amy and noted that nothing was attached to the prior message. She acknowledged that not all conditions are visible on the outside and expressed empathy for what Amy was enduring—physically and mentally, emotionally, financially, and spiritually—describing the incident as a life-changing event with lasting impact. Sarena stated they were not trying to create additional difficulty; if there were another way to obtain the information they would pursue it. She explained that while they understand tasks may present challenges and that they would grant as much time as the court allows, they needed to obtain information to resolve the matter. Specifically, the Defense was requesting Amy’s employment history, and the team could not move forward without it, though they understood it might take a couple of days for Amy to gather the information. Sarena proposed breaking down the request: begin with a simple list of places where Amy provided counseling or social work services, and then, later, gather more detailed information the Defense was seeking. She reiterated their willingness to help and support Amy through the process. The message closed with Sarena’s contact details and a note that this was her new email address.

Earlier, Amy Mills had sent a reply on May 4, 2023 at 9:07 a.m. describing the daily challenges she faces, which she said are often overlooked. She explained that the attachment she had prepared took hours to complete due to concentration problems, difficulty with sitting and standing, issues with typing, and blurred or separating words when reading. She shared that her child needed a school excuse and a permission slip signed, and she could not even hold a pen because of numbness, sharp electric “zapps,” and muscle spasms—extending to the extent of needing someone else to write and sign for her. She described these struggles as an ordeal that affected not only herself but also her family, noting that the fatigue and pain were a direct result of the accident. Amy stated that at first glance people might not notice anything, but if someone was with her every second, they would understand. She expressed frustration with inconsistent reports from doctors who reviewed the same scans without her accompanying notes, leading to conflicting diagnoses and questioning how to obtain the correct treatment. She reflected on four years of ongoing issues and their impact on every dimension of her life, wishing the accident had never happened. She thanked Sarena for taking the time to view what she had attached as a way to provide insight into her daily reality. Amy indicated she would send the completed document and would have someone assist her in putting it together as soon as possible. She closed with thanks and her name, Amy Mills.

The thread then moves to earlier correspondence on May 3, 2023. At 3:11 p.m., Sarena replied to Amy, thanking her and apologizing for any frustration and confusion. She signed as before, including her role and contact information.

At 2:35 p.m. on May 3, Amy Mills responded, agreeing to list the requested items and to send something for Sarena to review. She said she would await Sarena’s guidance on whether to change, add, or modify the information, and expressed appreciation to proceed from that point.

At 1:06 p.m. on May 3, Sarena had written that Amy should provide a list of all jobs that fell under the counseling/social worker umbrella, whether internship or paid employment. She indicated that she had reviewed the file and that Aaron Whaley had reviewed emails to Cecilia, and she again requested a simple list of all such positions.

At 12:44 p.m. on May 3, Amy Mills wrote in frustration that she had sent everything multiple times and that emails had been forwarded to Whaley Law Firm staff as her case had seen multiple case managers, but documentation had not been forwarded. She questioned whether she was understanding correctly. She stated that it was a very difficult task after the time that had passed and the circumstances related to the case. Amy discussed what would be accepted versus rejected and suggested this contributed to confusion about how her information—cosmetologist/beautician, social worker, certified counselor/therapist, training and education, or a combination of these—was being categorized. She mentioned sending screenshots as proof of time/date stamps for the information even before a deposit took place and noted that she was attempting to locate saved emails with documents to re-forward. She asserted she had no control over how her information was stored, transferred, or otherwise handled within the law firm, yet reiterated her transparency and willingness to provide any information requested. She recalled having discussed discovery and disclosure with Aaron and emphasized that she sent everything because she did not know what might be important or pertinent to her case, and she questioned how Aaron could be fully aware of what he needed to request if she did not provide all materials. She cited a confusing point from the prior email: the statement that “we do not need educational material,” but the sentence cuts off with “the inte,” indicating that the message ended mid-thought.

Note: The May 3, 2023, 12:44 p.m. email ends abruptly with the words “the inte,” and the remainder of that thought is not included in the record. The record, as provided, preserves all other content and timing from the thread.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy Mills — Premise 04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills.

In the email thread titled “Re: Your Personal Injury Claim - New Request for Information,” the communications relate to Amy Mills’s personal injury claim and a new request for information from the defense. On June 1, 2023, at 4:56 p.m. Eastern Time, Amy Mills sent a message to Sarena Tuttle. In that note, she explained that she had been dealing with numerous issues, including difficulty locating her materials in storage. She also stated that she had just undergone an unexpected root canal procedure. She said she would send whatever documentation she could within the next 24 hours and expressed a hope that nothing had been left out, emphasizing that she did not want to do anything wrong. She closed with a quick update and thanks, signing as Amy Mills.

Earlier in the thread, on May 4, 2023, at 10:54 a.m., Sarena Tuttle replied to Amy. Sarena explained that nothing was attached to the prior communication. She acknowledged that the circumstances were difficult and that the impact of the incident extended beyond the physical injury to include mental, emotional, financial, and spiritual effects. She emphasized that the goal was not to make things more difficult, and that if information could be obtained by other means they would pursue those options. She noted that the defense was currently requesting Amy’s employment history and that the matter could not move forward until that information was received, while recognizing that gathering it might take a few days. Sarena proposed breaking down the request to start with a list of places where Amy had provided counseling or social work services, with the intention of gradually gathering the more detailed information the defense sought. She reassured Amy that the firm was there to help and that they were willing to do whatever was needed to assist her. The message included Sarena’s contact details: Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal & Workers' Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct line 502-357-9971; office line 502-583-4022 ext. 104; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note to “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”

In that same day’s correspondence, at 9:07 a.m., Amy Mills wrote describing the daily challenges she faced. She detailed that she had spent hours on a document due to concentration difficulties, the need to manage sit/stand rotation, trouble typing, and visual disturbances that caused words to blur and separate on the page. She mentioned having to write a school excuse for her child and being unable to hold a pen because of numbness, sharp electric "zaps," and muscle spasms, all related to the accident. She described the frustration of encountering unspoken struggles that were not visible at a casual glance and the ongoing difficulty of obtaining consistent medical diagnoses from different doctors who often relied only on scans and test results without her input. She stated that she would send the completed document and that someone would help her put it together as soon as possible, noting that this had become a daily reality she continued to manage. She signed off with thanks and again stated her intention to send the completed document soon.

Earlier on May 3, 2023, at 3:11 p.m., Sarena replied to Amy with appreciation, saying, “Awesome, thank you so much,” and adding, “Again, I apologize for the frustration and confusion.” The signature block identified Sarena M. Tuttle as Litigation Paralegal and Workers' Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, with the same Louisville address and contact details as above.

Moments later, at 2:35 p.m. on May 3, Amy Mills said she would list the items and send them for review, inviting Sarena to advise if anything should be added or changed before proceeding.

At 1:06 p.m. on May 3, Sarena sent a direct request to Amy: she needed a list of Amy’s jobs that fell under the counseling/social worker umbrella, including any internships or paid employment. She confirmed that both she and another colleague, Aaron, had reviewed the file and communications to Cecilia, and asked Amy simply to provide a list of all roles under that umbrella.

Earlier still, at 12:44 p.m. on May 3, Amy Mills vented frustration about having sent all requested information multiple times. She explained that emails related to her case had been forwarded to The Whaley Law Firm (WLF) because her case had changed case managers several times, but the documentation had not been forwarded consistently. She questioned whether she was understood correctly. She expressed that compiling and submitting documentation was an extremely difficult task given the time that had passed and the circumstances affecting the case. She discussed potential confusion surrounding whether items would be accepted and suggested that emails containing documentation should be filed for present or future use. She speculated about mixups involving titles such as cosmetologist/beautician, social worker, and certified counselor/therapist, along with training and education, and indicated that she had attempted to provide screen shots as proof of time/date stamps, even before a deposit, to support the information. She stated she was seeking saved emails to re-forward the documentation and remarked that she had little control over how her information was stored or transferred within her case.

The chain ends with Amy’s partially complete note, cut off mid-sentence: “I have no control over how my information in stored, transferred, or otherwise for my case within.” 

In summary, the record shows Amy Mills communicating on June 1, 2023, to provide an update and promise to send available materials within 24 hours, following an earlier exchange in early May where the defense’s information requests prompted detailed, repeated attempts by Amy to supply employment and counseling/social work history, a substantial explanation of the personal and health-related difficulties she was experiencing, and ongoing coordination with Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm regarding how best to gather and organize the information.

Case: Amy Mills (Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019) involves client Amy Mills. The note comprises forwarded emails between Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, and Melissa Wilder of Aptiva Health, concerning scheduling and costs for an Independent Medical Examination (IME) with Dr. Manderino.

In the forward dated June 26, 2023 at 11:07:17 AM Eastern Time, Sarena forwarded Dr. Manderino’s cost information for review. She stated that there is a charge of $600 per hour for record review on top of the $2,500 exam costs, and she asked for guidance on which records the two law firm recipients would like to have sent in order to minimize costs. The message was signed by Sarena M. Tuttle, who is a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. Her direct line is (502) 357-9971 and the office line is (502) 583-4022 ext 104. She also noted her new email address as Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, and provided the email address as a point of contact. The firm’s file also indicates the forward is addressed to Aaron Whaley (agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com) and Bryce Koon (bryce@whaleylawfirm.com).

The forward also includes a previous message from Melissa Wilder. Dated Thursday, June 22, 2023 at about 1:54 PM, the message was addressed to Sarena@whaleylawfirm.com with the subject line “Amy Mills.” The content confirms that the firm had requested scheduling an IME for client Amy Mills with Dr. Manderino. It states that Dr. Manderino’s fee for an IME is $2,500, and there is also a surcharge billed at $600 per hour for the review of records exceeding 250 pages. The appointment is anticipated to take up to four hours. Dr. Manderino asked Melissa Wilder to send the attached disclaimer when scheduling IMEs, and she asked for an acknowledgment of receipt and to be informed whether the Whaley Law Firm would like to proceed.

The message from Melissa Wilder is signed as Administrative Specialist, with the following contact details: telephone number 859-592-1008, extension 2669; email mwilder@aptivahealth.com; website aptivahealth.com; and the mailing address 426 Codell Drive, Lexington, KY 40509. The signature also includes a standard confidentiality notice stating that the email and any attachments are intended only for the named addressees and may contain legally privileged or confidential information. It warns that dissemination, distribution, printing, or copying is strictly prohibited if the recipient is not the intended one, and instructs recipients who received the email in error to respond to the sender and permanently delete the original and any copies.

episodes.natural_language:
In the Amy Mills Premise case (case file: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019), the client is Amy Mills. The record reflects a sequence of late winter to summer 2023 communications between counsel concerning discovery, a discovery demand, and mediation scheduling.

Beginning in February 2023, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm indicated he did not object to Betsy Catron’s motion and expressed an interest in moving mediation forward, stating he would like to set mediation in April or May. On March 13, 2023, Betsy asked whether Aaron’s side could provide a demand by the end of the month; Aaron replied on March 14, 2023, that he “hop[e] so.”

On May 12, 2023, Betsy again inquired, asking, “When can I expect a demand from your client?” and she appears to have awaited a response. By June 16, 2023, Aaron responded, providing the demand and noting that he had added it to a Dropbox folder, with the message: “Betsy, here you go. Thank you for your patience. I have added the demand to a dropbox folder.” The link provided was https://www.dropbox.com/sh/0imoh5irinhb1bb/AACZwtaR1soOYXeuy9ox1F4ta?dl=0.

On June 27, 2023, Betsy wrote again, requesting responses to the discovery served on April 28, 2023, and asked whether the 30-day response period could be satisfied by responding at mediation. She also indicated she was coordinating a mediation with Judge Knopf and sought Aaron’s availability for late August or early September. Aaron replied on the same day, June 27, 2023, at 10:24:41 a.m. (-0400): “I will get the discovery to you asap. Yes I am agreeable to your response at mediation. My schedule is good late August early September.”
episodes.author: Aaron Whaley

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills.

This note is a forwarded email thread regarding the Amy Mills matter. The forward, labeled “__Fwd: Amy Mills__,” was sent on June 27, 2023 at 10:25:11 a.m. by Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm to the addresses Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019, Bryce Koon, and Sarena Tuttle. The subject line was simply “RE: Amy Mills.” The message begins with, “We need to respond to these requests,” and then includes a chain of prior communications tied to the case.

The forwarded portion contains a message from Betsy Catron dated June 27, 2023 at 10:21 a.m. Betsy, identified as an attorney with Vine Center in Lexington, KY, wrote to Aaron Whaley and Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019. She thanked Aaron and asked that responses be provided to the discovery served on April 28, 2023, noting that she had attached those discovery requests. She also observed that the demand in the file carries a 30-day response period and asked if the responding party could address the demand at mediation. Betsy stated she was having her assistant check for mediation dates with Judge Knopf and inquired about Aaron’s availability for late August or early September.

The email thread includes earlier correspondence. On June 16, 2023, Aaron replied to Betsy and to Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019, saying, “Betsy, here you go. Thank you for your patience. I have added the demand to a dropbox folder,” and provided the link: https://www.dropbox.com/sh/0imoh5irinhb1bb/AACZwtaR1soOYXeuy9ox1F4ta?dl=0.

Prior to that, Betsy had written on May 12, 2023, asking, “When can I expect a demand from your client?” Aaron’s response at that time is not quoted in full, but the thread includes Betsy’s signature with her contact information for Vine Center—333 West Vine Street, Suite 1100, Lexington, KY 40507, phone 859.422.6000, fax 859.422.6001, and the website www.whtlaw.com.

Earlier still, on March 14, 2023, Aaron replied to Betsy with the message, “I hope so.” Betsy had asked on March 13, 2023, whether Aaron could obtain a demand by the end of the month. The portion of the thread beginning February 13, 2023 shows Aaron writing, “I don’t object to your motion. I would like to get mediation set in April or May—,” followed by Aaron’s full signature block for Whaley Law Firm, including the office address at 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, and phone numbers. The emails repeatedly include standard external-email cautions in the signatures.

In summary, the file documents a back-and-forth from February through June 2023 regarding mediation timing and the production of a demand and discovery responses. By June 27, 2023, Betsy was requesting responses to discovery served on April 28, 2023, and to know whether the parties could handle the 30-day demand response at mediation, with plans to pursue mediation dates with Judge Knopf in late August or early September. The June 16, 2023 email confirms that the demand had been uploaded to a Dropbox folder for access.

Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm (located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207) sent an email titled “RE: Amy Mills” to the distribution list for Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019, including Aaron Whaley and Sarena Tuttle. The message, which carried the date Tue, Jun 27, 2023 at 10:27:36 AM (Eastern time zone offset -0400), stated, “I will work on them now.” The email also contained a standard confidentiality and privilege notice indicating that the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient and outlining steps to take if received in error, including contacting The Whaley Law Firm and not using or forwarding the information.

Earlier that same day, Aaron Whaley forwarded a message titled “Fwd: Amy Mills” to Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019, Bryce Koon, and Sarena Tuttle with the note, “We need to respond to these requests.” This forwarded message included a prior thread beginning with Betsy Catron’s reply.

In Betsy Catron’s June 27, 2023 email (dated 10:21 AM), she acknowledged Aaron’s message and requested responses to the discovery served on 4/28/23, noting that the discovery was attached. She also asked whether a 30-day response could be accommodated by providing responses at mediation, and she inquired about dates for mediation with Judge Knopf, asking for availability in late August or early September. Betsy signed with her attorney information for Vine Center at 333 West Vine Street, Suite 1100, Lexington, KY 40507, providing the firm’s phone number (859.422.6000) and fax (859.422.6001) and listing the website www.whtlaw.com. A standard caution about external emails was included in the thread.

The thread also showed prior communications from Aaron Whaley. On June 16, 2023, at 3:26 PM, Aaron informed Betsy that he had added the demand to a Dropbox folder and provided a link to the folder: https://www.dropbox.com/sh/0imoh5irinhb1bb/AACZwtaR1soOYXeuy9ox1F4ta?dl=0. This message followed Betsy’s earlier inquiries about the timing of the demand, including Betsy’s May 12, 2023 email asking, “When can I expect a demand from your client?” and Aaron’s March 14, 2023 reply, “I hope so,” in response to Betsy’s March 13, 2023 question: “Do you think you can get me a demand by the end of the month?” The preceding February 13, 2023 message from Aaron to Betsy indicated, “I don’t object to your motion. I would like to get mediation set in April or May,” followed by the signature blocks that included his contact information and a note about external email cautions.

In sum, the record documents ongoing discovery-related communications in the Amy Mills Premise case, including: a discovery response timeline being discussed (with a 30-day expectation), the plan to address those responses at mediation, the scheduling considerations with Judge Knopf for late summer or early fall, and the involvement of both Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019 and counsel from The Whaley Law Firm in coordinating these efforts. The exchange includes multiple attachments and references to a Dropbox link for the demand, and the thread repeatedly notes the cautionary boilerplate about external emails.

From: Bryce Koon [bryce@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:bryce@whaleylawfirm.com)

Date: Thu, 6 Jul 2023 10:20:21 -0400

Good morning Ms. Mills, 

 

 

Below are just a couple of questions from the defense that I do not easily have the answers to and were hoping you could help:

 

 

Names and addresses of each person or organization where you have worked or interned in the areas of Substance Abuse, Behavioral Disorder and Mental Health Counseling, worked as a LPCA (Licensed Professional Counselor Associate), or worked toward a LPC (Licensed Professional Counselor) designation. 

 

For each person and/or organization above, please state 

The dates of each such employment, practicum, or internship; The nature of the work or duties; The place or places where such work or duties were performed; The names and telephone numbers of any supervisors for each employment, practicum, or internship; andThe average weekly or monthly compensation from such employment, practicum, or internship.  

 

Please provide copies of any applications for any employment or internships above, the date of the applications, and the result of the application.  

 

Any other documents which relate in any way to the above question(s).  

 

 

 

Thank you!

 

W. Bryce Koon, Esq.The Whaley Law Firm 712 Lyndon Lane

Louisville, KY 40222Phone: (502) 365-5043Fax: (502) 237-3207

 

This electronic message is intended only for the named recipient. It may contain attorney-client privileged r otherwise protected information. If you have received this message or any attachment in error, you are instructed to contact The Whaley Law Firm and advise in this regard, no waiver of any privilege shall be applicable, and you are instructed that you should not use the information contained herein or forward it to any third person not intended to receive it.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy Mills – Premise 04-26-2019
Client: Amy Mills

In the Amy Mills matter, communications relating to discovery and mediation unfolded over several months in 2023. On July 21, 2023, Bryce Koon of Whaley Law Firm reported via email that he had sent Amy Mills the discovery questions but had been unable to reach her. He stated that he had called, texted, and emailed without receiving a response.

That same July 21 email included a forwarded message thread. Aaron Whaley’s initial entry in the thread, sent Friday, July 21, 2023 at 10:03 AM, was directed to Bryce Koon and Sarena Tuttle under the subject Fwd: Amy Mills, and it contained Betsy Catron’s inquiry about discovery responses. Betsy had previously sent on July 21, 2023 at 9:54 AM a message to Aaron Whaley asking, “Aaron, when can we expect responses to our discovery?” and noted that Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019 had a corresponding file alias at AmyMillsPremiseZ995806@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com.

The thread shows earlier exchanges between Betsy Catron and Aaron Whaley. In a June 27, 2023 email, Aaron replied at 10:25 AM that he would get the discovery to Betsy asap and that he was agreeable to receiving a response at mediation, with his schedule open for late August to early September. Betsy had previously asked, in a June 27, 2023 email at 10:21 AM, for the discovery responses served on 4/28/23, attaching those documents. She also asked whether the 30-day response requirement could be satisfied by responding at mediation and inquired about availability for a mediation with Judge Knopf in late August or early September.

The correspondence also includes a June 16, 2023 email from Aaron to Betsy Catron and Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019, in which Aaron said he had added the demand to a Dropbox folder and provided the link: https://www.dropbox.com/sh/0imoh5irinhb1bb/AACZwtaR1soOYXeuy9ox1F4ta?dl=0.

Earlier still, Betsy Catron had written on May 12, 2023, asking when a demand could be expected from Aaron’s client. Aaron’s response in this thread was not until June 16, 2023, when he provided the Dropbox link containing the demand.

The record also includes communications from February 13, 2023, with Aaron stating that he did not object to Betsy’s motion and that he would like to get mediation set in April or May, followed by repeated signatures for Aaron Whaley, whose firm is Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, with phone number 502-583-4022 (the signature blocks also include the firm’s standard contact details). The chain shows a March 13, 2023 exchange in which Betsy asked if a demand could be provided by the end of the month; Aaron replied on March 14, 2023, “I hope so.” Betsy had previously asked on March 13, 2023 (2:59 PM) “Do you think you can get me a demand by the end of the month?”

The emails include standard external email caution footers indicating caution when opening attachments and links from external senders. The material also shows repeated signature blocks for Betsy Catron, Attorney at Vine Center, with the address 333 West Vine Street, Suite 1100, Lexington, KY 40507, and contact details (P 859.422.6000; F 859.422.6001; www.whtlaw.com), and for Aaron Whaley at Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, with the same phone number.

In summary, the file records a sequence of discovery-related discussions and mediation planning spanning February through July 2023, culminating in July 21, 2023, when a Whaley Law Firm representative reported difficulty contacting Amy Mills and shared the prior discovery and discovery-related communications with the involved parties. The underlying file maintained the case reference Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019 and the alias AmyMillsPremiseZ995806@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com for the materials connected to the matter.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills.

In the matter titled Amy Mills, counsel communications show ongoing discovery and demand negotiations between Betsy R. Catron of Vine Center and Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm, with activity spanning from February through July 2023. The record begins with an exchange on February 13, 2023, when Aaron Whaley wrote to Betsy Catron that he did not object to her motion and that he would like to have mediation set in April or May.

On March 13, 2023, Betsy asked Aaron whether he thought he could get a demand by the end of the month. Aaron replied on March 14, 2023 with the brief, “I hope so.” The thread continued as Betsy followed up on May 12, 2023, asking, “When can I expect a demand from your client?” and stating that she had attached related materials.

Subsequently, on June 16, 2023, Aaron responded that he had added the demand to a Dropbox folder, providing a link to the folder for Betsy to access: https://www.dropbox.com/sh/0imoh5irinhb1bb/AACZwtaR1soOYXeuy9ox1F4ta?dl=0. The next day, June 27, 2023, at 10:21 AM Betsy wrote back, thanking Aaron and requesting (a) the discovery responses served on 4/28/23, noting that she had attached them, (b) clarification about the 30-day response period for the demand and whether the parties could allow a response at mediation, and (c) Aaron’s availability for mediation in late August or early September, as she was arranging a mediation with Judge Knopf.

Aaron replied at 10:25 AM on June 27, 2023, agreeing to provide the discovery responses promptly, confirming that he was agreeable to a mediation-based response, and reiterating that his schedule was suitable for late August to early September.

On July 21, 2023, Betsy again asked Aaron when the discovery responses would be provided. Aaron’s reply, dated July 21, 2023 at 11:44 AM, stated that they were working on it. He explained that Amy had sent the answers to Sarena while Sarena was out on bereavement leave, and those responses had become lost in the shuffle; Aaron noted that they had found the responses and were in the process of drafting answers.

The thread shows that the matter involves the delivery of a discovery response for Amy Mills Premise and a demand related to the case, with mediation contemplated for late summer to early fall and ongoing coordination between the two law firms. The communications include direct references to specific dates, the Dropbox link containing the demand, and the noted issue of lost responses during a bereavement-related absence. The contact details in the correspondence identify Betsy Catron as the attorney for Vine Center in Lexington, KY, and Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm, with associated email addresses and firm information reflected in the exchanges.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy Mills – Premise file identified as Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills. The subject of the exchange is a forwarded message titled “FW: Amy Mills.” On August 9, 2023, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm spoke with Amy Mills by phone to gather additional information. Amy stated she does not have any documents related to the jobs at issue, with the most recent position occurring eight years ago. Aaron added the information Amy could remember, and in the accompanying note Bryce Koon instructed to finish up and add something noting that Amy cannot recall specific details like phone numbers, with a plan to supplement if those memories change. The note also states that, aside from what Amy recalled, this is good for filing. Amy has not applied for any jobs in the relevant area since her last job, and there is nothing responsive to the first Request for Production (RPD).

The surrounding email thread provides the progression of discovery communications. Earlier in the thread, on February 13, 2023, Betsy Catron asked whether discovery could be set or a demand could be provided by the end of the month; Aaron Whaley replied that he did not object to the motion and would like to set mediation in April or May. On March 14, 2023, Betsy asked if a demand could be provided by month’s end, and Aaron responded, “I hope so.” By May 12, 2023, Betsy was again asking when a demand could be expected. On June 16, 2023, Aaron sent a message to Betsy and Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019, announcing that the demand had been added to a Dropbox folder, and provided a link to that folder.

On June 27, 2023, Aaron told Betsy that he would get the discovery to her as soon as possible and that he was agreeable to the opposing party’s response at mediation; he also noted that his schedule was favorable for mediation in late August or early September. Betsy replied that she had attached the discovery served on April 28, 2023 and inquired whether the parties were agreeable to a mediation timeline and dates with Judge Knopf; Aaron confirmed he would be available and reiterated willingness to proceed. Betsy later indicated that the firm was working on the responses, explaining that Amy had previously sent answers to Sarena while on bereavement leave and those responses had been mislaid; they had been found and were being drafted.

In late July 2023, Betsy asked when discovery responses could be expected. Aaron replied that the team was working on them and that the answers Amy had previously provided were located and would be drafted into the current set of responses. Betsy’s communications through July include the note that the discovery responses were anticipated and that a mediation timeline was being considered.

In August 2023, the thread shows further activity. On August 8, 2023, Aaron directed Bryce Koon to draft the discovery responses with blanks for any missing information. Bryce responded that he had in fact attempted contact with Amy—texting, emailing, and calling—with no response. Later that day and into August 9, 2023, the thread documents the ongoing process: Aaron’s August 9 email reiterates the phone conversation with Amy, confirms the lack of documents, records the eight-year gap since the most recent job, and notes the plan to supplement if new information becomes available. The August 9 note also includes the directive to finalize the filing and to add the caveat about Amy’s memory for certain details, such as phone numbers.

Throughout this period, the communications reflect the parties’ attempts to obtain complete discovery responses and to coordinate mediation timing. The thread references the assistant contacts, the disposition of discovery responses, the status of Amy’s information, and the use of a Dropbox folder to house the demand. The matter remains set toward resolution via mediation, with mediation discussions anticipated for late August to early September, and the overall objective of finalizing discovery responses despite the gaps in available information. Aaron Whaley’s and Betsy Catron’s signatures and contact details appear in the thread, along with the contact information for Betsy’s firm, Vine Center, located at 333 West Vine Street, Suite 1100, Lexington, KY 40507, with a private phone number listed as 859.422.6000 and a fax number of 859.422.6001.

In summary, the case notes reflect ongoing discovery efforts regarding Amy Mills’ work history, the absence of documentation for the relevant jobs (the most recent being eight years prior), and a sequence of communications dating from February through August 2023 aimed at drafting discovery responses, securing missing information (including supervisor names and wage amounts), coordinating mediation, and organizing documents via a Dropbox link, all while acknowledging Amy’s limited memory for certain details and the plan to supplement as information becomes available.

In the matter of Re: Amy Mills Medical Records, on Wednesday, August 9, 2023, at about 1:51 PM Eastern Time, Aaron Whaley of The Whaley Law Firm sent an email to Sarena Tuttle regarding Amy Mills’ medical records. The message was cc’d to Bryce Koon, the Amy Mills Premise file (Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019), and Jessica Bottorff, among others. Aaron asked if someone could also save the medical records to the medical tab with the bills and the billed amount for each provider.

Earlier in the same thread, at 12:09 PM, Sarena Tuttle replied that she had reviewed the Mills Certified Medical Records (MRs) and found them in the Litigation Folder, properly labeled by Date Received and Provider. She stated she would send all new requests that day to ensure everything was up to date. This followed a prior note in the thread where Sarena stated, “I’m on it,” at 11:53 AM.

The preceding message from Aaron, sent at 11:42 AM, requested that the records be updated and cleaned up. He emphasized the need for certified records for every provider as well as the accompanying bills, and he wanted all information easily accessible in Amy Mills’ file. He pointed out that Mills is still treating with Bluegrass Orthopaedics, Dr. Huff, even though he had previously indicated that treatment was complete. Aaron noted that she had seen Dr. Huff about a month ago and had been referred to an orthopedic clinic in Nashville for her back, and he requested updated records from Bluegrass Orthopaedics as a result. episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills. Re: Amy Mills Medical Records. The exchange begins with an email thread labeled “Re: Amy Mills Medical Records” in which the matter is being organized and updated for Amy Mills. The original sender in the visible thread is Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm, and the message is dated August 9, 2023.

In the thread, Sarena’s signature identifies her as a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, with her contact information and a note that there is a new email address. The header shows the message came from Sarena to Aaron Whaley and was cc’d to Bryce Koon, to a file labeled Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019, and to Jessica Bottorff, with the subject line “Re: Amy Mills Medical Records.”

The body of the thread begins with Sarena replying “Absolutely.” The thread then outlines a sequence of messages exchanged on August 9, 2023. Earlier in the day, at about 11:42 AM, Aaron Whaley asked whether the team could update and clean up the records, ensuring certified records for every provider as well as the associated bills, with all information easily accessible in Amy Mills’s file. He noted that Amy Mills was still receiving treatment from Bluegrass Orthopaedics, specifically Dr. Huff, even though the team had marked treatment as complete, and he requested updated records from Bluegrass because Mills had seen Dr. Huff about a month earlier and had been referred to an orthopedic clinic in Nashville for her back.

Around 11:53 AM, Sarena replied, “I’m on it,” and she signed her message with her full title and contact details. At about 12:09 PM, Sarena wrote that she had reviewed Mills Cert MRs and found they were in the Litigation Folder, properly labeled by Date Recvd and Provider, and that she would send all new requests that day to ensure everything was up to date. She again signed with her title and contact information, including the notice to please note her new email address.

Later, at roughly 1:51 PM, Aaron responded again, thanking Sarena and asking whether she or someone else could also save the medical records to the medical tab, including the bills and the billed amount for each provider. The thread shows the ongoing efforts to organize Amy Mills’s medical records, certify the providers, and ensure that billing information is complete and easily accessible in her file.

Throughout the thread, the communications were directed within The Whaley Law Firm and included the relevant participants in Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019’s matter, with Sarena M. Tuttle consistently handling the organization and verification of Mills’s medical records, and Aaron Whaley directing the need for up-to-date, comprehensive documentation. The record also notes that the correspondence comes from and goes to The Whaley Law Firm’s Louisville, Kentucky offices, with Sarena’s signature listing her phone numbers and her new email address.

This case is labeled Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019 and concerns the client Amy Mills.

On Friday, August 18, 2023, at 19:55:29 UTC, Stephanie Mason, ROI Quality Analyst (stephanie.mason@medicopy.net), sent an email from noreply@box.com to SARENA@whaleylawfirm.com regarding a file for Amy Mills. The message includes a file named AMY MILLS.pdf with a direct access link: https://medicopy.box.com/s/xcsshw7v8drclrrxp0bnhpgrfujmera9, and a View link: https://medicopy.box.com/s/xcsshw7v8drclrrxp0bnhpgrfujmera9.

The body of the email states: “Please click ‘View File’ to access the medical records you have requested. The password for access will be ‘MCSI’ plus the patient’s four-digit birth year (i.e., MCSI1912). Please download the file, as the link will disable in 10 days. If you need further assistance, please contact our office at 866.587.6274. Thank you.” It also includes a prompt to view the file and a note to download, since the link will expire in 10 days, along with the instruction to contact the office for assistance.

The email provides a mobile viewing option with a box app link: https://app.box.com/link/?lp=... (an extended mobile link is included). It also repeats the Box header/footer context, including the standard Box© footer with the address “© 2023 | 900 Jefferson Avenue, Redwood City, CA 94063, USA” and links labeled About Box, Privacy Policy, and related settings (e.g., Edit Notification Settings). The footer lists “MediCopy” and ends with: “To unsubscribe from these emails please click the following link:,” though no unsubscribe link is shown in the note provided.

On Monday, August 21, 2023, at approximately 12:46 PM, Betsy R. Catron, an attorney at Vine Center (WHT Law), wrote to Aaron Whaley regarding mediation dates for Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank. She noted that she and the judge’s mediation calendar, as well as her own schedule, indicated several potential all-day mediation dates: September 21 (all day), October 23 (all day), October 26 (all day), and October 27 (all day). She asked Aaron to advise regarding his availability, adding a preference for the morning if possible. The message was signed by Betsy R. Catron, Attorney, with contact information for Vine Center: 333 West Vine Street, Suite 1100, Lexington, KY 40507; P 859.422.6000; F 859.422.6001; www.whtlaw.com.

The following day, Tuesday, August 22, 2023, at 2:46:29 PM -0400, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, replied to Mrs. Catron. She stated that their office and Mrs. Mills are available for mediation on September 21, 2023, starting at 10:00 AM, and that they prefer a Zoom conference due to the distance of all parties involved. She asked Mrs. Catron to confirm whether this schedule works for her and her client. The message included her signature with full contact details: Sarena M. Tuttle, The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 357-9971; O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS). The email was CC’d to agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com, Aaron Whaley, and Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019. The subject line of the thread was Re: Amy Mills v Forcht Bank mediation.

On September 18, 2023 at 12:44:09 p.m. Eastern Time, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm forwarded an email titled “Fwd: Download Facebook” to multiple recipients, including bellabeautyinstitute@gmail.com, Amy Mills, amy.mills@lindsey.edu, amymillspremisez995806@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com, and Amy Mills again. In the forwarded message, Aaron stated that, in preparation for mediation that week, he wanted to review Amy Mills’s Facebook history, specifically the period before her fall, in order to contrast the before-and-after. He asked to receive Amy’s best pre-fall and post-fall pictures, emphasizing normal, social pictures, and directed that the information be downloaded as part of the process.

The forwarded content included a prior message from Sarena M. Tuttle dated September 14, 2023, at 9:44 a.m., with the subject “Re: Download Facebook,” sent to Bryce Koon and cc’d to Aaron Whaley. Sarena noted that if Amy were using a desktop—which she recommended—it would be a little different and provided the following steps: click the upper right profile picture, click Settings & Privacy, click Your Facebook Information, and click Download. The message was accompanied by three image attachments. Sarena signed as follows:

Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal & Workers' Compensation Case Manager, The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. D: (502) 357-9971, O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104, E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (Please note new email address).

Earlier in the thread, on September 14, 2023 at 9:30 a.m., Bryce Koon responded that he hadn’t done it before but recalled seeing the instructions recently in someone’s discovery requests. Prior to that exchange, Aaron Whaley had sent a message on September 14, 2023 at 9:26 a.m. to Bryce Koon and Sarena Tuttle with the subject “Download Facebook,” asking whether either of them knew how to download Amy Mills’s Facebook history, and stating a desire to retrieve her history going back as far as possible to determine a contrast with the period before the fall.

The thread closes with Aaron Whaley’s signature: Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, 502-583-4022.

Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills. This is in the matter of Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank.

On October 5, 2023, communications regarding Amy Mills’ medical records took place between Betsy R. Catron, attorney at Vine Center in Lexington, KY, and Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm in Louisville, KY, in connection with the Amy Mills case. Betsy requested that Aaron submit the additional medical records and bills related to Amy Mills’ recent medical treatment, and she included her firm’s contact information in the message. Amy Mills and Sarena Tuttle were copied on the correspondence.

Earlier that morning, Betsy had written, “Hi Aaron, [Can you please submit the additional records and bills for your client for her recent medical treatment?] Thank you,” followed by her signature block which listed Vine Center, 333 West Vine Street, Suite 1100, Lexington, KY 40507, with telephone and fax numbers and the website www.whtlaw.com.

In Aaron’s subsequent reply, sent at approximately 11:02 AM, he stated, “Betsy, happy to. What is the last date you have records for?” This indicates the request for the timeframe of the records.

Later that day, at 11:08:59 AM, Aaron sent another message to Betsy with the subject content starting, “Betsy, I’ll make it easy. Here is a link to a dropbox folder with every medical record and bill that I have. Sorted by date.” He provided a Dropbox link: https://www.dropbox.com/sh/1893hm62npxoyf8/AAA-a48rECj5IP5XyKkKv2WJa?dl=0. In this latest message, Betsy was copied along with Amy Mills and Sarena Tuttle.

The signature blocks accompanying the messages included contact details for Betsy Catron at Vine Center and for Aaron Whaley at Whaley Law Firm. Betsy’s signature listed Vine Center’s address and contact information, while Aaron’s signature provided his own firm address and phone number.

Case: Amy Mills premises note for Amy Mills, dated 04-26-2019, documents a sequence of email communications on October 6 and October 16, 2023 between Amy Mills’ attorney and Bluegrass Orthopaedics regarding a telephone conference with Dr. Wallace Huff.

The involved parties were Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm (agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com), and Anna Mercer, the clinical assistant to Dr. Wallace Huff at Bluegrass Orthopaedics (anna.mercer@bluegrassortho.com). Amy Mills was CC’d on the correspondence. The note includes standard confidentiality notices typical of these emails.

The first exchange took place on Friday, October 6, 2023. Anna Mercer indicated that Bluegrass Orthopaedics could arrange a phone conference with Amy Mills’ attorney and Dr. Huff, noting the cost: $1,000 per 30 minutes, with these telephone conferences typically held on Tuesday afternoons. Aaron Whaley replied that he was free on Tuesday and that would work for him.

Later that same day, Anna replied that they could accommodate a phone call with Aaron and Dr. Huff, confirming the rate of $1,000 per 30 minutes and the typical Tuesday afternoon scheduling.

A follow-up thread on October 16, 2023 begins with Aaron Whaley’s confirmation that 10/24/23 would work for him. Anna then announced that she had scheduled the telephone conference for 10/24/2023 at 3:45 p.m. and asked for a fax number to which the invoice could be sent; she also stated that payment would need to be received 48 business hours before the conference to avoid cancellation or postponement.

That same day, Aaron Whaley responded that 10/24/23 works for him. Earlier that morning, Anna had suggested Dr. Huff could do either 10/24/2023 at 3:45 p.m. or 10/31/2023 at 3:30 p.m., and asked Aaron to indicate which date would be preferred so she could send the invoice.

The note also lists the Bluegrass Orthopaedics contact details for reference: 3401 Yorkshire Medical Park, Lexington, KY 40509; phone (859) 263-5140, extension 226; and the website www.bluegrassortho.com, along with social media links (Facebook, Twitter). The Whaley Law Firm signatures include their office address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222 and phone number 502-583-4022.

In addition to these procedural details, the emails include the standard confidentiality notices required by Electronic Communications Privacy Act (18 U.S.C. 2510-2521), cautioning that the information is confidential and intended only for the named recipients, with instructions to notify the sender and delete the message if received in error.

In October 2023, in the matter of Amy Mills (Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019), communications were exchanged between Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm and Anna Mercer, the clinical assistant to Dr. Wallace Huff at Bluegrass Orthopaedics, regarding arranging a telephone conference for Amy Mills. The parties discussed the structure and timing of the session, with Bluegrass noting that a telephone conference costs $1,000 per 30 minutes and that these conferences are typically held on Tuesday afternoons. On October 6, 2023, at 9:36 AM, Anna Mercer stated that they could arrange a phone call with Dr. Huff and that the conference would be scheduled on a Tuesday afternoon. Aaron Whaley responded later that day, at 12:45 PM, saying he was free that Tuesday if it worked.

Dr. Huff’s availability was then proposed for two possible dates: on October 6, 2023, at 8:29 AM, Anna Mercer suggested 10/24/2023 at 3:45 PM or 10/31/2023 at 3:30 PM and asked which date would work, promising to send the invoice once chosen. On October 16, 2023, at 10:13 AM, Aaron Whaley replied that 10/24/2023 works for him. At 10:40 AM that same day, Anna confirmed she had scheduled the telephone conference for 10/24/2023 at 3:45 PM and asked for a fax number to send the invoice, noting that payment would need to be received 48 business hours before the conference to avoid cancellation or postponement. At 10:44 AM, Aaron provided a contact number, 502-357-9939, in response.

The invoice was subsequently faxed. On October 17, 2023, at 11:07 AM, Anna Mercer wrote, “Thank you! I faxed the invoice yesterday.” Later that day, at 12:43:51 PM, Aaron Whaley replied, “I received it, and the check has gone out.” The thread shows that the payment was being handled via a mailed check following the invoicing process.

Throughout the correspondence, standard confidentiality notices were included in each message, reflecting the Electronic Communications Privacy Act (18 U.S.C. sections 2510-2521). The emails also contained the contact information for the parties: Anna Mercer as the Clinical Assistant to Dr. Wallace Huff of Bluegrass Orthopaedics, located at 3401 Yorkshire Medical Park, Lexington, KY 40509, with the office phone number (859) 263-5140, Ext. 226; and Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with the phone number 502-583-4022. The signatures also listed websites and social media handles for Bluegrass Orthopaedics and related details.

In sum, the parties arranged a 10/24/2023 telephone conference with Dr. Huff at 3:45 PM, agreed on a fee structure of $1,000 per 30 minutes, and completed invoicing and payment steps with the invoice faxed on or around October 16, 2023 and the check issued after the receipt of the faxed invoice, with confidentiality notices appended to every message.

This case note concerns client Amy Mills (Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019). The file documents communications about a Dr. Huff meeting and related referrals. On November 10, 2023, at 12:57:25 PM Eastern, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm sent an email titled “Re: Dr. Huff meeting” to the Bellabeautyinstitute email and to Amy Mills (two recipient addresses: bellabeautyinstitute@gmail.com and amymillspremisez995806@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com). In that message, he checked in to see whether Amy had scheduled the requested appointment yet.

The preceding exchanges began on October 24, 2023. At 4:11 PM that day, Aaron Whaley wrote that he had just met with Dr. Huff and attached the note from that meeting. He explained that Dr. Huff had referred Amy to another clinic physician, Dr. Hunt, for an evaluation of her neck. Dr. Huff wanted Amy to obtain a new cervical MRI first, and she would need to call and follow up to arrange that MRI. Whaley also recommended that Amy see a pain-management specialist for her headaches. He concluded by inviting any questions and asking that Amy confirm she had received the message.

Later the same day, at 8:42 PM (text in the thread reads “8:42?PM”), Amy Mills responded that she had received the information and would print it and make an appointment with her primary physician to discuss it as well as taking further steps forward. She signed off with thanks: “Thank You, Amy Mills.”

The thread includes the full contact details for Aaron Whaley and his law firm: Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, phone 502-583-4022. The messages referenced the Dr. Huff meeting, the referral to Dr. Hunt for neck evaluation, the recommendation for a new cervical MRI, and the suggestion to pursue pain management for headaches.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy Mills – Premise 04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills.

In late October 2023, the Whaley Law Firm began coordinating medical steps for Amy Mills following a Dr. Huff meeting. On October 24, 2023 at 4:11 PM, Aaron Whaley wrote to Amy Mills (and to others) after his meeting with Dr. Huff. He said he had met with Dr. Huff and attached the note Dr. Huff wrote after the meeting. Dr. Huff had referred Amy to Dr. Hunt at the same clinic for an evaluation of her neck, and he wanted Amy to obtain a new cervical MRI first, so she would need to call and follow up about that. Dr. Huff also recommended that Amy see someone for pain management to address her headaches. Whaley invited Amy to ask any questions and to confirm that she received the note.

That same day, October 24, 2023, at 8:42 PM, Amy Mills replied that she had received the note, would print it, and would make an appointment with her primary physician to discuss it as well as to take further steps forward. She thanked Whaley for the information.

On November 10, 2023, at 12:57 PM, Whaley sent a follow-up message to Amy Mills, checking in to see whether she had made that appointment yet.

Then, on November 28, 2023, at about 3:45 PM, Amy Mills wrote that they had attempted to proceed but encountered a problem: the MRI machine was down, and after it was repaired she received another call to reschedule. She was told the MRI would be scheduled sometime in December due to the backlog of MRI orders. Amy also stated that she had been down and in bed for over a week with a terrible, debilitating migraine, which explained the delayed reply.

Finally, on December 5, 2023 at 2:22 PM (14:22:54 -0500), Aaron Whaley responded: “I’m sorry to hear that. Let me know when you get rescheduled.” The email exchange demonstrates the plan Dr. Huff laid out—referral to Dr. Hunt for neck evaluation, the need for a new cervical MRI, and consideration of pain management for headaches—along with ongoing efforts to coordinate appointments despite MRI machine downtime and Amy’s migraine-related illness. The communications include the sender and recipient details, with Whaley’s Whaley Law Firm sign-off at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and the firm’s phone number, 502-583-4022.

Dr. Huff wanted Amy to obtain a new cervical MRI first, so she would need to call and follow up regarding that MRI. In the case file titled Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019, involving client Amy Mills, the notes describe communications surrounding a Dr. Huff meeting and subsequent medical-legal actions. On January 3, 2024, the attorney Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm sent an email to Amy Mills and the Bella Beauty Institute, with Amy copied, asking whether the MRI had been rescheduled. He stated that the MRI needed to be completed so that he could send the results to an expert to determine if revision surgery might be necessary and to assess whether a neck issue could be causing Amy’s headaches. If the neck could be ruled out as the source of the headaches, they could move on to treatment for the headaches, and experts could offer an opinion. He noted that obtaining this information was necessary in order to reach the financial figures sought in the case. He also warned that the longer they waited, the worse things could be if the case went to trial, and he needed the information to push the defense toward trial and improve the outcome.

The email trail shows a back-and-forth regarding the MRI rescheduling. On Friday, December 29, 2023, at 2:44 PM, Aaron wrote: “Amy, hope you had a good Christmas. Has the MRI been rescheduled?” Prior to that, on Friday, December 8, 2023 at 8:03 AM, Amy Mills replied, “Ok, I will let you know.” Earlier, on Tuesday, December 5, 2023 at 2:23 PM, Aaron had written, “I’m sorry to hear that. Let me know when you get rescheduled.” And on Tuesday, November 28, 2023 at 3:45 PM, Amy Mills replied: “We did but then the machine was down for the MRI. It was to be fixed and then I got another call for it to be rescheduled. I was told it would be for sometime in December with the backlog of MRI orders. I have been down and in bed for over a week with a terrible debilitating migraine. This is the reason for the long awaited reply.”

The timeline also shows prior outreach: on Friday, November 10, 2023 at 12:57 PM, Aaron asked Amy if she had made the appointment yet. On Tuesday, October 24, 2023 at 8:42 PM, Amy Mills wrote that she had received the note and planned to print it and make an appointment with her primary physician to discuss next steps; she thanked Aaron. Earlier that same day, at 4:11 PM, Aaron informed Amy that he had just met with Dr. Huff and attached the note from that meeting. Dr. Huff had referred Amy to another clinician at the same clinic, Dr. Hunt, for an evaluation of her neck. He instructed that Amy should obtain a new cervical MRI first and follow up with that appointment, and he also recommended that she see someone for pain management for her headaches. He asked Amy to let him know if she had any questions and to confirm receipt of the message.

In summary, the communications chronicle the plan to obtain a new cervical MRI, to evaluate the neck’s potential role in Amy’s headaches through a referral to Dr. Hunt, and to pursue pain management for the headaches, all in the context of advancing the case with the necessary expert opinions and trial readiness. The MRI’s scheduling, the machine’s downtime, and Amy’s health episodes (including a prolonged debilitating migraine) contributed to delays in obtaining the needed information for the case’s valuation and potential trial strategy.
episodes.author: Aaron Whaley
