episodes.natural_language:
This is a narrative summary of the Amy Mills case (Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019), focusing on the correspondence between Amy Mills and attorney Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm regarding medical imaging, neck evaluation, head- and neck-related symptoms, and settlement dynamics following a personal injury.

On January 11, 2024, Aaron Whaley emailed the recipient(s) about whether Amy had been able to obtain an MRI on January 6. In the preceding exchanges, Amy Mills had written on January 4, 2024 that the MRI had been scheduled for Saturday, January 6, 2024. She expressed strong personal urgency and frustration, noting that she had been dealing with severe agony from the injury and could not rush the process. She stated there had been no Christmas for her kids due to her condition. She also described a botched root canal—specifically that the filling had failed and the tooth was exposed—and that extraction could not be performed because of her neck injury and related issues, necessitating surgical removal. 

Amy also commented on the financial aspects of the case. She described the compensation offer as insulting and noted that the four months of 2019 before she was hurt were twice as much, plus more than the annual income estimate; she asserted the tax returns showed this, but the overall impact was a loss from not working for the rest of the year. She claimed that Jason had already made an offer, and that he earns as an owner/operator truck driver for the four-plus years the case had been ongoing. She asserted that a quick search suggested his specialized hazard-pay salary in Kentucky was $84,000, but, in reality, he performed only one contract per month, which she implied equated to the same figure.

Amy identified several medical- malpractice concerns, including a failure to diagnose and prolonged treatment from the initial ER visit, a traumatic brain injury (TBI), and a possible failed spinal fusion. During their ongoing negotiations, she noted that the defense’s lawyer would not even consider returning with a higher offer, suggesting that such behavior could be frowned upon by licensing and insurance boards.

As a side note regarding the scheduled Saturday appointment, Amy warned that if the forecasted snow materialized, she would not attend the appointment due to safety concerns. She attributed this caution to PTSD or anxiety, emphasizing she could not risk potential future harm, and she pledged to keep Whaley posted.

In a January 3, 2024 message, Aaron asked whether the MRI had been rescheduled, explaining that obtaining the MRI was necessary so he could send the results to an expert to determine whether Amy needed a revision surgery and to assess whether the neck might be causing her headaches. He emphasized that ruling out a neck-related cause for the headaches was important to proceed with treatment for the headaches and to obtain expert opinions. He also noted that having this information was essential to determine the financial numbers sought in the case and that delaying the process could worsen the trial position.

Earlier communications included a December 29, 2023 email in which Aaron asked Amy if the MRI had been rescheduled, and a December 8, 2023 reply in which Amy said she would let him know. On December 5, 2023, Aaron expressed sympathy and requested that Amy inform him when she was rescheduled. In a November 28, 2023 message, Amy explained that the MRI had been scheduled but the machine went down, followed by another reschedule request due to backlog; she noted she had been sidelined by a debilitating migraine and bedridden for over a week, which contributed to the delayed reply. On November 10, 2023, Aaron checked in again to see if Amy had scheduled the appointment. On October 24, 2023, Amy acknowledged receipt of the note and said she would print it and discuss it with her primary physician to plan further steps. Earlier that same day, October 24, 2023 at 4:11 PM, Aaron reported that he had met with Dr. Huff; he attached the note Dr. Huff wrote after the meeting, which indicated a referral to Dr. Hunt for a neck evaluation and to obtain a new cervical MRI first, with a recommendation to pursue pain management for headaches. He instructed Amy to call and follow up about the MRI, and to let him know if she had questions and that she received the information.

The review of the threaded correspondence also includes standard practice details: the Whaley Law Firm’s contact information appears at the end of the exchange, including the firm’s address—712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222—and phone number, 502-583-4022.

Case: Amy Mills – Amy Mills (Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019). Client: Amy Mills.

On January 12, 2024, at 12:04:25 PM Eastern Time, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm correspondence to Betsy Catron regarding Amy Mills. In his email, he confirms that the physician Dr. Huff wanted Amy to see was Dr. Paul McCombs, who, however, is retired. Dr. Huff then referred Amy to a spine orthopedic specialist within Bluegrass Orthopaedics. Amy Mills had an updated MRI on January 6, and the results were still pending at the time of the note. Aaron’s message was cc’d to Sarena Tuttle and Amy Mills herself, and it included contact details for Aaron Whaley at Whaley Law Firm.

Earlier that same day, around noon, Betsy Catron—an attorney at Vine Center in Lexington, Kentucky— replied to Aaron. She stated that they were still working on obtaining all of Ms. Mills’s records from Bluegrass Orthopaedics and PT Pros. She asked whether Amy Mills had presented to the Nashville clinic to which she had been referred, and if so, she requested details of the provider. Betsy noted that the Bluegrass Orthopaedics record refers to Dr. Paul McCombs in Nashville, but that Dr. McCombs appears to be retired; she added that he was previously associated with the Howell Allen clinic. The message concluded with thanks and Betsy’s standard signature block.

For reference, Aaron Whaley’s email signature identifies his firm as Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with the phone number 502-583-4022. Betsy Catron’s signature provides her affiliation with Vine Center, 333 West Vine Street, Suite 1100, Lexington, KY 40507, and the office contact numbers 859-422-6000 (phone) and 859-422-6001 (fax).

Case: Amy Mills – Premises file dated 04-26-2019. This narrative summarizes the email exchanges and accompanying notes related to Amy Mills, Dr. Huff, Dr. Hunt, MRI scheduling, neck evaluation, pain management, and associated settlement discussions, covering communications from October 2023 through January 2024.

In the brief notes surrounding Dr. Huff’s meeting, attorney Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm communicated with Amy Mills (and copies to other recipients) to provide updates and coordinate next steps. The exchange began with a note dated October 24, 2023, in which Whaley advised that Dr. Huff had referred Amy to Dr. Hunt for a neck evaluation and that she should obtain a new cervical MRI first. He also recommended that Amy see a pain management professional for her headaches and asked her to confirm receipt of the notice and to raise any questions she had.

Amy responded later on October 24, 2023, saying she would print the note and discuss it with her primary physician, and she thanked Whaley for the information. The thread continued with a follow-up from Whaley on November 10, 2023, asking whether Amy had scheduled that appointment.

On November 28, 2023, Amy explained that the MRI machine was down, and there was a backlog for rescheduling; she also described being bedridden for over a week due to a severe migraine. In her message, she noted that a December reschedule had been communicated and that she had continued to experience substantial symptoms.

Whaley responded on December 5, 2023, expressing sympathy for what Amy was going through and inviting her to inform him when she was able to reschedule. Amy replied on December 8, 2023, that she would let him know. A follow-up from Whaley on December 29, 2023 asked whether the MRI had been rescheduled, extending hope for movement on scheduling during the holiday period.

As January 2024 approached, Whaley pressed the matter again. In an exchange dated January 3, 2024, he emphasized the need for the MRI to be completed so he could forward the results to an expert. The goal was to determine whether Amy would require a revision surgery and to assess whether the neck might be contributing to her headaches. He noted that delaying the MRI could hinder obtaining favorable settlement figures by trial, stressing that progress toward trial depended on having this information.

Amy replied on January 4, 2024 with a detailed message concerning the upcoming MRI scheduled for Saturday, January 6, 2024. She stated that she hoped to have the MRI done but was unwilling to rush it, given the ongoing agony from her injury and the impact on her family—specifically mentioning that there had not been a Christmas for her children due to her condition. She also described a botched root canal, where the filling had failed and the tooth was exposed; she explained that extraction was not an option because of her neck injury and related issues, so surgical removal would be necessary. 

Additionally, Amy vented about the financial aspects of the case. She claimed that the four months of 2019 before her injury were worth more than the annual income estimate used for settlement discussions, noting that tax returns showed a loss from not working for the rest of the year. She asserted that Jason, described as an owner/operator truck driver involved in the case for over four years, had offered compensation that she viewed as inadequate. She claimed that Jason’s salary, described as specialized hazard pay for Kentucky, was stated as $84,000, but she contended that in reality he earned that amount by executing one contract per month. Amy then itemized several grounds for medical malpractice: failure to diagnose and prolonged treatment from the ER, traumatic brain injury (TBI), and a possible failed spinal fusion. 

She also criticized the negotiation process, noting that the defense’s lawyer would not revisit a higher offer, which she believed would concern licensing and insurance boards. As a side note about the scheduled Saturday appointment, she warned that if forecasted snow occurred, she would not attend due to safety concerns, describing it as PTSD or anxiety and expressing a need to protect her safety and reduce risk of future harm. She concluded by saying she would keep Whaley posted.

Following this, Whaley sent subsequent inquiries. On January 11, 2024, he asked Amy whether she had been able to obtain the MRI on January 6. Then, on January 16, 2024, he again checked in, asking if she had managed to get the MRI.

Across these exchanges, the thread repeatedly highlighted the central issues: Dr. Huff’s meeting and the referral to Dr. Hunt for neck evaluation, the necessity of a new cervical MRI before any further treatment decisions, the consideration of pain management for headaches, the medical and economic arguments underpinning settlement positions, and the practical barriers to obtaining the MRI, including equipment downtime, scheduling backlogs, health concerns, and safety considerations for winter weather. The communications reflect an ongoing effort to obtain the MRI results and to move the case toward a resolution while addressing Amy Mills’s substantial medical and personal burdens.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019
Client: Amy Mills

This record comprises a chain of email communications between Amy Mills and Aaron Whaley of the Whaley Law Firm concerning medical evaluation after the Dr. Huff meeting, scheduling of an MRI and referral appointments, and related settlement and case issues, spanning from October 24, 2023 through January 18, 2024.

In late October 2023, Aaron Whaley sent a note following a meeting with Dr. Huff. Dr. Huff’s note stated that Amy Mills should be evaluated by Dr. Hunt for a neck assessment, and that she should obtain a new cervical MRI first. He also recommended that Amy see a pain-management specialist for her headaches. Aaron attached Dr. Huff’s note and asked Amy to confirm receipt and to proceed with the recommended steps. Amy later indicated she understood the plan and the references to the referral and MRI.

On November 28, 2023, Amy reported a delay in scheduling the MRI due to issues with the MRI machine being down and a backlog that would push December scheduling. She explained she had been dealing with a debilitating migraine and had not yet been able to respond fully, emphasizing the impact of the delays on moving the case forward. Aaron acknowledged the situation and encouraged Amy to let him know when she was rescheduled.

Throughout December 2023, the exchange continued as scheduling remained uncertain. On December 5, 2023, Aaron asked Amy to inform him when the MRI could be rescheduled. On December 8, 2023, Amy replied that she would let him know. Aaron followed up again on December 29, 2023, asking whether the MRI had been rescheduled.

In early January 2024, the communications focused on whether the MRI had been rescheduled and the strategic importance of obtaining the MRI. On January 3, 2024, Aaron stressed that the MRI needed to be completed so the results could be forwarded to an expert to determine if a revision neck surgery might be necessary and to assess whether neck issues were contributing to Amy’s headaches. He also noted that delaying information would worsen the case if it went to trial and that advancing this information could help secure a better trial outcome.

On January 4, 2024, Amy provided a detailed update reflecting the MRI scheduling status and a number of personal and case-related concerns. She stated the MRI was scheduled for Saturday, January 6, 2024, and expressed strong personal motivation to have the procedure done promptly due to ongoing pain and the desire to resolve the medical issues. She also described additional health challenges: a botched root canal with a filling that had failed, leaving her tooth exposed, with extraction not being an option because of her neck injury and related issues, thus requiring surgical removal. She criticized the insurance settlement offers as insulting, noting that four months of income in 2019 before the injury was at least twice the estimated annual income; tax returns corroborated the higher earnings prior to the injury, while the overall year was a loss due to not working. She contrasted Jason’s claimed salary for hazard-pay roles in Kentucky—citing an online figure of $84,000—with her understanding that he only performed one contract per month. She described medical-legal concerns including alleged medical malfeasance (failure to diagnose and prolonged ER treatment), a traumatic brain injury (TBI), and a possible failed spinal fusion. She also criticized the opposing side’s attorney for not revising a higher offer, suggesting that such conduct could draw the attention of licensing and insurance boards. Finally, she noted a safety-related warning: if forecasted snow materialized, she would not attend the Saturday appointment due to safety concerns, labeling it as possibly PTSD or anxiety and stating she could not risk future harm. She pledged to keep Aaron updated.

On January 11, 2024, Aaron asked Amy whether she was able to obtain the MRI dated for January 6, to enable him to forward the results to an expert and to assess the need for potentially revising the surgery plan and evaluating whether the neck is contributing to headaches. He underscored the urgency given trial timelines.

On January 16, 2024, Aaron again checked in, asking if Amy had been able to obtain the MRI.

On January 18, 2024, Amy replied that she did obtain the MRI, and that the medical report should be in the possession of the involved parties by now. She explained that due to snow and ice, she had not yet scheduled the referral appointment, but she had a direct contact with whom she had been dealing on the matter.

That same day, Aaron responded, “Great! Let me know when it gets scheduled,” indicating continued coordination on the referral and next steps.

In summary, this record documents: (1) Dr. Huff’s note recommending a neck evaluation by Dr. Hunt and a new cervical MRI, plus pain-management for headaches; (2) ongoing MRI scheduling delays and weather-related postponements from late 2023 into January 2024; (3) a detailed January 4, 2024 email from Amy describing health issues (botched root canal with exposed tooth requiring possible surgical removal due to neck injury), the controversial settlement offers and income history, alleged medical malfeasance (ER treatment failures, TBI, possible failed spinal fusion), and safety concerns about travel due to weather; (4) multiple efforts by Aaron Whaley to obtain MRI results and push for a timely medical-and-legal evaluation; and (5) the MRI ultimately taking place on January 6, 2024, with the report to follow, though referral scheduling remained pending due to weather.

Case: Amy Mills (Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019). Client: Amy Mills.

This narrative summarizes the medical-legal communications between Amy Mills and attorney Aaron Whaley regarding Dr. Huff’s meeting, referrals, and MRI scheduling from October 2023 through January 2024. In late October 2023, after a meeting with Dr. Huff, Whaley informed Mills that Dr. Huff had referred her to Dr. Hunt for a neck evaluation and that she needed a new cervical MRI first. Dr. Huff also recommended that Mills see someone for pain management for her headaches, and Whaley advised her to call and follow up with the referral.

Over the following months, the scheduling of the MRI and related appointments became a recurring topic. On November 10, 2023, Whaley checked in with Mills to see if she had been able to obtain the MRI. By November 28, Mills replied that the MRI machine had been down and there was a backlog; she had also been bedridden for over a week with a terrible debilitating migraine, which contributed to delays in responding. On December 5, 2023, Whaley expressed sympathy for her situation and asked to be informed when she was rescheduled. Mills responded on December 8, 2023, that she would let him know. On December 29, 2023, Whaley followed up again, asking if the MRI had been rescheduled.

In early January 2024, Whaley pressed for progress, noting that the MRI needed to be completed so he could forward the results to an expert to determine whether a revision surgery might be required and to assess whether the neck could be contributing to her headaches. He stressed that the longer they waited, the worse the situation could be for trial purposes, and that obtaining the information was necessary to reach the numbers Mills desired in the case.

On January 4, 2024, Mills replied that she had been called the previous day to schedule the MRI and that it was scheduled for Saturday, January 6, 2024. She emphasized her strong desire to have the MRI done, noting she has been in great pain from the injury and cannot rush the process without harming herself; she added that there hadn’t been a Christmas for her kids because of these issues. Mills also described a dental issue: a botched root canal in which the filling has completely given way, leaving the tooth exposed, and she stated that extraction is not an option due to her neck injury, so the tooth would need to be surgically removed. She criticized the settlement offer being offered, arguing that the 4 months of 2019 before her injury were twice as much (plus) as the annual income estimate; she cited tax returns showing this, but noted that the year was still a loss because she could not work for the remainder of the year. She also alleged medical malpractice, referencing a failure to diagnose and prolonged ER treatment, a traumatic brain injury (TBI), and a possible failed spinal fusion. Regarding the negotiations, she stated that the defense’s lawyer would not go back with a higher offer, which she believed would be disapproved by licensing and insurance boards. She added a side note that if forecasted snow appeared, she might not attend the scheduled appointment due to safety concerns, describing it as PTSD or anxiety and stating she could not risk further harm. Mills concluded by promising to keep Whaley posted.

Subsequent messages show ongoing inquiry about the MRI’s progress. On January 11, 2024, Whaley asked whether the MRI had been completed on January 6. He reiterated the importance of the MRI for moving forward with expert review and trial strategy. On January 16, 2024, he again asked Mills whether she had been able to obtain the MRI. On January 18, 2024, Mills replied that she believed the MRI had occurred and that the MRI report should be available by now, but because of weather (snow and ice), she had not scheduled the referral appointment yet; she also noted that she had a direct contact she had been dealing with regarding the matter. Finally, on January 31, 2024, Whaley followed up with the question: Did your doctor visit get rescheduled?

episodes.natural_language:
This narrative consolidates the email communications in the Amy Mills case, focusing on the Dr. Huff meeting, referrals, MRI scheduling, and related medical-legal strategy, from October 24, 2023 through February 5, 2024.

On October 24, 2023, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm reported that he had just met with Dr. Huff and attached the note from that meeting. Dr. Huff referred Amy to Dr. Hunt, another doctor at the same clinic, for a neck evaluation. He instructed Amy to obtain a new cervical MRI first and to follow up with that appointment. Dr. Huff also recommended that Amy pursue pain management for her headaches.

In late November 2023, Amy Mills reported delays affecting the MRI process. She explained that the MRI machine was down and would need to be fixed, with additional rescheduling expected due to the backlog of MRI orders. She also noted that she had been in bed with a debilitating migraine. Aaron Whaley acknowledged the situation in early December, expressing sympathy and asking Amy to let him know when she was rescheduled.

Throughout December 2023, and into January 2024, the thread continued with follow-up about MRI scheduling. On December 29, 2023, Aaron asked whether the MRI had been rescheduled. On January 3, 2024, he emphasized the need for the MRI to be done so he could forward the information to an expert to assess whether Amy might need a revision surgery and to determine whether the neck could be contributing to her headaches. He noted that delaying further could worsen the situation at trial and stressed the goal of obtaining information to present a stronger position to the defense. He also indicated that the longer the delay, the harder it would be to reach favorable trial numbers.

On January 4, 2024, Amy replied that the MRI was scheduled for Saturday, January 6, 2024. She expressed strong desire to have the MRI done and described the ongoing suffering from the injury. She also provided context about other health and financial stresses: a botched root canal, with the filling having deteriorated and the tooth exposed, and the unsuitability of extraction due to her neck injury, implying the tooth would need surgical removal. She commented on the financial aspect of the case, noting that four months of 2019 before the injury were worth more than the annual income estimate, and that tax returns reflected this despite a loss from not working the rest of the year. She mentioned that her husband Jason had already made an offer and, in her view, more than that as a long-standing owner/operator truck driver. She contrasted his claimed Kentucky hazard-pay salary of $84,000 with her perception that his actual work involves approximately one contract per month. She described the medical-legal issues as including medical malpractice for the failure to diagnose and prolonged treatment from the initial ER visit, a traumatic brain injury (TBI), and a possible failed spinal fusion. She also noted that, during back-and-forth negotiations, the defense’s attorney would not come back with a higher offer, which she suspected would concern licensing and insurance boards.

On January 11, 2024, Aaron Whaley followed up to ask whether Amy was able to obtain the MRI on January 6. He reiterated the importance of having the MRI results for expert review and potential revision surgery considerations, as well as to inform the treatment plan for headaches and the overall case numbers for trial.

On January 16, 2024, Aaron again checked in, asking if Amy had been able to get the MRI.

On January 18, 2024, Amy responded that she did indeed obtain the MRI. She stated that the medical report should be available by now. However, due to weather conditions involving snow and ice, she had not yet scheduled the referral appointment. She noted that she had a direct contact she was dealing with regarding that referral as well.

On January 31, 2024, Aaron asked Amy whether her doctor visit had been rescheduled.

Finally, on February 5, 2024, Aaron followed up once more, asking Amy to confirm whether the doctor visit had been rescheduled, indicating that this remains a current issue in the case.

Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills.

In February 2024, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm emailed Anna Mercer, the clinical assistant to Dr. Wallace Huff at Bluegrass Orthopaedics, and Amy Mills regarding Amy Mills. He noted that Dr. Huff had referred Mrs. Mills to another doctor at Bluegrass Orthopaedics to evaluate her neck and asked Anna if she knew who that doctor was, and whether that doctor had someone as helpful as Anna whom he could contact.

The email thread from October 2023 shows ongoing coordination about Dr. Huff’s involvement. On October 24, 2023, Anna Mercer indicated she was sending “the note Dr. Huff dictated today.” Earlier in the day, Aaron Whaley had provided a phone number: 502-357-5048. Earlier still, Anna asked which phone number she should have Dr. Huff call.

The thread also records several scheduling and billing details. On October 16, 2023, Anna stated that Dr. Huff could do a telephone conference on 10/24/2023 at 3:45 PM or 10/31/2023 at 3:30 PM, and she requested a fax number to send the invoice, noting that payment would need to be received 48 business hours before the conference to avoid cancellation or postponement. Aaron confirmed that 10/24/23 worked for him. Earlier that same day, Anna listed the two available dates for the conference (10/24/2023 at 3:45 PM and 10/31/2023 at 3:30 PM) and offered to send the invoice once a date was chosen. Aaron responded affirmatively that 10/24/23 would work.

On October 16 and 17, 2023 there were continued exchanges about logistics and payment. Aaron provided a contact number of 502-357-9939, and Anna explained the conference arrangements and the 30-minute block rate of $1,000 for a telephone conference with Dr. Huff. There are also notes indicating the invoice was faxed and that a check had been issued, with subsequent confirmations that the check had gone out. Anna’s responses repeatedly referenced the schedule and the invoice process, and Aaron’s replies confirmed acceptance of the proposed arrangements.

The email chain includes the usual signatures and contact details for the parties. Anna Mercer is identified as the Clinical Assistant to Dr. Wallace Huff at Bluegrass Orthopaedics, located at 3401 Yorkshire Medical Park, Lexington, KY 40509, with a phone number of (859) 263-5140 Ext. 226 and a corresponding website. The signatures also contain standard confidentiality notices consistent with the Electronic Communications Privacy Act, and the messages reference typical disclaimers about privileged and confidential information and the proper handling of misdirected messages. The Whaley Law Firm signatures repeatedly appear with their Louisville, Kentucky address and phone number as well.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills.

On February 14, 2024, a forward of Amy Mills’ file was sent by Aaron Whaley to Amy Mills’ address. The message includes a note from Anna Mercer stating that Dr. Huff referred Amy Mills to Dr. Hunt for evaluation, but the appointment was canceled because Amy Mills canceled her MRI at Lexington Diagnostics. Anna notes that Dr. Hunt’s assistant is Kristen Cox and that her extension is 364.

In a separate thread within the same forward, dated February 14, 2024 at 1:11 PM, Aaron Whaley asked Anna Mercer if she could identify which doctor at Bluegrass Orthopaedics had been referred to for a neck evaluation and whether that doctor had an assistant as helpful as Anna, so he could reach out if needed. Anna had previously sent a note on October 24, 2023, indicating “Here is the note Dr. Huff dictated today,” which suggests Dr. Huff’s referral and related details were being circulated to the parties.

The October 2023 portion of the chain shows additional context about coordinating Dr. Huff’s involvement. Communication on October 24, 2023 included notes of a telephone conference for Dr. Huff and related scheduling details. The thread shows a contact number used in these communications: 502-357-5048. Earlier exchanges on October 16, 2023 included the number 502-357-9939, and discussions about which phone number Dr. Huff should call. There were arrangements for a telephone conference with Dr. Huff, typically conducted on Tuesday afternoons, at a rate of $1,000 per 30 minutes. Dr. Huff offered two possible times for the conference: October 24, 2023 at 3:45 PM or October 31, 2023 at 3:30 PM, with Dr. Huff’s assistant and scheduling details handled through Anna Mercer, Clinical Assistant to Dr. Wallace Huff of Bluegrass Orthopaedics.

The correspondence also covered logistical and billing aspects. Anna asked for a fax number to send an invoice and stated that payment would need to be received 48 business hours before the conference to prevent cancellation or postponement. Several notes reference the invoicing process, including mentions of sending the invoice and a subsequent payment note that the check had gone out. Specific contact and billing details appear in the thread, including a telephone number for inquiries (502-357-9939) and a fax line (the exact fax number appears in the exchange as part of the invoicing discussion). The chain includes the standard confidentiality notices typical of these professional communications, with signatures for Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm (712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, 502-583-4022) and for Anna Mercer of Bluegrass Orthopaedics (3401 Yorkshire Medical Park, Lexington, KY 40509, 859-263-5140 Ext. 226).

In summary, the notes reflect: Dr. Huff referred Amy Mills to Dr. Hunt (Dr. Hunt’s assistant is Kristen Cox, extension 364) for neck evaluation, but the appointment was canceled due to Amy Mills canceling her MRI at Lexington Diagnostics. The broader thread documents prior efforts to identify the referred Bluegrass Orthopaedics physician, coordinate a Dr. Huff teleconference (usually on Tuesdays) at a cost of $1,000 per 30 minutes, and manage the associated invoicing and payment timeline, including specific phone and fax numbers and the parties’ contact details.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills.

In January 2024, the record shows an ongoing correspondence between attorney Betsy Catron of WHT Law and Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm regarding Amy Mills. On January 12, 2024 at 12:00 PM, Betsy Catron wrote to Aaron inquiring about obtaining all of Ms. Mills’ records from Bluegrass Ortho and PT Pros. She asked whether Ms. Mills had presented to the Nashville clinic to which she was referred and requested details about that provider. Betsy noted that the Bluegrass Ortho record referred to Dr. Paul McCombs in Nashville; however, she understood that Dr. McCombs is now retired and that he was previously affiliated with the Howell Allen clinic. Betsy asked for confirmation of provider details and for any additional records.

That same day, January 12, 2024 at 12:04 PM, Aaron Whaley replied to Betsy. He explained that the doctor Dr. Huff had wanted Amy Mills to see was Dr. Paul McCombs, but Dr. McCombs is retired. Dr. Huff had referred Amy to a spine orthopedic surgeon within Bluegrass Orthopaedics. Aaron added that Amy had undergone an updated MRI on January 6 and that they were waiting for the results.

Earlier, on January 12, 2024, Betsy Catron had already sent the initial inquiry regarding records and the Nashville referral. The thread shows Betsy’s concern about sourcing records from Bluegrass Ortho and PT Pros, and her request for information about the January 6 MRI results.

Moving forward to March 2024, the activity continues. On March 1, 2024 at 7:43 AM, Betsy sent another message reiterating that they were having difficulty obtaining records from Bluegrass Ortho and PT Pros. She asked whether Aaron had any updated records he could provide and whether there was any further information following the January 6 MRI.

Later that same day, at 11:35 AM, Aaron responded to Betsy. He stated that Amy Mills could not attend the previously scheduled appointment due to a severe snowstorm. He noted that Amy is currently scheduled for an appointment on March 11. The exchange confirms that the schedule adjustment was weather-related and that plans were set for a later date.
episodes.author: Aaron Whaley

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy Mills – Premise 04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills.

Re: Amy Mills. On Friday, March 1, 2024, at 11:35:24 AM, in an email from Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm (agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com) to Betsy R. Catron of Vine Center (betsy.catron@whtlaw.com), with copies to Sarena Tuttle (sarena@whaleylawfirm.com) and Amy Mills (amymillspremisez995806@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com), Aaron stated that Amy Mills could not attend the previously scheduled appointment due to one of the bad snowstorms and that she is currently scheduled for March 11.

Earlier that day, at 7:43 AM (time shown as 7:43?AM in the record), Betsy Catron replied, explaining that they were having difficulty obtaining records from Bluegrass Orthopaedics (Ortho) and PT Pros, and asking Aaron for any updated records he could provide, as well as any further information following the January 6 MRI.

Looking back to January, 2024, the thread shows that on Friday, January 12, 2024 at 12:04 PM, Aaron Whaley wrote to Betsy Catron (cc’d to Sarena Tuttle and Amy Mills) confirming that the doctor Dr. Huff had wanted Amy to see was Dr. McCombs, but Dr. McCombs is retired. Dr. Huff then referred Amy to a spine orthopedic provider within Bluegrass Orthopaedics. Aaron noted that Amy had an updated MRI on January 6 and that they were waiting on the results.

Also on January 12, 2024, at 12:00 PM (time noted as 12:00?PM in the record), Betsy Catron wrote again, stating that they were still working on obtaining all of Ms. Mills’ records from Bluegrass Ortho and PT Pros. Betsy asked whether Amy had presented to the Nashville clinic referenced by Bluegrass Ortho, and if so, for details of the provider. The Bluegrass Ortho record referred to Dr. Paul McCombs in Nashville, though it appeared that he is now retired; she noted that he had previously been associated with the Howell Allen clinic.

Betsy’s signature block then followed, listing her as Attorney at Vine Center, with the address 333 West Vine Street, Suite 1100, Lexington, KY 40507, and contact information: P 859.422.6000, F 859.422.6001, www.whtlaw.com.

The thread also includes Aaron’s closing signature, showing his information as part of the Whaley Law Firm: 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, 502-583-4022, and a standard external email caution notice.

In summary, the communications between January and March 2024 revolved around locating and obtaining Amy Mills’ medical records from Bluegrass Ortho and PT Pros, confirming which physician Amy was referred to (initially Dr. McCombs, who is retired), noting a January 6 MRI with results still pending, and coordinating scheduling after a snowstorm prevented an earlier appointment, with Amy now scheduled for March 11.

episodes.natural_language:
This narrative summarizes the email communications in the Amy Mills case (Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019) regarding MRI and orthopedic follow-up, as documented by The Whaley Law Firm.

On March 12, 2024, Sarena Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager for The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email about the MRI and ortho follow-up. The subject was Re: MRI and Ortho Follow up. In the body of the message, she noted that a task had been set to order the MRI that day, and she had called Nicole (HIM) to request that the MRI report be faxed. She also stated that she sent a CRR via fax, and that confirmation had been received, with the matter now being that the practice is awaiting records and bills. The email was directed to Aaron Whaley, with Amy Mills CC’d, and included Sarena’s signature block with her title and contact information, along with a note to please note the new email address. The message included The Whaley Law Firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY, and listed direct line and main office numbers.

The record also captures prior correspondence in the chain. On February 14, 2024, at approximately 1:13 PM, Aaron Whaley wrote to Amy Mills, checking in to see whether she had been able to obtain the MRI results and whether she had recently seen the orthopedic specialist or had a scheduled appointment. He closed with thanks.

Later, on March 9, 2024, at approximately 1:43 PM, Aaron Whaley again wrote, stating simply, “Need this MRI report ASAP.”

Also on March 9, 2024, in a forwarded message from Amy Mills dated around 1:25 PM, she replied to Aaron Whaley: “Hello, Yes I did, I had sent an email on this a few times actually. I will be going to a specialist on Monday. I will keep you updated. Thanks, AM.” This indicates that Amy had previously sent multiple emails on the MRI/report issue and that she anticipated a specialist appointment on the following Monday, with a commitment to provide updates.

In summary, the March 12, 2024 note confirms that the team had requested the MRI report be faxed, had arranged for related records (CRR) to be faxed, and were awaiting the associated records and bills, while the February and March exchanges show ongoing client inquiries about MRI results and orthopedic follow-up, and Amy Mills’ confirmation of a pending specialist visit and ongoing updates.

episodes.natural_language:
This note documents a sequence of email communications about a new case for Amy Mills, filed under Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019.

On March 27, 2024, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm in Louisville, Kentucky, reached out to Kate Smith to inquire about having Dr. Orlando review one of his cases. He explained that Dr. Orlando comes highly recommended by his friend Robert Mattingly and described the matter as fairly complicated, asking what steps he needed to take to get the process started. The email was sent to Kate Smith (and included Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019 in the cc line, along with Marc Orlando and Amy Mills’ filevine-associated contact) and carried Aaron’s signature detailing the Whaley Law Firm’s address and phone number.

On the same day, March 27, 2024 at 2:27 PM, Kate replied. She introduced herself as Kate Smith, a nurse and life care planner who works with Dr. Orlando and helps keep his schedule organized and records uploaded. She stated that they often handle catastrophic cases where an independent medical examination (IME) and a life care plan (LCP) are needed, and she noted that they work both jointly and individually. She attached their usual forms, including an introduction letter, CVs, fee schedules, and W-9s, and mentioned that she also had her own information attached. Kate provided her direct line (513) 312-1742 and her email address marcinckate@gmail.com. She also outlined availability for a phone call: March 28 anytime from 11:00 AM to 4:00 PM, March 29 at 9:00 AM, April 1 from 10:00 AM to 2:00 PM, and April 2 from 10:00 AM to 4:00 PM. She emphasized that Dr. Orlando and she frequently work together on catastrophic cases and that they can work jointly or separately. The message included a standard notice indicating that the email and attachments may contain sensitive information intended only for the recipient.

Later the same day, Aaron responded with appreciation but asked for further guidance, writing: “Kate, I am inquiring about getting one of my cases reviewed by Dr. Orlando. He comes highly recommended. Robert Mattingly is one of my good friends and he recommended Dr. Orlando. I have a pretty complicated case and want to know what I need to do to get the ball rolling. Thank you so much for your time.” His signature followed, listing his firm’s name and contact information.

Shortly after, on March 28, 2024 at 1:03 PM, Kate followed up to Aaron with a brief note: it had been great speaking with him earlier that day and that she had discussed the case with Dr. Orlando, but unfortunately, this is a case they would not be able to assist with. Aaron replied about five minutes later, asking, “Ok. Why?”

This chain of emails establishes that the matter originated as a new case for Amy Mills (Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019) and that Aaron Whaley sought Dr. Orlando’s review, a request ultimately declined by Kate after consultation with Dr. Orlando. The communications include the initial inquiry, the information about Dr. Orlando’s team and services, the attachments provided, the availability for a call, the standard notice about sensitive information, and the final determination that the case could not be accepted.
episodes.author: Aaron Whaley

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019. The client involved is Amy Mills.

The record begins with a new-case inquiry. On March 27, 2024, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm (712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-583-4022; agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com) reached out to Kate Smith (marcinckate@gmail.com) regarding a potential review by Dr. Orlando. He explained that Dr. Orlando comes highly recommended by a mutual contact, Robert Mattingly, and noted that the case is fairly complicated and he wanted to know what he needed to do to get things rolling. He also indicated that this inquiry related to a case involving Amy Mills.

In response, on March 27, 2024, Kate Smith introduced herself. She explained that she is a nurse and a life care planner who works with Dr. Orlando and helps manage his schedule, records, and related logistics. She stated that she and Dr. Orlando often collaborate on catastrophic cases requiring an IME (independent medical examination) and an LCP (life care plan), though they can work jointly or individually. She attached their standard materials, including an introduction letter, CVs, fee schedules, and W-9s, and noted that she also has her own information on file. She provided her contact details: direct line 513-312-1742 and email marcinckate@gmail.com, and offered to discuss the case further by phone. She listed available times for a call: March 28 anytime from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m., March 29 at 9 a.m., April 1 from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m., and April 2 from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. She also included a notice stating that the message and attachments may contain sensitive information and are for the intended recipient.

Also on March 27, 2024, Aaron Whaley replied to Kate, asking for clarification. He stated that he was inquiring about having one of his cases reviewed by Dr. Orlando, noting that Dr. Orlando comes highly recommended and that Robert Mattingly—his good friend—had recommended Dr. Orlando. He described the case as pretty complicated and asked what he needed to do to get the ball rolling.

On March 27, 2024 at 2:27 p.m., Aaron sent a further message reinforcing his inquiry about Dr. Orlando and thanking Kate for her time.

On March 28, 2024 at 1:03 p.m., Kate replied that it had been great speaking with Aaron and that she had discussed the case with Dr. Orlando; unfortunately, they would not be able to assist with the case.

At 1:06 p.m. on March 28, Aaron asked, “Ok. Why?”

Then at 1:16 p.m., Kate responded that, due to their current busy schedule, they have had to be more selective when accepting cases. She suggested that the case may be more appropriate for a neuro-headache specialist who can discern what are new migraine symptoms, specifically distinguishing those symptoms from a fall versus pre-existing conditions.

Finally, at 1:26 p.m. on March 28, Aaron sent a closing reply: “Ok, thank you. You would not happen to have someone to refer in that area?”

This summarizes the sequence of outreach, responses, and referrals discussed in the correspondence regarding the Amy Mills Premise case.

episodes.natural_language:
In the case file for Amy Mills, titled Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019, the client is Amy Mills. The communications center on gathering and updating medical records from Bluegrass Orthopedics, PSC, and on tracking appointments related to her care.

On April 3, 2024, at 11:02:32 a.m. (04:00 offset -0400), Sarena M. Tuttle, the Whaley Law Firm’s litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager, wrote to Betsy R. Catron with the subject FW: Amy Mills. She advised that she was attaching the most recent records received from Bluegrass Orthopedics, PSC and invited Betsy to contact her directly if anything further was needed to discuss the matter in detail. Tuttle noted her new email address and provided her contact information: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct line (502) 357-9971; office line (502) 583-4022 ext 104; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com.

Earlier, on April 2, 2024, at 10:31?PM, Aaron Whaley of The Whaley Law Firm forwarded a message. The forwarded content shows Whaley’s firm details (712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222; 502-583-4022) and a note indicating a forwarding of prior correspondence without substantive changes to the case record at that time.

The forwarded message originated from Betsy Catron, dated April 2, 2024 at 4:11?PM, addressed to Aaron Whaley with the subject FW: Amy Mills. Betsy stated that attached were records from Bluegrass Ortho for Amy Mills and asked whether there was anything from 2024 or an update on Amy’s March appointment.

Before this, Betsy had emailed on March 1, 2024 at 12:07 PM, sending a reply to Aaron with a brief “RE: Amy Mills” and simply “Ok, thanks.”

Prior to that, Aaron Whaley had replied on March 1, 2024 at 11:35 AM to Betsy. His message explained that Amy could not make the appointment during a snowstorm, and that she was currently rescheduled for March 11.

On March 1, 2024, at 7:43?AM, Betsy had written to Aaron asking for updates. She noted that there was difficulty obtaining records from Bluegrass Orthopedics and PT Pros and requested any updated records as well as information following the January 6 MRI.

The chain also contains prior correspondence from January 12, 2024. At 12:04 PM, Aaron Whaley wrote to Betsy (Cc’d to Sarena Tuttle and Amy Mills). He stated that the doctor Dr. Huff wanted Amy to see was Dr. McCombs; however, Dr. McCombs is retired. Dr. Huff referred Amy to a spine orthopedic specialist within Bluegrass Orthopedics. He also noted that Amy had an updated MRI on January 6 and that the results were pending.

Earlier that same day, January 12, 2024 at 12:00 PM, Betsy had written: she was trying to obtain all of Ms. Mills’ records from Bluegrass Orthopedics and PT Pros and asked whether Amy Mills had presented to the Nashville clinic she was referred to; if so, Betsy requested details of the provider. Betsy noted that Bluegrass Orthopedics’ record referred to Dr. Paul McCombs in Nashville, but that he is apparently retired, having previously been associated with Howell Allen clinic.

The thread includes the signatures and contact details of the participants. Betsy Catron’s signature lists Vine Center, 333 West Vine Street, Suite 1100, Lexington, KY 40507, with phone and fax numbers (P) 859.422.6000 and (F) 859.422.6001, and the website www.whtlaw.com. Aaron Whaley’s signature lists Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, with phone 502-583-4022 and a standard external email caution. Sarena Tuttle’s signature lists her role at The Whaley Law Firm and provides her contact information, including the note “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS” for Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com. The communications reference the new email address for Sarena and include the firm’s Louisville address and phone numbers.

Together, the exchanges reflect ongoing efforts to obtain 2024 records, confirm the status of Amy Mills’s March appointment, and clarify details regarding the referred Nashville provider and the January 6 MRI results, with the latest update being that the most recent records from Bluegrass Orthopedics were attached to the April 3, 2024 email from Sarena Tuttle.

She says they are doing fairly okay, but it has been a hard long road. She notes there were so many people at the funeral it was unreal; the funeral home couldn't hold them and there were lines down the street of people trying to get in. From city counsel members to judges and politicians to local business owners, and they came from other states even. She adds that it hasn't been easy but we r making it one day at a time. The message was sent on 2024-05-15 via the inbound channel.

__Message:__ Aaron it's Amy 
I just wanted to let you know that I have contacted the federal insurance regulating board and for the state due to the inaccurate compliance of the issue with the mri and requesting approval. After we get over this minor issue I'll update you further. 
They may be the insurance company but they do Not have the final say! 
Everyone has a governing body and someone over them! I am definitely not letting anything go within this case even down to the most minor detail! 
It will be fine and we will be back on track soon .

Kathleen, it has been a minute. I have a case that I need some work on. I
am thinking I need a narrative of what injuries are related to a fall as
well as an IME. Probably need a life plan from there. Client slipped and
fell on a marble floor at a bank. She was in her late 30's at the time.
Since the fall in 2019 she has had a cervical fusion, shoulder labral
repair, migraine headaches and still has shoulder/neck pain. Current
treaters at Bluegrass Ortho have gone back and forth between whether it is
her shoulder or neck. I have records as well as timelines I have created. I
can send records already separated by date or just all together. Whatever
is easiest for you. Thanks!

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy Mills Premise 04-26-2019. The client is Amy Mills. This matter concerns expert services in connection with a fall and related medical evaluations.

In August 2024, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm reached out regarding a case requiring expert work. In an email sent on August 5, 2024 at 11:02:40 a.m. Eastern Time, addressed to Kathleen Johnson of PMR Life Care Plans, along with Amy Mills Premise and others, Aaron explained that he needed a narrative tying injuries to a fall and an independent medical examination (IME), followed by a life care plan. He described the incident as the client slipping and falling on a marble floor at a bank, noting she was in her late 30s at the time. Since the 2019 fall, she has undergone a cervical fusion and a shoulder labral repair, suffers migraine headaches, and continues to experience shoulder and neck pain. Her current treating physicians at Bluegrass Orthopaedics have vacillated between shoulder- versus neck-related causes. Aaron stated that he has records and timelines prepared and could provide records either organized by date or in total, depending on what is easiest for the recipient.

Earlier, on Friday, July 26, 2024 at approximately 1:20 p.m., Aaron Whaley sent an initial inquiry to pmrlifecareplans@gmail.com. He explained that he had obtained the contact information from Seth Gladstein, who spoke highly of their services, and asked for a list of all the services and doctors available, including good medical reviews, narratives, IME reports, life care plans, and related offerings.

On Saturday, July 27, 2024 at about 10:03 a.m. (time approximate in the record), Kathleen Johnson replied to Aaron. She opened with a warm greeting, noting that it had been a while since they last connected. She attached PMR Life Care Plans, LLC’s current team overview and fee schedule. She announced that in September they would be adding six pediatric PM&R life care planners from Gillette Children’s and Vanderbilt University, as well as four additional adult PM&R physicians from Vanderbilt and the University of Kentucky (UK). She offered to discuss the arrangement in more detail by phone or coffee, noting availability on Monday and Tuesday of the following week.

Johnson described PMR Life Care Plans, LLC as a national provider offering forensic consultation, expert medical opinions, and life care planning services, supported by a team of renowned, board-certified adult and pediatric physical medicine and rehabilitation physicians, orthopedic surgeons, and neurologists. She stated that this group comprises academic leaders, researchers, and practicing clinicians whose primary mission is advancing medical knowledge and patient care, with their forensic work grounded in academic rigor. She explained that PMR’s mission-driven approach underpins their damages valuation services, including impartial assessments of future medical care, loss of earnings capacity, and loss of household services for individuals affected by chronic or catastrophic injuries. Johnson emphasized the commitment to impartiality and professionalism, asserting that their evaluations are trusted, credible, and unbiased. She claimed that PMR not only sets the standard for medical expert consultation but also embodies a mission-driven service essential to the advancement and just resolution of complex litigation cases.

Johnson signed as Kathleen Gormley Johnson, Owner/Chief Strategist/Chief Operations of PMR Life Care Plans, LLC, located at 37 River Hill Rd, Louisville, KY 40207. Her contact details were listed as KathleenJohnson@pmrlifecareplans.com, with the website www.pmrlifecareplans.com, business phone 502-530-6265, and mobile 859-750-2678. The message included a confidentiality disclaimer noting that it may contain privileged information or work product and advising that unintended recipients should notify the sender and delete the message and any attachments.

The thread also contains an earlier message from Aaron Whaley, dated Friday, July 26, 2024, to pmrlifecareplans@gmail.com, reiterating his request for information about services and doctors after a referral from Seth Gladstein, and closing with his signature and firm contact details (Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, 502-583-4022).

episodes.natural_language:
In late July and early August 2024, the Whaley Law Firm began coordinating with PMR Life Care Plans to obtain expert services for a case involving Amy Mills, labeled Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019. The client, Amy Mills, slipped and fell on a marble bank floor in 2019. In the course of the case, Aaron Whaley sought a narrative linking injuries to the fall, an independent medical examination (IME), and likely a life-care plan to support damages valuation.

The outreach began with Aaron Whaley’s email dated July 26, 2024. He explained that he had learned of PMR Life Care Plans through Seth Gladstein and was seeking a full suite of expert services, including medical reviews, narratives, IMEs, and life-care planning. He noted that the client’s fall occurred in 2019, and that since then she has undergone a cervical fusion and a shoulder labral repair, experienced migraine headaches, and continued to have shoulder and neck pain. He described the treating physicians at Bluegrass Orthopaedics as alternating between attributing her symptoms to the shoulder or to the neck, with the latest assessment indicating the problem might originate from the neck. He stated that he had records and timelines available and asked whether PMR preferred records organized by date or all at once.

Kathleen Johnson of PMR Life Care Plans responded on July 27, 2024. She attached PMR’s current team overview and fee schedule and noted upcoming expansions: in September, PMR planned to add six pediatric PM&R life care planners from Gillette Children’s and Vanderbilt University, and four additional adult PM&R physicians from Vanderbilt and UK. She proposed a meet-and-greet via Zoom with Aaron and a few of the doctors to determine the best fit for the project. Johnson asked for Aaron’s project timeline and inquired whether Mills had been treated at UofL or Frazier, and who the treating physicians were that were debating whether the issue was neck or shoulder, as this information could assist the physicians in determining the best approach.

Earlier that same week, on August 5, 2024, Aaron Whaley sent another email to Kathleen Johnson and Amy Mills, reiterating the request. He explained that the case had been quiet for some time and needed to move forward. He described the client as having fallen on a marble bank floor and, at the time, being in her late 30s. Since the 2019 fall, she had undergone a cervical fusion, a shoulder labral repair, and experienced migraine headaches, with ongoing shoulder and neck pain. He reaffirmed that the current treaters at Bluegrass Orthopaedics had vacillated between shoulder and neck as the source of the pain. He stated that he could provide records already sorted by date or in a single bundle, depending on what was easiest for PMR, and that he could send timelines and materials as needed.

In response, also on August 5, 2024, Kathleen Johnson proposed potential physicians for the project. She suggested Dr. Hockenbury, Dr. Carrasquer, Dr. Chen, or Dr. Wagers as possible experts and expressed a desire to arrange a meet-and-greet Zoom with Aaron and a couple of them to determine the best person for the project. She asked for the project timeline and again inquired about Mills’ treating facilities (UofL or Frazier) and the identifying of treating physicians who were debating whether the neck or the shoulder was the source of the problems, noting that this information would assist the physicians in determining the best approach.

Shortly after, Aaron Whaley sent a follow-up email on August 5, 2024, at approximately 11:03 a.m., addressing Kathleen and Amy Mills. He recalled that the case had been quiet for a while and reiterated the needs: a narrative identifying which injuries were related to the fall, an IME, and likely a life plan. He restated the core facts: Amy Mills slipped and fell on a marble bank floor in 2019 when she was in her late 30s; since the fall she had a cervical fusion, a shoulder labral repair, and migraine headaches, with persistent shoulder and neck pain. He again noted that the treating physicians at Bluegrass Orthopaedics had given differing opinions on whether the symptoms were shoulder- or neck-related and indicated he could provide records either by date or in one complete bundle.

In the original thread dating from July 26, 2024, Aaron had reached out to PMR Life Care Plans seeking a comprehensive list of services and available doctors, asking for examples of the work they could provide (reviews, narratives, IMEs, life-care plans, etc.). Kathleen’s July 27 follow-up included a detailed overview of PMR’s team and outlined upcoming expansions and the firm’s mission to provide impartial, academically grounded forensic consultation and life-care planning for litigation.

Together, the exchanges establish a sequence of outreach and coordination intended to secure PMR Life Care Plans’ expert services for Amy Mills’ case. The team would, if engaged, deliver a narrative linking the fall to Mills’ injuries, conduct an IME, and develop a life-care plan, with consideration given to which doctors should be involved and where Mills was treated, and with the aim of moving the case forward as the parties align on the proper medical source of Mills’ current symptoms.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank. The client is Amy Mills, in the matter captioned Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank, with the case file labeled Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019.

On September 16, 2024, Betsy R. Catron, an attorney at Vine Center in Lexington, KY, wrote regarding the case. She noted that written discovery had been served on the Plaintiff on August 2, 2024, but no response had been received, and because the discovery was past due, she asked Aaron Whaley of the Whaley Law Firm to advise when the responses could be expected so as to avoid petitioning the Court to compel. She also requested an update on Amy Mills’s treatment and asked that any treatment records be provided as soon as possible.

Earlier that same day, at 11:18 a.m., Aaron Whaley replied that he was working on obtaining records and that Amy Mills had a new MRI on September 11. He stated that he did not yet have those records.

Earlier still, at 11:17 a.m., Betsy Catron had written that written discovery had been served on August 2, 2024, but no responses had been received, and she reiterated the need for a timely update to avoid court intervention. She requested information on her client’s treatment and, if treatment had taken place, asked for the records as soon as possible.

On October 17, 2024, Betsy followed up again, asking whether there were any new records for Amy Mills and for an update on her treatment status.

Finally, on October 21, 2024 at 11:08:38 a.m. (Eastern Time), Aaron Whaley sent a further update. He stated that he did not have new records at that moment, but that Amy Mills had recently undergone a new MRI of her shoulder, which showed a new tear of the labrum located at the suture from her previous surgery. He added that she is currently in physical therapy again. The message was sent to Betsy Catron, with CCs to Sarena Tuttle (sarena@whaleylawfirm.com and stuttle.wlf@gmail.com) and Gregg Thornton (GThornton@whtlaw.com).

Throughout the exchange, the parties’ communications circulated among the Whaley Law Firm and the WHT Law Firm, with the subject line Re: Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank, and the email header identifying Aaron Whaley as the sender and Betsy Catron as the recipient, along with the CC list. The correspondence includes standard firm signatures and disclaimers typical of external email, noting the offices and contact details for Betsy Catron and the Whaley Law Firm.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

In the matter of Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank, Knox County Circuit Court, case number 20-CI-00112, the file is titled Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019 and lists Amy Mills as the client. The communication thread begins with a November 27, 2024 email from Elizabeth Romersa, a paralegal at Vine Center in Lexington, KY, to Aaron Whaley at Whaley Law Firm (agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com) with Betsy Catron, Gregg Thornton, and Elizabeth Romersa copied. The subject line was Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank – Knox County Circuit Court 20-CI-00112. In that message, Elizabeth Romersa stated that attached please find the recently filed Motion to Compel and exhibits along with the Proposed Order regarding the above-referenced matter, and she invited any questions to contact their office directly. The message included the standard confidentiality notice: information contained in the email transmission is privileged and confidential, and if you are not the intended recipient you should not read, distribute, or reproduce it; if received in error, delete it and notify the sender. The Vine Center contact details listed were 333 West Vine Street, Suite 1100, Lexington, KY 40507, with P 859.422.6000, F 859.422.6001, and the website www.whtlaw.com. The email was signed as from Elizabeth Romersa, Paralegal to Walter Ward, William Partin, Betsy Catron, James Freel, Whitney Williams, and Jeanette Jayne, affording the firm’s address and standard notice.

In the chain of messages that followed, the forwarded message from Elizabeth Romersa was addressed to agwhaley@louisville-accident-lawyer.com, with Betsy Catron, Gregg Thornton (GThornton@whtlaw.com), and Elizabeth Romersa copied. Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, was advised that the Motion to Compel and exhibits, along with the Proposed Order, had been filed and attached, and that any questions should be directed to their office. The communications also carried the Whaley Law Firm’s standard contact information and the attorney’s disclosures.

On December 2, 2024, at approximately 11:39 AM, Aaron Whaley replied to Sarena Tuttle’s message, and the body of his reply began with a forwarded message block referencing Elizabeth Romersa’s November 27 email containing the attached Motion to Compel, exhibits, and the Proposed Order. This reply included the same confidential notice and contact details as in the forwarded message, and it reiterated the ongoing handling of the matter.

Shortly thereafter, at around 11:45 AM, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, replied with: “Already saved to File :) Has she disclosed her new providers yet?” Sarena’s signature identified her role and contact information: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; Direct line 502-357-9971; Office line 502-583-4022 ext 104; Email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, and a note that this is a new email address.

At approximately 11:47:21 AM on December 2, 2024 (GMT-05:00), Aaron Whaley responded, “nope. I have reached out to her. Ill let you know.” This line followed the initial content of the thread and confirmed that Aaron had attempted contact with Amy Mills and would provide an update.

Throughout these exchanges, the participants and recipients included the case caption referencing Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank (Knox County Circuit Court 20-CI-00112), the file-note reference Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019, and the involvement of The Whaley Law Firm and Vine Center personnel. The communications included the Motion to Compel and exhibits along with the Proposed Order, the attached confidentiality notices, and the updated contact details for Sarena M. Tuttle (new email address) and the Whaley Law Firm’s main address and phone numbers.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills. Re: Amy Mills v Forcht Bank. This note documents a chain of communications regarding discovery and treatment records in the Amy Mills v Forcht Bank matter.

On December 12, 2024, at 12:19:06 GMT-05:00, Betsy Catron of Vine Center in Lexington, KY received an email from Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm concerning Amy Mills. In that message, Aaron stated that after speaking with Amy, they could provide Betsy with all the information and responses to her interrogatories and requests for production. This included identifying who Amy is treating with after January 3. January 3 was noted as the date of Amy’s upcoming shoulder surgery, and Amy wished to wait to reveal the doctor’s identity until after the surgery. Aaron explained that the doctor had said he would not take Amy as a patient if she were in litigation, and Amy did not want the surgery canceled.

This December 12 email followed a prior thread, beginning with Betsy’s question on November 26, 2024 at 2:11? PM asking who Amy’s providers for physical therapy were and who would perform the surgery. In Aaron Whaley’s reply, sent that same day at 8:48 AM, he explained that he did not know those providers. He did, however, confirm that Amy had completed physical therapy and that she was scheduled for shoulder surgery on January 3.

Earlier in the chain, on November 25, 2024 at 11:06? AM, Betsy had written requesting updated records and asking for the names of Amy’s current treating providers so those records could be requested.

Prior to that, on October 21, 2024 at 11:09 AM, Aaron wrote that he did not know the PT providers but noted that Amy had a new MRI of her shoulder showing a new labral tear at the suture from her previous surgery and that she was currently in physical therapy again.

On October 17, 2024, Betsy had asked Aaron to check for any new records for Amy and to update her on treatment status.

On September 16, 2024, Betsy inquired about treatment and records, and Aaron responded at 11:18 AM that he was working on it and that Amy had a new MRI on September 11, with the records not yet in hand. Earlier that same day, Betsy had noted that written discovery had been served on August 2, 2024, but no response had been received; she cautioned that the discovery was past due and requested within a week an expectation for responses, along with an update on Amy’s treatment and any available records.

Throughout these communications, the email chain included various recipients and CCs, such as Sarena Tuttle and Gregg Thornton, and a Filevine project email address associated with Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019, as reflected in the CC line of the December 12, 2024 message. The correspondence circulated among counsel concerning the handling of interrogatories, production requests, treatment records, and the forthcoming disclosure of Amy’s treating physician, to be disclosed after her January 3 shoulder surgery, due to litigation considerations.
episodes.author: Aaron Whaley

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank, file noted as Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019, with Client: Amy Mills.

In a December 12, 2024 email chain regarding the Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank matter, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm asked Gregg Thornton of WHT Law whether Thornton was asserting a right to dictate when Amy Mills can receive medical care ordered by her treating physician. The message opened with the question: “Gregg, are you asserting that you have the right to dictate when my client can receive medical care that has been ordered by her treating physician?”

Thornton replied later that day, stating that his firm could not agree to that position. He explained that Amy Mills is in litigation and that they need to evaluate the current films and records so their expert can determine whether anything else is needed before the surgery to address the incident can be opined as related. He added that waiting until after the surgery to hide the fact that she is in litigation from the surgeon is not something they could agree to.

Also on December 12, 2024, Aaron Whaley sent a separate message to Betsy Catron (with various others copied) indicating a willingness to provide complete responses to interrogatories and production requests. He stated that these would include information about who Amy Mills is treating with at that moment after January 3, which he identified as the date of her upcoming shoulder surgery. He noted that Amy would like to wait until after the surgery to reveal the identity of the treating doctor, explaining that the physician has said he will not take her as a patient if she is in litigation, and Amy does not want her surgery canceled.

The December 12 exchange followed a prior thread beginning in late November 2024. On November 26, Betsy Catron had asked who Amy Mills’ providers for physical therapy were and who would perform the shoulder surgery. Aaron Whaley responded that he could not provide the names of those providers at that time, but did confirm that Amy had completed physical therapy and was scheduled for shoulder surgery on January 3. Earlier in the month, on November 25, Betsy Catron had asked for any updated records and requested the identity of Amy’s current treatment providers so she could request those records. Whaley’s reply on that date did not provide the requested provider names but acknowledged the status of therapy and surgery plans.

This sequence followed prior communications dating back to October 2024. On October 21, 2024, Aaron Whaley indicated that he did not have new records to provide but knew that Amy had completed a new MRI on September 11 showing a new tear of her labrum located at the suture from her previous surgery, and that she was currently in physical therapy again. Betsy Catron had inquired on October 17, 2024 about any new records, and Aaron’s response highlighted the absence of new records at that time, while confirming the September 11 MRI and ongoing physical therapy.

Earlier in September 2024, Betsy Catron had noted in her September 16, 2024 correspondence that the plaintiff’s discovery had been served on August 2, 2024, but the defendants had not yet received responses. Aaron Whaley replied that Amy had a new MRI on September 11, and he did not yet have those records, while Betsy urged prompt provision of updated treatment information and records.

In summary, the communications reflect ongoing litigation in the Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank matter, with the defense insisting on evaluating current medical films and records before surgery to determine relatedness to the incident, and the plaintiff’s counsel seeking to delay disclosing the treating physician’s identity until after the January 3, 2025 shoulder surgery to avoid jeopardizing treatment. The record also documents Amy Mills’ ongoing treatment status: completed physical therapy, a planned shoulder surgery on January 3, 2025, and a September 11 MRI revealing a new labral tear at the suture from her prior surgery. The parties repeatedly discussed production of medical records and identification of treating providers, against the backdrop of litigation considerations and the surgeon’s willingness to treat patients who are in litigation.
episodes.author: Aaron Whaley

From: Aaron Whaley [agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com)

Greg, no one is saying that you can’t have the records or copies of all of
the MRIs and the other scans. You can certainly have those reviewed to
determine if the tear is related or not. Whether or not she has the surgery
on January 3 won’t have an impact on that.
January 3 is in three weeks so sometime shortly after that I will be able
to provide you with the names of all of the new providers as well as an
executed medical authorization.

There is nothing that the court is going to do that will be any faster than
that.

Aaron Whaley
Whaley Law Firm
712 Lyndon Ln
Louisville, KY 40222
502-583-4022
