episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy Mills v Forcht Bank, Premise file 04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills. This narrative reflects the email correspondence regarding discovery and medical records in the Amy Mills v Forcht Bank matter, focusing on communications dated December 12, 2024, and the earlier interim updates between September and November 2024.

On December 12, 2024, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm sent an email to Gregg Thornton of Vine Center with Betsy Catron, Sarena Tuttle, and the Amy Mills premise email address copied. In his message, Aaron stated that no one was prohibiting the defense from obtaining the records or copies of all of Amy Mills’s MRIs and other scans, and that those records could be reviewed to determine whether the tear is causally related to the incident. He added that whether Amy Mills undergoes shoulder surgery on January 3 would not affect the ability to review those records. He noted that January 3 was three weeks away and that shortly after that date he would provide Thornton with the names of all new providers as well as an executed medical authorization. He closed by saying that there is nothing the court would do that would move faster than that. Aaron’s contact information shared in this message included Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, telephone 502-583-4022, and agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com. The message also referenced that the email was part of the Amy Mills v Forcht Bank case and included the Amy Mills Filevine project email address in the CC line.

Later on December 12, 2024, Gregg Thornton replied (the message timestamp showing 3:37 PM). He asserted that he would never claim the right to restrict records, but emphasized that his client is only responsible for what is causally related. Since Aaron had indicated this was a new tear, Thornton said they needed to look at it. Thornton provided his contact details: Vine Center, 333 West Vine Street, Suite 1100, Lexington, KY 40507; phone 859-422-6000; fax 859-422-6001; email gthornton@whtlaw.com; and site www.whtlaw.com. He also included a standard confidentiality disclosure found in professional emails and noted the message originated from an iPhone.

Earlier on the same day, Aaron had sent a preliminary note (timestamp around 3:19 PM) to Betsy Catron with a warning that the message was external email. In that exchange, Aaron asked whether Gregg was claiming the right to dictate when Amy Mills could receive medical care ordered by her treating physician. The thread then includes Gregg’s reply (2:29 PM) stating that they cannot agree to waiting; they need to evaluate the current films and records because their expert needs to determine whether additional records are required before the surgery to assess whether the treatment is related to the incident; Aaron’s attempt to delay disclosure until after surgery to “hide the fact that she is in litigation from the surgeon” was not acceptable to them.

The thread then traces earlier communications in late 2024. In Aaron Whaley’s December 12, 2024 email to Betsy Catron, with a copy to Sarena Tuttle, Gregg Thornton, and the Amy Mills Filevine address, Aaron indicated that they could provide Betsy with all responses to interrogatories and requests for production, including information about who Amy Mills was treating with after January 3. He noted that January 3 was the date of her shoulder surgery and that she wished to wait until after the surgery to disclose the doctor’s identity because the doctor had stated he would not treat a patient who is in litigation, and Amy did not want her surgery canceled.

Previously, Betsy Catron had asked, on November 26, 2024, who Amy Mills’s PT providers were and who would perform the surgery. Aaron responded that he did not have that information at that time but noted that Amy had completed physical therapy and was scheduled for shoulder surgery on January 3. On November 25, 2024, Betsy had requested updated records and to know who Amy Mills was currently treating with so those records could be requested. This line of inquiry sits within ongoing discovery in the case.

The back-and-forth also reveals historical updates from September through October 2024. On September 16, 2024, Betsy Catron wrote asking for an update on Amy Mills’s treatment and records, and Aaron replied that he was working on it and that Amy had a new MRI on September 11, but he did not yet have those records. Betsy followed up on September 16 about the status. On October 17, 2024, Betsy again asked whether there were new records for Amy Mills and about treatment status. Aaron responded on October 21, 2024, stating that he did not have new records but did note that Amy had a new MRI showing a new tear of her labrum, located at the suture from her previous surgery, and that she was currently in physical therapy again. A later message on October 21 referenced that Amy Mills had completed physical therapy and was again in PT. On November 26, 2024, Aaron confirmed that Amy had completed physical therapy and was scheduled for shoulder surgery on January 3, while noting that he did not have updated records at that moment.

In summary, the December 12, 2024 correspondence reflects a dispute over the timing and scope of medical-record disclosures in the Amy Mills v Forcht Bank case. Aaron Whaley indicated that records, including MRIs, could be reviewed to determine causation and that new provider information and an executed medical authorization would be provided after Amy Mills’s scheduled January 3 shoulder surgery. Gregg Thornton disputed any arrangement that would delay evaluation of current films and records and insisted that records must be reviewed to determine whether the tear is related to the incident, arguing against hiding information from the surgeon. The thread also documents a pattern of prior updates from September through November 2024, including MRI findings showing new labral tears near prior surgical sites, ongoing physical therapy, and the evolving intent to disclose physicians’ identities and treatment providers after the January 3 surgery. The CCs and addresses included in the exchanges identify the involved parties and their contact details, including Betsy Catron, Sarena Tuttle, and Amy Mills Premise file email address, along with the law firm and medical-provider contact information.

Case: Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank (file: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019) involves client Amy Mills. The following notes summarize a sequence of counsel communications in late 2024 regarding medical records and treatment status for Amy Mills. The exchanges were between Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm (Louisville, KY) and Betsy R. Catron of Vine Center ( Lexington, KY), with multiple colleagues copied on the emails. The subject line across the thread was Re: Amy Mills v Forcht Bank.

On September 16, 2024, Betsy Catron, attorney at Vine Center, Lexington, KY, emailed Aaron Whaley noting that written discovery had been served on the Plaintiff on August 2, 2024 but no responses had yet been received. She asked for an update on her client’s treatment and requested that records be provided as soon as possible, and she provided her firm’s contact details. In the same exchange, Aaron replied that he did not have updated records at that moment but did report that Amy had a new MRI on September 11 showing a new tear of her labrum at the suture from her previous surgery, and that she was currently in physical therapy again.

Earlier in the thread, Betsy had also communicated that the discovery had been served on August 2, 2024 and emphasized the need for responses to avoid court intervention; she requested updates on treatment and any records as soon as possible, attaching the signature block of her firm (Vine Center, 333 West Vine Street, Suite 1100, Lexington, KY 40507; P 859.422.6000; F 859.422.6001; www.whtlaw.com).

On October 17, 2024, Betsy again checked in, asking whether there were any new records for the client and an update on her treatment status.

On October 21, 2024, Aaron replied that he did not have new records but noted that Amy had a new MRI on September 11 showing a labral tear at the suture from her prior surgery and that she was currently in physical therapy again.

On November 25, 2024, Betsy asked for updated records and specifically requested to be told who Amy Mills is currently treating with so Betsy could request those records directly.

The following day, November 26, 2024, Aaron responded: unfortunately, he did not have updated records. He did, however, state that Amy has completed physical therapy and is scheduled for shoulder surgery on January 3.

For reference, the emails included the following participants and contact details: Betsy R. Catron, Attorney, Vine Center, Lexington, KY 40507, P 859.422.6000, F 859.422.6001, www.whtlaw.com; Aaron Whaley, Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, 502-583-4022; CC’d recipients included Sarena Tuttle (sarena@whaleylawfirm.com; stuttle.wlf@gmail.com) and Gregg Thornton (GThornton@whtlaw.com).

This file covers the Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank case, with client Amy Mills, and tracks a sequence of internal emails among the attorneys handling the matter.

In late November 2024, Betsy R. Catron, an attorney at WHT Law (Vine Center, 333 West Vine Street, Suite 1100, Lexington, KY 40507), sent an email to Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm (and copied colleagues Sarena Tuttle and Gregg Thornton) asking for any updated records related to Amy Mills and, specifically, who Amy is currently treating with so Betsy could request those treatment records. The message, dated Monday, November 25, 2024 at 16:03:58 UTC, included the external‑email caution note about attachments and links from external senders.

This inquiry followed an earlier thread of communications. On October 21, 2024, Aaron Whaley replied that he did not have updated records in hand but did note that Amy Mills had undergone a new MRI of her shoulder, which revealed a new tear of the labrum at the suture from her prior shoulder surgery, and that she was currently in physical therapy again.

Before that, on September 16, 2024, Betsy had written that written discovery had been served on the Plaintiff on August 2, 2024, but no response had been received. She warned that discovery was past due and asked Aaron to indicate within the next week when he could expect the plaintiff’s responses so as to avoid a court compel order. Betsy also requested any update on Amy’s treatment and, if treatment existed, the corresponding records as soon as possible. The email from Betsy on September 16 included an explicit request for updates on treatment and records and again carried the external‑email caution note.

Aaron’s reply, also dated September 16, 2024, stated that he was working on obtaining the information and that Amy had a new MRI on September 11, but he did not yet have those records in his possession.

A related message from Betsy, sent around the same day, reaffirmed the request for treatment updates and for records ASAP, and emphasized the need to address the discovery timeline to avoid court intervention.

In summary, the correspondence shows a focused effort across September through November 2024 to obtain updated medical records for Amy Mills and to ascertain her current treating provider, in light of a new MRI finding on September 11 and subsequent treatment activity, with multiple reminders about discovery responses and ongoing medical treatment.

episodes.natural_language:
This is a chronological narrative of the email correspondence in the case captioned Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank, involving client Amy Mills. The communications ran from September through November 2024 and were between Betsy R. Catron, an attorney with WHT Law in Lexington, Kentucky, and Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm in Louisville, with Sarena Tuttle and Gregg Thornton copied on several messages.

On September 16, 2024, Aaron Whaley replied to Betsy Catron that he did not have updated records to provide at that moment but noted that Amy Mills had a new MRI on September 11. He stated that he was working on obtaining those records. In Betsy Catron’s reply sent shortly afterward, she reminded Aaron that written discovery had been served on the plaintiff on August 2, 2024 and had not yet produced responses, and she asked for an update on Amy’s treatment and for the records ASAP to avoid court action to compel discovery.

Later on September 16, 2024, Betsy followed up again to request any available updates on Amy’s treatment and to obtain records if treatment existed. Aaron responded that he did not have the records yet but reiterated that Amy had a new MRI on September 11 and was in the process of obtaining them.

On October 17, 2024, Betsy sent another inquiry asking whether there were any new records for the client and what her treatment status was. Aaron’s subsequent message on October 21, 2024, indicated that he did not have updated records but did provide a medical update: Amy had a new MRI on her shoulder showing a new tear of her labrum, located at the suture from her previous surgery, and she was currently in physical therapy again.

Moving forward to late October and November 2024, Betsy continued to seek updated records and current treatment information. On November 25, 2024, Betsy asked whether there were updated records she could obtain and requested confirmation of who Amy Mills was currently treating with so that she could request those records directly. In the following exchange on November 26, 2024, Betsy asked, “Who are her providers for PT and who is doing the surgery?”

Aaron Whaley replied that he did not know the PT providers or the surgeon, but he did know that Amy had completed physical therapy and was scheduled for shoulder surgery on January 3 (the year is not specified in the notes). The thread shows the ongoing attempt to obtain current medical records and verification of treating providers as part of the case management process.

Throughout these exchanges, the email chain included numerous copies to Sarena Tuttle (two addresses) and Gregg Thornton, reflecting the involved legal teams at Whaley Law Firm and WHT Law. Betsy Catron’s messages also carried her attorney signature and contact information, indicating her affiliation with Vine Center in Lexington, Kentucky.

In summary, between September and November 2024, the office of Betsy Catron repeatedly asked for updated medical records and confirmation of Amy Mills’s current treatment status. Aaron Whaley repeatedly reported that new imaging existed—specifically a September 11 MRI showing a labral tear at the prior surgical suture—and that Amy was in physical therapy again, but he did not provide the PT providers or the surgeon involved. By late November, the latest status indicated that Amy had completed physical therapy and was scheduled for shoulder surgery on January 3, with no disclosed information on the treating PT providers or the surgeon.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019
Client: Amy Mills

Re: Amy Mills v Forcht Bank

On December 12, 2024, Gregg Thornton, a member of WHT Law, sent an email regarding the Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank matter to Aaron Whaley and Betsy Catron, with Sarena Tuttle and a Filevine project email address copied on the thread. In his message, Thornton stated that the opposing side could not agree to the proposed arrangement because Amy Mills is in litigation. He explained that the defense team needed to evaluate current films and records so their expert could determine whether anything additional was needed before Amy’s upcoming shoulder surgery in order to render an opinion about whether the surgery is related to the incident. Thornton cautioned that waiting until after the surgery to conceal the litigation from the surgeon was unacceptable. He signed as MEM BER at the Vine Center, Lexington, KY, and included standard confidentiality language warning that the email and any attachments are privileged and confidential and should be deleted if received in error.

Earlier that same day, Aaron Whaley replied to Betsy Catron and copied the same recipients. His external-email notice appeared at the top of the message. Whaley reported that he had spoken with Amy and that they could agree to provide Betsy Catron with all information and responses to interrogatories and requests for production, including who Amy is treating with after January 3 (the date of her upcoming shoulder surgery). He stated that Amy would like to wait to reveal the doctor’s identity until after the surgery because the doctor has indicated he will not take her as a patient if she is in litigation, and Amy does not want her surgery canceled.

This email thread sits within a broader discovery and treatment-status narrative dating back to September 2024. On September 16, 2024, Betsy Catron asked Aaron Whaley for an update, noting that written discovery had been served on August 2, 2024, and requesting the plaintiff’s records if there were any treatment updates. Whaley responded later that day that Amy had had a new MRI on September 11, which showed a new tear of her labrum at the suture from her previous surgery, and that she was in physical therapy (PT) again, but Whaley did not yet have the records.

On October 17, 2024, Betsy followed up again, asking if there were any new records for Amy Mills and for an update on her treatment status. Whaley replied on October 21, 2024, saying he did not have updated records and that Amy had received a new MRI showing a labral tear located at the sutures from the prior surgery, and that she was in PT again.

The thread continued with Betsy’s inquiry on November 25, 2024, asking for any updated records and specifically who Amy was currently treating with so those records could be requested. Whaley replied on November 26, 2024, that he did not have updated records; he did know that Amy had completed PT and was scheduled for shoulder surgery on January 3. Betsy followed up again on November 26, 2024, asking for the names of Amy’s PT providers and who would be performing the surgery.

In the same December 12, 2024 exchange, Aaron Whaley stated that he was willing to provide all information and responses to interrogatories and production requests, including the identity of Amy’s current treatment providers after January 3. He reiterated that January 3 marks the date of her upcoming shoulder surgery and that Amy preferred not to disclose the doctor’s identity before that date. He added that the doctor had indicated he would not take a patient who is in litigation, and Amy did not want her surgery canceled.

Taken together, the communications reflect a litigation-centered context for Amy Mills’s medical treatment records related to a shoulder injury and surgery, with contemporaneous concerns about the timing of disclosing treating providers and the potential impact of litigation status on medical care. The messages include multiple external-email warnings and standard confidentiality notices, and they document a sequence of MRI findings (notably a new labral tear at the prior suture site), ongoing physical therapy, a scheduled shoulder surgery on January 3, and the conditional release of treating-provider information after the stated surgery date.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy Mills Premise 04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills. This note summarizes an email thread connected to the case Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank, involving Amy Mills’s medical treatment status, discovery responses, and the scheduling of her shoulder surgery, as discussed by counsel in December 2024 and in prior months.

On September 16, 2024, Betsy R. Catron of WHT Law wrote to Aaron Whaley of the Whaley Law Firm noting that written discovery had been served on the Plaintiff on August 2, 2024 but had not yet been answered. She stated that because the discovery was past due, she wanted to know when she could expect the Plaintiff’s responses, to avoid seeking court intervention to compel. Betsy also requested an update on the Plaintiff’s treatment and asked for records as soon as available. Aaron Whaley replied that he was working on it and that the Plaintiff had a new MRI on September 11, but he did not yet have those records.

On October 17, 2024, Betsy Catron checked in again for an update on whether there were any new records. Aaron’s response on October 21, 2024 stated that he did not have updated records to provide yet but did know that Amy Mills had a new MRI on her shoulder indicating a new tear of the labrum at the suture from her previous surgery, and that she was currently in physical therapy again.

On October 21, 2024 Betsy followed up to inquire about who Amy Mills was currently treating with and what records could be obtained. Aaron replied that he could not provide those details at that moment but reiterated that Amy had had a new MRI on September 11 and that she was in physical therapy again.

On November 25, 2024, Betsy asked for any updated records and specifically requested to know who Amy Mills was currently treating so those providers’ records could be requested. Aaron responded on November 26, 2024 that he did not have updated records to provide at that time, but he did confirm that Amy had completed physical therapy and was scheduled for shoulder surgery on January 3. Betsy had previously asked for the names of Amy’s providers for physical therapy and the surgeon who would perform the surgery.

On November 26, 2024, Betsy had previously asked, “Who are her providers for PT and who is doing the surgery?” Aaron had replied that he did not have updated records to share yet but confirmed the PT status and the January 3 surgery date.

In addition to the above, a December 12, 2024 email thread began with a message from Aaron Whaley to Betsy Catron (and others) stating that he could agree to provide information and responses to interrogatories and requests for production, including who Amy Mills was treating with after January 3. He explained that January 3 was the date of her upcoming shoulder surgery and that Amy would prefer to wait until after the surgery to reveal the doctor’s identity, noting that the doctor had indicated he would not take her as a patient if she remained in litigation and that Amy did not want her surgery canceled.

That same day, December 12, 2024 at approximately 2:29 PM, Gregg Thornton of WHT Law replied: “Aaron we cannot agree to this. First she is in litigation. We need to evaluate the current films and records because our expert needs to tell us if they need anything else before the surgery is performed to be able to give an opinion if it is related to this incident. Waiting until after the surgery because you want to hide the fact that she is in litigation from the surgeon is not something we can agree to.” Thornton’s message was followed by his standard confidentiality and privilege notice with the WHT Law Firm contact information.

The December 12, 2024 exchange thus centers on two core issues: (1) whether Amy Mills can disclose the identity of her treating doctor and provide certain medical information before her January 3 shoulder surgery, given that she is in litigation; and (2) whether the defense team will review current imaging and records and defer any dependent actions until after the surgery to avoid exposing litigation status to the surgeon. The parties reiterate the tension between timely discovery and the implications of litigation status on medical treatment and record sharing, with Amy Mills’s upcoming January 3 shoulder surgery a focal point of the discussion.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

In the case Amy Mills v Forcht Bank (Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019; Client: Amy Mills), the following email communications occurred between September and December 2024 among Amy Mills’ counsel and opposing counsel. The participants include Gregg Thornton of WHT Law (Vine Center, Lexington, KY), Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm (Louisville, KY), and Betsy Catron plus Sarena Tuttle on distribution. The notes reference a Filevine project address for Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019.

On September 16, 2024, Betsy Catron reported that written discovery had been served on the Plaintiff on August 2, 2024, but no responses had yet been received. She asked for a timeline to avoid a court motion to compel and requested any updates on the plaintiff’s treatment and accompanying records. Aaron Whaley replied that he did not have updates yet but was working on obtaining them; he noted that Amy had a new MRI on September 11 and that he did not yet have those records.

A follow-up from Betsy on October 17, 2024, inquired whether Aaron had any new records or information regarding Amy’s treatment status. Aaron responded on October 21, 2024 that he did not have new records to share at that time. He did indicate that Amy’s shoulder MRI showed a new tear of the labrum at the suture from her prior surgery and that she was back in physical therapy.

Toward the end of November 2024, Betsy asked for updated records and to identify Amy’s current treatment providers so she could request those records. On November 26, 2024, Aaron replied that he did not have new information on providers, but he did confirm that Amy had completed physical therapy and was scheduled for shoulder surgery on January 3. Betsy had previously requested information about who was treating Amy for physical therapy and who would perform the surgery.

On December 12, 2024, the parties exchanged further messages. Aaron Whaley told Betsy that they could provide all information and responses to interrogatories and requests for production, including who Amy would be treating with after January 3. He noted that January 3 is the date of Amy’s upcoming shoulder surgery and that Amy would like to wait until after that date to reveal the doctor’s identity, because the doctor had said he would not take a patient who is in litigation, and Amy did not want her surgery canceled.

Gregg Thornton responded later that day, stating, “Aaron we cannot agree to this. First she is in litigation. We need to evaluate the current films and records because our expert needs to tell us if they need anything else before the surgery is performed to be able to give an opinion if it is related to this incident. Waiting until after the surgery because you want to hide the fact that she is in litigation from the surgeon is not something we can agree to.”

In reply, Aaron Whaley asked, “Gregg, are you asserting that you have the right to dictate when my client can receive medical care that has been ordered by her treating physician?” Gregg Thornton later clarified, “Absolutely not I would never do that. However my client is only responsible for what is causally related and since you said this is a new tear we need to look at it.”

Whaley stated that no one was saying Thornton could not obtain records or copies of all of Amy Mills’s MRIs and other scans; those records could be reviewed to determine whether a tear is related to the incident. He added that whether Amy Mills undergoes surgery on January 3 would not affect that analysis. Whaley indicated that January 3 is in three weeks, and that shortly after that date he would be able to provide Thornton with the names of all new providers as well as an executed medical authorization. He also asserted that there is nothing the court will do that would be faster than that timeline. Whaley signed as with Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, with the phone number 502-583-4022.

Later on December 12, 2024, Gregg Thornton replied, stating, “Absolutely not I would never do that. However my client is only responsible for what is causally related and since you said this is a new tear we need to look at it.” Thornton’s signature block followed, showing his firm Vine Center at 333 West Vine Street, Suite 1100, Lexington, KY 40507, with the phone number 859-422-6000, fax 859-422-6001, and email gthornton@whtlaw.com.

Also on December 12, 2024, a separate message from Aaron Whaley appeared at 3:19 PM, prefaced with an external email warning. In that note, Whaley asked Thornton whether he was asserting the right to dictate when the client could receive medical care ordered by her treating physician, given that Amy Mills is in litigation and the surgeon had been instructed to act in accordance with her physician’s orders.

Earlier that same day, at 2:29 PM, Thornton wrote that he could not agree to the proposed arrangement. He explained that because Amy Mills is in litigation, they needed to evaluate the current films and records so that their expert could determine whether anything else was needed before the surgery to be able to opine on whether the surgery is related to the incident. He added that waiting until after the surgery in order to “hide” the litigation from the surgeon is not something they could agree to.

At 12:19 PM, Whaley had written a prior message to Betsy Catron (with Betsy Catron copied on the thread and to other recipients) indicating that he and Amy Mills could agree to provide all information and responses to Betsy Catron’s interrogatories and requests for production. This included disclosing who Amy Mills was treating with after January 3. Whaley noted that January 3 was the date of her upcoming shoulder surgery, and Amy Mills would prefer to wait until after that surgery to reveal the doctor’s identity. He explained that the doctor had stated he would not take a patient if the patient were in litigation, and Amy Mills did not want her surgery canceled.

This December 12 sequence followed earlier communications in the same case. On November 26, 2024, Betsy Catron had written asking for updated records and, specifically, who Amy Mills was currently treating with so those records could be requested. Aaron Whaley replied that he did not have the requested providers for physical therapy or the surgeon’s identity, but he did know that Amy Mills had completed physical therapy and was scheduled for shoulder surgery on January 3.

On November 25, 2024, Betsy Catron had requested updated records and the identity of Amy Mills’s current treating providers so she could request those records. On October 21, 2024, Betsy Catron stated that she did not have the providers but knew there had been a new MRI showing a new tear in Amy Mills’s shoulder labrum, located at the suture from her previous surgery, and that Amy Mills was currently in physical therapy again.

Betsy Catron had previously written on October 17, 2024, checking in for any new records and the status of Amy Mills’s treatment. On September 16, 2024, Betsy Catron sent two messages: at 11:18 AM she asked for an update, noting that Amy Mills had a new MRI on September 11 and that she did not yet have those records; at 11:17 AM she mentioned that written discovery on Amy Mills had been served on August 2, 2024, and, noting some garbled content, asked to be informed within the next week when responses could be expected to avoid court compulsion, and requested any available updates on treatment and records if treatment existed.

In sum, the December 12, 2024 communications built on a longer thread about the management of medical records, the timing and conditions of treatment and surgery (notably a shoulder surgery scheduled for January 3), and the curricular need to identify treating providers—while balancing the plaintiff’s litigation status and the desire to protect the treating physician(s) from appearing to tailor care around litigation. The parties repeatedly discussed whether records could be supplied now and how the identities of treating providers would be disclosed, with the surgeon reportedly not accepting patients who are in litigation and with Amy Mills’s counsel indicating a willingness to provide information after the January 3 surgery and to share the medical authorization and provider list shortly thereafter.

Re: August interrogatories. On December 17, 2024, at 12:21:40 PM (GMT-05:00), an email was sent from Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm to Aaron Whaley, with a copy to the Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019 Filevine project email address. The subject line indicated the matter concerned the August interrogatories. In the body of the message, Sarena explained that the list included every provider listed in Amy Mills’s file, noting that most of the firm’s most recent CMRs (case medical reports) were from 2023 through March 2024. She added that this did not necessarily mean Amy had seen those providers in 2023 or 2024, and asked whether Aaron would like her to review Amy’s records and narrow the list.

Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, provided her contact details and signature, including the firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with direct line (502) 357-9971 and office line (502) 583-4022 ext 104. She noted a new email address: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com.

Earlier in the thread, Aaron Whaley had replied on December 17, 2024, at 12:12? PM, asking: “That looks good. The list of providers is all provider since 01/01/2023?”

Prior to that, on December 17, 2024, at 11:51? AM, Sarena sent a draft message to AW. She wrote that she had prepared the draft you requested, listing all known providers and any related objections, and asked AW to review for approval before submitting to the DC. She also stated that she would send updated CRRs to all known providers since most were over a year old.

The chain also shows an email from Aaron Whaley on December 16, 2024 at 12:00? PM, requesting: “Please prepare a draft response with what we have in the file that is responsive to the request.” The thread then closes with Aaron’s signature block repeating his contact information at The Whaley Law Firm.

In sum, the correspondence from mid-December 2024 centers on preparing a draft response to the August interrogatories, with a comprehensive list of providers drawn from Amy Mills’s file (noting that most current medical reports were dated 2023 through March 2024), a plan to review and potentially narrow the list, and a plan to issue updated CRRs to providers given that many are over a year old. The exchange includes confirmations of the draft provider list, discussion of any objections, and the intent to move forward with submission to the district court, along with acknowledgement of the new email address for Sarena.

Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills. Re: August interrogatories. The note details a chain of email exchanges at The Whaley Law Firm concerning the provider list to be used in response to August interrogatories for Amy Mills.

On December 20, 2024, Aaron Whaley emailed Sarena Tuttle regarding the August interrogatories in the Amy Mills file. In his message he noted that in the provider list item a) the entry appears blank and suggested that this could simply be a formatting issue. The email was sent from Aaron Whaley of the Whaley Law Firm to Sarena Tuttle, with the case’s Filevine project email address cc’d: Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019 - Filevine Project Email Address AmyMillsPremiseZ995806@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com. The message thread also shows the case context and subject line “Re: August interrogatories.”

In a prior message, dated December 19, 2024, Sarena Tuttle replied to Aaron with the draft provider information. She wrote, “Here you go. :) I listed the known providers for 2023 per the records we have. I also included DOS which I do not normally do. Let me know if there are any changes needed.” Her signature identified her as Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal & Workers' Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and the contact numbers D: (502) 357-9971 and O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104, plus the note that the email address is Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com and an indication to note the new email address.

Earlier in the thread, on December 17, 2024, Aaron Whaley replied, “Yes, please do.” In a contemporaneous message, Sarena asked whether she should review Amy Mills’s records to narrow the provider list, noting that the list includes every provider listed in the file and that most of their most recent CMRs are from 2023 through March 2024, while cautioning that this does not necessarily mean the patient saw those providers in 2023 or 2024. Her message, like the others, was signed with her department title and contact information.

Also on December 17, 2024, at 12:12 PM, Aaron Whaley commented, “That looks good. The list of providers is all provider since 01/01/2023?” The thread also contains an earlier message from December 17, 2024, at 11:51 AM from Sarena, titled “Good afternoon AW,” which stated: “Here is the draft you requested. I listed all known providers and any related objections, please review for approval before submitting to the DC. I will get updated CRRs out to all known providers as well since most are over a year old.” The signatures in these messages again identified Sarena M. Tuttle and provided her contact details at The Whaley Law Firm.

The chain begins with a December 16, 2024, 12:00 PM message from Aaron Whaley requesting the preparation of a draft response with what is in the file that is responsive to the request, followed by the subsequent December 17–20 exchanges in which the provider list and related considerations were discussed and drafted for submission to the DC. Throughout, the correspondence lists the firm’s standard contact details for Sarena Tuttle, including the firm address, phone numbers, and her email, and includes the case’s Filevine project email address in the cc field for tracking and project management purposes.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy Mills — Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019
Client: Amy Mills

This note summarizes a December 2024 email thread about the August interrogatories and the provider list for the case of Amy Mills. The primary correspondence ran among Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, and Aaron Whaley, with Amy Mills Premise in copy, related to preparing a draft response and compiling a list of providers.

The thread began with an email from Sarena on December 16, 2024, in which Aaron Whaley urged her to prepare a draft response using the information already in the file that would be responsive to the August interrogatories. The message asked for a draft to address the request directly. This exchange was part of a broader effort to respond to the district court’s (DC) inquiry and to ensure that the file would be properly supported by updated or corrected records.

On December 17, 2024, Sarena sent a draft in response to Aaron’s request. She stated that she had listed all known providers and noted any related objections, adding that she would also obtain updated CRRs for all known providers since most CRRs were over a year old. She stated that the draft was intended for approval before submission to the district court.

Later on December 17, 2024, Aaron replied, asking for clarification: “That looks good. The list of providers is all provider since 01/01/2023?” A few minutes later, at 12:12 PM, Aaron again weighed in, and Sarena responded at 12:21 PM, explaining that the draft included every provider listed in the client’s file, most of whose CMRs dated from 2023 through March 2024. She cautioned that this did not necessarily mean the client saw those providers in 2023 or 2024 and offered to review the records to narrow the list if needed.

At 12:38 PM on December 17, 2024, Aaron replied, “Yes, please do.” In response, Sarena indicated that she would proceed with reviewing the records to narrow the list to those actually seen by the client, while continuing to list all known providers and any objections.

On December 19, 2024, Sarena sent an updated version. She wrote, “Here you go. :) I listed the known providers for 2023 per the records we have. I also included DOS which I do not normally do. Let me know if there are any changes needed.” This message included her standard professional signature with her title, firm, address, telephone numbers, and her note about a new email address.

On December 20, 2024, Aaron commented that in the provider list item “a” it looked blank and suggested it could be a formatting issue. He again referenced the formatting concern in his message.

Shortly after, at 12:05:01 PM on December 20, 2024 (GMT-05:00), Sarena replied that she had observed the same formatting issue. She explained that the blank appeared due to a formatting error and stated that when she opens the PDF on her computer the item is not missing. She said she would verify proper formatting on the PDF version upon approval. Sarena again included her contact information and noted her new email address.

The CC for the primary message included Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019 with the Filevine project email address AmyMillsPremiseZ995806@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com, indicating that Amy Mills was kept in the loop for these communications. The correspondence illustrates a collaborative effort to finalize the August interrogatories response and ensure an accurate, properly formatted provider list, with ongoing checks for formatting accuracy in the PDF version before final submission to the district court.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills.

This note records correspondence regarding the August interrogatories in the Amy Mills Premise case. The thread begins with an email from Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm to Sarena Tuttle, dated December 20, 2024 at 03:59:13 GMT-05:00. In the message, with Amy Mills’ Filevine project email address CC’d (Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019 - Filevine Project Email Address: AmyMillsPremiseZ995806@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com), Aaron states: “Ok, then good to go. File them on December 26.”

The preceding exchange began earlier that week and spanned several days of drafting and review. On December 16, 2024 at 12:00 PM, Aaron Whaley asked Sarena to prepare a draft response that would address the August interrogatories using the materials currently in the file. Sarena Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager for The Whaley Law Firm, replied on December 17, 2024 at 11:51 AM. She explained that the draft would list all known providers and any related objections, and that she would obtain approval before submitting to the district agency (DC). She noted that most of the known provider records’ CRRs would need updating, given that many were over a year old. Her signature block identified her as Sarena M. Tuttle and provided her contact information.

On December 17, 2024 at 12:12 PM, Aaron responded that the draft looked good and asked whether the provider list covered all providers since January 1, 2023. Sarena confirmed in another message later that day (12:21 PM) that the draft indeed covered every provider listed in Amy Mills’ file, with most recent CMRs from 2023 through March 2024, while acknowledging that this did not necessarily mean Amy Mills saw those providers in 2023 or 2024. She asked whether Aaron would like her to review the records further and narrow the list accordingly. Aaron agreed that the list seemed to cover all providers since 01/01/2023, as reflected in his earlier inquiry.

In a December 19, 2024 email, Sarena delivered a draft for review. She stated she had listed all known providers and any related objections, and requested Aaron’s review for approval before submitting to the DC. She also noted that she would issue updated CRRs to all known providers, recognizing that most CRRs were over a year old. Her message again included her standard signature with her title and contact information.

The thread continued with a December 20, 2024 message from Sarena noting a formatting error she observed: “I saw that. It is a formatting error. When I open on my computer it is not there, I will verify proper formatting on the PDF version upon Approval.” Later that day, Aaron replied with a succinct directive: “Ok, then good to go. File them on December 26.”

Accompanying the chain were the standard email footers and signatures for both counsel, repeatedly showing their professional titles, the Whaley Law Firm address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222), multiple phone numbers (D: 502-357-9971; O: 502-583-4022 ext 104; general line 502-583-4022), and email contact details (Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com and agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com). The messages also circulated the case’s Filevine-related CC address for Amy Mills Premise, underscoring that the matter centers on the August interrogatories for the Amy Mills Premise case, with a file designation of Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019 and the client listed as Amy Mills. The correspondence confirms that the plan was to file the related documents on December 26.

Case: Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills. The matter under discussion was the August interrogatories.

On December 23, 2024, in a message titled “Re: August interrogatories,” Sarena M. Tuttle, the Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email from sarena@whaleylawfirm.com to Aaron Whaley at agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com. The message CC’d Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019 – Filevine Project Email Address (AmyMillsPremiseZ995806@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com). The header showed the date as Mon Dec 23 2024 10:20:34 GMT-05:00, and the body simply stated, “Will do.” Her signature block followed, detailing her position, The Whaley Law Firm’s address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222), and contact numbers (D: 502-357-9971, O: 502-583-4022 ext 104), along with her new email address (Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com).

Earlier in the thread, there were several back-and-forth exchanges. On December 20, 2024, at about 3:59 PM (timestamp shown as 3:59?PM), Aaron Whaley replied, “Ok, then good to go. File them on December 26.” Before that, at 12:05 PM (timestamp shown as 12:05?PM), Sarena Tuttle explained that a formatting error had occurred with a document she opened on her computer and that she would verify proper formatting on the PDF version upon approval. She signed again with her Whaley Law Firm credentials and new email address.

On December 20, 2024 at about 11:58 AM, Aaron commented that in the provider list, item a) looked blank and suggested it could be a formatting issue. The previous message from Sarena, at 12:24 PM, had provided the draft: “Here you go. :) I listed the known providers for 2023 per the records we have. I also included DOS which I do not normally do. Let me know if there are any changes needed.” This message included Sarena’s full signature block.

On December 17, 2024, at 12:21 PM, Sarena stated: “It is every provider listed in her file, most of which our most recent CMRs are from 2023 through March 2024. However, that is not to say she saw the providers in 2023/2024. Would you like me to review her records & narrow it down?” Aaron replied at 12:12 PM: “That looks good. The list of providers is all provider since 01/01/2023?” Earlier, at 12:38 PM, Aaron requested confirmation, and Sarena affirmed with her signature.

The thread began on December 16, 2024, with Aaron Whaley directing: “Please prepare a draft response with what we have in the file that is responsive to the request.” The subsequent messages show Sarena and Aaron refining the draft: Sarena compiled a comprehensive list of known providers with any related objections, asked for approval before submission to the District Court (DC), and noted that updated CRRs would be sent to all known providers since many were over a year old.

Across the exchanges, the participants repeatedly referenced the August interrogatories and the need to align the provider list with records in Amy Mills’s file, including whether to include dates of service (DOS) and whether to broaden or narrow the provider list based on the records from 2023 through early 2024. The communications also included standard administrative details such as signatures, office addresses, and contact information for Sarena, with emphasis on her new personal email address. The overall plan culminated in the December 20–23 exchange, with Aaron indicating readiness to file the interrogatories on December 26.

She added that if Amy Mills is claiming this upcoming surgery as related to her 2019 fall, they are entitled to this information. Betsy signed as Attorney for WHT Law, and provided her firm’s contact details and location at Vine Center, 333 West Vine Street, Suite 1100, Lexington, KY 40507, with phone number 859.422.6000, fax 859.422.6001, and the firm’s website www.whtlaw.com.

In summary, the case note documents two sequential communications regarding the Plaintiff’s Response to the Defendant’s third set of interrogatories and fourth set of requests for production of documents, including notice of service filed via CourtNet envelope 9457257, and a subsequent attorney-to-attorney exchange critiquing the sufficiency of the medical-provider information and the related subpoena needs for records concerning Amy Mills’ medical treatment and upcoming surgery related to the 2019 fall.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank; Plaintiff’s Response to Defendant’s Third Set of Interrogatories and Fourth Set of Requests for Production of Documents (PL Resp to DC Disc Req 3rd & 4th). Client: Amy Mills.

On December 26, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Gregg Thornton and Betsy Catron, with Aaron Whaley, Bryce Koon, and Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019 cc’d. The subject line read: Amy Mills v Forcht Bank - PL Resp to DC Disc Req 3rd & 4th. In the body, Sarena advised that the Plaintiff’s Response to the Defendant Forcht Bank’s 3rd set of Interrogatories and 4th set of Requests for Production of Documents was attached, and that Notice of Service had been filed moments earlier via CourtNet Envelope 9457257. She noted that this message was an external email and included the standard caution about external emails. The contact details listed for The Whaley Law Firm were provided, including the firm’s Louisville address and direct lines, and the email was signed by Sarena M. Tuttle with her updated email address: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com.

The following day, December 27, 2024, Betsy R. Catron, Attorney at Vine Center in Lexington, KY, replied to Aaron Whaley and others. Her message criticized the responses as deficient, stating that there were no new medical providers identified and that the client’s ongoing treatment over the past year, as well as the physician performing her upcoming surgery, had not been disclosed. She explained that they cannot subpoena records without knowing who the client is treating with, and if the upcoming surgery is claimed to be related to the 2019 fall, they are entitled to this information. Betsy signed the email with her attorney credentials and provided her firm’s contact information, including the Vine Center address, phone and fax numbers, and website.

The next day, December 28, 2024, at approximately 5:15 a.m. (the Date stamp on the message being Sat Dec 28, 2024 05:15:31 GMT-05:00), Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm responded from out of town. He wrote that he would be back on Monday, January 6, and that he would review the matter and update if necessary. He concluded with thanks and provided his firm’s contact information, including the Louisville office address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and his primary phone number, 502-583-4022.

The Whaley Law Firm’s communications were as described, with Sarena Tuttle’s December 26 email including a detailed note about the attached Plaintiff’s Response and the CourtNet filing, Betsy Catron’s December 27 response detailing deficiencies in the production and pursuit of new medical provider information, and Aaron Whaley’s December 28 follow-up indicating he would review the file after returning from being out of town.

Case: Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank – Plaintiff’s Response to Defense Discovery Requests (Third Interrogatories and Fourth Requests for Production)

The matter involves Amy Mills as the client in the case titled Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank, with the file labeled Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019. On December 26, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to counsel Gregg Thornton and Betsy Catron, with Aaron Whaley, Bryce Koon, and the file “Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019” cc’d. The subject of the message was “Amy Mills v Forcht Bank - PL Resp to DC Disc Req 3rd & 4th.” In the body of the email, Sarena stated: “Good afternoon Counsel, We hope that you all had a wonderful holiday. Please find attached the Plaintiff's Response to the Defendant Forcht Bank's 3rd set of Interrogatories and 4th set of Requests for Production of Documents. Our Notice of Service was filed moments ago via CourtNet Envelope 9457257. If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact us directly to discuss them in further detail.” The email noted it was an external email and provided the Whaley Law Firm contact details: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with D: (502) 357-9971, O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104, and the sender’s email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com.

On December 27, 2024, Betsy R. Catron, Attorney with Vine Center in Lexington, Kentucky, responded to Aaron Whaley. Her message criticized the plaintiff’s responses as deficient, specifically noting that there were no new medical providers identified—namely, who Amy Mills has been treating with over the past year and who will perform her upcoming surgery. She stated that subpoenas cannot be issued for records if the treating providers are unknown, and she asserted that if the upcoming surgery is claimed to be related to Amy Mills’s 2019 fall, the information about treating providers is entitled to disclosure. She signed with the firm’s details: Vine Center, 333 West Vine Street, Suite 1100, Lexington, KY 40507; P 859.422.6000; F 859.422.6001; www.whtlaw.com.

On December 28, 2024, Aaron Whaley of The Whaley Law Firm replied to Betsy Catron. He wrote, “Betsy I am out of town. I’ll be back Monday January 6. I’ll take a look and update if necessary. Thanks.” His signature followed, listing The Whaley Law Firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with phone numbers 502-583-4022 and 502-357-9971, and noting his email contact as agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank. The file is labeled Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019, and the client is Amy Mills.

In the case caption, the matter is identified as Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank, and the note concerns Plaintiff’s Response to the Defendant’s Discovery Requests (3rd set of Interrogatories and 4th set of Requests for Production of Documents). The communication thread includes messages from The Whaley Law Firm and opposing counsel, with the date of the latest exchange noted as January 12, 2025.

On December 26, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to counsel for the defendant, Betsy Catron, and Gregg Thornton, with copies to Aaron Whaley, Bryce Koon, and Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019. The subject was “Amy Mills v Forcht Bank - PL Resp to DC Disc Req 3rd & 4th.” The email stated that the plaintiff’s response to the defendant’s third set of Interrogatories and fourth set of Requests for Production of Documents had been attached, and that their Notice of Service had been filed moments earlier via CourtNet Envelope 9457257. The message also included an external email banner warning and provided contact information for Sarena: D: (502) 357-9971, O: (502) 583-4022 ext. 104, E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, as well as the firm’s Louisville address and related details.

The following day, December 27, 2024, Betsy R. Catron, attorney at Vine Center in Lexington, Kentucky, replied that Aaron Whaley’s responses were deficient. She stated that there were no new medical providers identified and that the record did not indicate who Amy Mills had been treating with over the past year or who would be performing her upcoming surgery. She added that they are not able to subpoena records if they do not know who Amy Mills is treating with, and that if she is alleging that the upcoming surgery is related to her 2019 fall, they are entitled to this information.

On January 12, 2025, at 10:06:41 AM Eastern Time, Aaron Whaley of The Whaley Law Firm sent a follow-up to Betsy Catron. In his message, he noted that Amy Mills is seeing Dr. Kevin Magone in London, Kentucky, who is described as an orthopedic and sports medicine surgeon. He also stated that she had physical therapy at PT Pros in London. He reported that her January 3 surgery had been postponed due to some supply issue, and he concluded with, “Not sure.” The Whaley Law Firm contact details appear in the message: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, phone 502-583-4022.

__Summary of the call with lfarah@whtlaw.com__
From: Aaron Whaley [agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com)
To: Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019 - Filevine Project Email Address [AmyMillsPremiseZ995806@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com](mailto:AmyMillsPremiseZ995806@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com)
Date: Mon Feb 24 2025 01:15:34 GMT-05:00

Hi

Here's the summary of the call with lfarah@whtlaw.com at 2/24 01:04 PM
(UTC-05:00):

Betsy and Aaron discussed the client's ongoing medical issues and the
challenges in negotiating a settlement due to her persistent pain and
upcoming surgery.

Recap

 * Betsy reached out to Aaron to discuss the client's situation and
potential settlement negotiations.
 * Aaron informed Betsy that the client had surgery scheduled for January
3rd, which was canceled due to weather, and she has been unwell recently.
 * The client is still experiencing pain and has not been able to engage in
settlement discussions.
 * Aaron mentioned that the client is unlikely to lower her settlement
demand of $1.5 million due to her ongoing pain and medical issues.
 * Betsy suggested obtaining the most recent medical records to assess the
situation and keep track of expenses.
 * They agreed to stay updated on the client's surgery timeline to better
understand the case's progression.

Tasks

 * Aaron needs to send the most recent medical records to Betsy this week.
 * Aaron should keep Betsy informed about the client's surgery schedule as
it develops.

Best,
aaron whaley
episodes.natural_language:
On February 24, 2025 at 1:04 PM (UTC-05:00), Betsy and Aaron spoke with lfarah@whtlaw.com about Amy Mills’s case. The conversation centered on the client’s ongoing medical issues and the difficulties of negotiating a settlement due to her persistent pain and upcoming surgery.

Aaron and Betsy discussed the client’s situation and potential settlement negotiations. Aaron informed Betsy that the client had a surgery scheduled for January 3, which was canceled because of bad weather, and that she has been unwell recently. The client remains in pain and has not been able to engage in settlement discussions. Aaron noted that the client is unlikely to lower her settlement demand of $1.5 million in light of her ongoing pain and medical issues. Betsy suggested obtaining the most recent medical records to assess the situation and track expenses. They agreed to stay updated on the client’s surgery timeline to better understand the progression of the case.

Next steps: Aaron should send the most recent medical records to Betsy this week and keep Betsy informed about the client’s surgery schedule as it develops. The note is signed, Best, Aaron Whaley.
episodes.author: Aaron Whaley

On February 27, 2025, the matter was referenced in an email chain labeled Re: Amy Mills v Forcht Bank - PL Supp Resp to DC Forcht Disc Req. The email thread involved Sarena Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, and Aaron Whaley, with Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019 CC’d on the exchanges.

In an email sent on the morning of February 27, 2025, at 9:44 AM, Sarena Tuttle wrote to Mrs. Catron that Mrs. Mills’s Supplemental Responses to the Defendant’s 3rd and 4th Discovery Requests were attached, and she invited any questions or discussions to address the matter in further detail. The message included Sarena’s contact information and noted that there was a new email address for her: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com. Her signature identified her as the Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager for The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with D: (502) 357-9971, O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104.

Earlier in the day, at 1:22 PM, Aaron Whaley replied, noting, “Make sure the actual records and bills are attached to them that we have received.” His signature followed, showing his affiliation with The Whaley Law Firm and listing the firm’s address—712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222—and the contact number 502-583-4022.

Later still, at 1:27 PM, Sarena responded with the line, “The packet was 72 pages, I assume all pages were attached correctly.” This message carried her standard signature block, reiterating her role at The Whaley Law Firm and including the firm’s address, direct line (D: 502-357-9971), main line (O: 502-583-4022 ext 104), and her email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, again noting the parenthetical reminder to please note the new email address. The message also reflected the same case context and the subject matter regarding supplemental discovery responses.

The email chain also shows that the message to Mrs. Catron included the attachment of Mrs. Mills’s Supplemental Responses to the Defendant’s 3rd and 4th Discovery Requests, with Sarena’s note that if there were questions, they should be discussed directly. The CC for the correspondence included Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019 at the email AmyMillsPremiseZ995806@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com.

For completeness, Aaron Whaley’s signature appeared with the Whaley Law Firm details: 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, 502-583-4022, following his reply.

episodes.natural_language:
This case note concerns the Mills matter for client Amy Mills, filed as Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019. The correspondence span from February 27, 2025 to March 20, 2025 and centers on imaging records, radiology information, and communications with Betsy Catron, Aaron Whaley, and Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm.

On March 20, 2025, at 2:01 AM Eastern Time, Aaron Whaley sent an email to Sarena Tuttle and the Amy Mills Premise file (Amy Mills Premise 04/26/2019) asking, “Can you make a copy and forward to defense counsel? Thanks.” Later that same day, at 11:55 AM (the record notes a question mark after the time), Sarena Tuttle replied: “Received Imaging CD - Placed in your chair,” and she included her standard contact information as Litigation Paralegal & Workers' Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm.

In the earlier portion of the chain, on March 17, 2025 at 3:25 PM, Sarena wrote that she had called Radiology, obtained a direct fax number, and sent the CRR. Then, on March 14, 2025, Aaron Whaley had requested the actual films for all of Amy Mills's MRI, CT, and X-ray studies.

On March 12, 2025, at 1:05 PM, Sarena informed the team that the results were in the CHI St. Joseph Orthopedics Records, spanning pages 25–30, appearing to be completed in-house, and that the results were attached. Earlier that same day at 12:19 PM, Aaron Whaley asked, “Do we have this?” In relation to that inquiry, a forwarded message from Betsy Catron appeared, dated March 12, 2025 at 10:48 AM, with the subject “FW: Mills.” Betsy asked Aaron: “Hi Aaron – can you tell me where your client had her Sept 11, 2024 MRI done?”

The chain also includes Betsy’s prior correspondence from February 27, 2025. In Betsy’s 3:49 PM message to Aaron, she wrote: “I appreciate it, Aaron. Please keep me informed should any surgery be scheduled.” Aaron replied to Betsy on February 27, 2025 at 1:33 PM: “Betsy, we have sent you everything we have. I will continue to send you anything we get in.” This message carried the standard external email caution notice indicating it was sent from outside the recipient’s organization, advising caution with links and attachments. The communications included the sign-offs from Aaron Whaley and the Whaley Law Firm, listing their address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and the corresponding phone numbers and email addresses, with Aaron Whaley repeatedly signing as the author and Sarena Tuttle providing her role and contact information.

In sum, the working thread shows coordination to locate and forward Amy Mills’s imaging records, including an imaging CD that was received and placed for access, requests for the actual films of MRI/CT/X-ray studies, and inquiries about the location of a September 11, 2024 MRI, with updates about CHI St. Joseph Orthopedics records (Pages 25–30) and confirmation that results were attached. The primary objective stated in the March 20 message was to copy and forward the materials to defense counsel.

episodes.natural_language:
In the Mills matter, the file labeled Amy-Mills-Premise-04-26-2019 involves client Amy Mills. The thread titled “Re: FW: Mills,” dated March 21, 2025, shows a series of internal actions and communications among The Whaley Law Firm staff. On March 21, 2025, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, created a Dropbox folder and shared it with DC and the assistant; the assistant acknowledged the link; she drafted a NOS; she replied to the assistant’s acknowledgment with the NOS; and she created a hard CD which FG will mail out with a copy of the NOS and the Certification Pages. Sarena’s contact information is: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct line 502-357-9971; office line 502-583-4022 ext 104; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (noting the new email address).

The surrounding email activity shows a sequence of communications from mid-February to March 2025 regarding imaging and records. On February 27, 2025, Betsy Catron emailed Aaron Whaley to say, “Betsy, we have sent you everything we have. I will continue to send you anything we get in,” and she added that she would appreciate being kept informed should any surgery be scheduled. Earlier that day, Aaron had replied to Betsy saying that all available materials had been sent and that he would continue to forward anything received. Betsy had previously asked on February 27, 2025, at 3:49 PM to be kept informed about any surgery. On March 12, 2025, at 10:48 AM, Betsy sent a forwarded message asking Aaron where his client had her September 11, 2024 MRI done. Later that same day, at 12:19 PM, Aaron asked, “Do we have this?” and at 1:05 PM, Sarena responded that the results were in the CHI St. Joseph Orthopedics Records (Pages 25–30), appeared completed in-house, and that the results were attached. The thread shows that on March 14, 2025, at 3:49 PM, Aaron requested the actual films for all MRI/CT/X-ray studies. On March 17, 2025, at 3:25 PM, Sarena wrote that she had called Radiology, obtained a direct fax number, and sent the CRR. On March 20, 2025, at 11:55 AM, Sarena noted that she received an imaging CD and had placed it in Aaron’s chair; later, at 2:01 PM, Aaron asked if a copy could be made and forwarded to defense counsel. On March 21, 2025, Sarena finalized the earlier steps by confirming the Dropbox folder creation, sharing, and related administrative tasks (as described above), including drafting and signing off on the NOS and arranging a hard CD distribution.

All individuals referenced in the thread and the key participants include Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, and Aaron Whaley. Their communications originate from The Whaley Law Firm’s Louisville, Kentucky office at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with the contact details cited above for Sarena. The chain also includes Betsy Catron, who appears to be communicating with Aaron regarding MRI history and potential surgery timing. The thread confirms the following documented actions: creation of a Dropbox folder and sharing with the defense and assistant; acknowledgment of the shared link; drafting of the NOS; correspondence acknowledging the NOS; creation of a hard CD containing the NOS and Certification Pages; and ongoing handling of imaging CDs, radiology communications, and requests for actual film copies, as well as the location of prior MRI work and related records.

Case: Amy Mills – Premise 04-26-2019. Client: Amy Mills.

On April 8, 2025, at 14:50:46 UTC, Chelsea Rivera, ROI Quality Analyst at MediCopy, sent a Box file titled AMY MILLS.pdf to Sarena at whaleylawfirm.com. The email indicates the file was delivered with both a “AMY MILLS.pdf” attachment name and a Box access link: https://medicopy.box.com/s/plyd4927var4wii8363pul2hbjyctkhm, along with a separate view URL: https://medicopy.box.com/s/plyd4927var4wii8363pul2hbjyctkhm. The From line identifies Chelsea Rivera- ROI Quality Analyst, with the address chelsea.rivera@medicopy.net, and the To line shows sarena@whaleylawfirm.com. The message includes the standard Box footer and prompts for Box actions such as viewing the file and downloading it.

The body of the message states, in all caps: "WE RECEIVED AN UPDATED REQUEST FROM YOU BUT THERE ARE NO NEW RECORDS. THERE ARE JUST THE ONES THAT HAVE BEEN PREVIOUSLY SENT SO I AM RESENDING THIS ONE TO YOU. IF YOU NEED ACTUAL IMAGES THEN YOU WILL NEED TO REACH OUT TO THE FACILITY DIRECTLY. Please click “View File” to access the medical records you have requested. The password for access will be “MCSI” plus the patient's four-digit birth year (i.e. MCSI1912). Please download the file, as the link will disable in 10 days. If you need further assistance, please contact our office at 866.587.6274. Thank you." The file is accessible via the link provided above, and there is also a "View File" option.

In addition to the primary links, the message invites viewing on mobile with a Box app link, and provides a Box account footer including the organization address: © 2025 | 900 Jefferson Avenue, Redwood City, CA 94063, USA. There are standard Box options for About Box, Edit Notification Settings, and Privacy Policy, as well as a MediCopy label. The email includes a note to unsubscribe from these emails via a provided link, though the exact unsubscribe URL isn’t shown in the content provided.

Case: Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank, Knox Circuit Court. Client: Amy Mills. The file note describes a chain of emails in September through October 2025 in which Amy Mills’ counsel sought to retain David Johnson of Johnson Health and Safety as a consulting expert for the matter, with coordination of an upcoming site inspection and related terms.

The initial contact occurred on September 10, 2025, when Adam Redden of DECAMILLIS & MATTINGLY, PLLC, wrote to David Johnson to discuss retaining him as a consulting expert for the case Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank. Adam asked if David had time today or tomorrow for a discussion about the retention. He included his firm’s contact details: DECAMILLIS & MATTINGLY, PLLC, 138 S. 3rd Street, Louisville, Kentucky 40202, with phone 502-589-2822 and fax 502-589-2826, and he also noted at the end that the message contained a confidentiality and privilege notice.

Over the next day, there was ongoing scheduling dialogue. Adam indicated that an afternoon meeting would work for him, and David Johnson proposed a 3:00 PM time in EST for the conversation. There were further exchanges about possible times, with Adam replying that the afternoon would work and David trying to reach him by phone. The thread shows multiple correspondents being cc’d, including Robert Mattingly, Lauren Byrn, Taylor Brown, and Aaron Whaley.

On September 12, 2025, David Johnson wrote again to Adam Redden, noting that he could discuss either that day or the next afternoon and offering a concrete time window. In parallel, David attached a retainer consulting agreement, a CV, a Litigation Summary, and a 2025 Fee Schedule to the thread (the attachment notes indicate that fee information was contained in Section 5). Adam’s responses and the ongoing exchange continued, with references to the confidentiality and privilege notices typical of these communications.

Later in September, there was a discussion about sending and executing the retainer agreement and related case materials. On September 30, 2025, David asked Adam whether the retainer consulting agreement had been executed and whether it had been mailed along with any case information, or if it had already been sent. Adam replied later that day that he planned to send the retainer check and the executed agreement within the week, and he noted that he was waiting on some dates for an inspection.

On October 1, 2025, Adam informed David that he expected to have the retainer check and executed agreement out to him that week. The thread also reiterates the standard confidential notices included in each email.

The matter then moved toward scheduling an inspection. On October 15, 2025, Adam asked David whether he had availability on October 27 or October 29 to perform an inspection at the bank in Corbin, Kentucky, noting that it would be about a three-hour drive for Adam and proposing around 12:00 p.m. ET on either day. David replied the same day that he could do October 29 at 12:30 p.m. EST and requested a confirmation plus a good time to discuss the scope of the inspection beforehand.

On October 16, 2025, Adam confirmed that they were set for October 29 and indicated he was fairly open on October 24, 27, or 28 for a phone call to discuss the scope. David responded that he would attempt to reach Adam in the early afternoon on the 24th and would try again on the 27th if he missed him. Adam followed up on October 17, 2025, providing his cell phone number (502-905-4700) in case he could not be reached at the office, and restated his firm’s contact details: DECAMILLIS & MATTINGLY, PLLC, 138 S. 3rd Street, Louisville, KY 40202, with the same phone and fax numbers. The email also reiterates the confidentiality and privilege notices standard to the correspondence.

Throughout the thread, the communications include the usual professional signatures with firm addresses and phone numbers, and each message contains confidentiality notices indicating the information is privileged and intended for the recipient only. There is also mention of scheduled communications and potential in-person inspection logistics related to the Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank matter, including the anticipated inspection in Corbin, Kentucky, and the planned discussion of the scope of that inspection prior to the visit.

Date: 10/23/2025, 10:44:26 AM

Lauren,
Amy still has not responded to any of my phone calls or emails. Can you please do this letter to her to be sent via US mail with a self-addressed stamped envelope
RE Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank
Dear Ms. Mills,
Before any medical providers will talk with us about your injuries and treatment they require a signed HIPAA authorization. Please sign the enclosed HIPAA authorization and return it to us in the enclosed self-addressed stamped envelope. We also need to set up a time to talk about your case, a second mediation, an independent medical examination, and other steps that need to be taken to keep your case moving forward. Please respond to the e-mail chain with some dates and times that you would be available to talk. As I stated in a recent e-mail, I will be in town for an inspection of the bank on Wednesday October 29, 2025. If you would like to meet before or after that inspection that would be fantastic.
Cordially by me

The message stated that Amy had still not responded to any of Redden’s phone calls or emails and requested that a letter be prepared for Amy Mills to be sent via US mail with a self-addressed stamped envelope, concerning Amy Mills v. Forcht Bank.

The proposed letter to Ms. Mills would begin with “Dear Ms. Mills,” and explain that, before any medical providers will talk with them about her injuries and treatment, a signed HIPAA authorization is required. Ms. Mills would be asked to sign the enclosed HIPAA authorization and return it in the enclosed self-addressed stamped envelope. The letter would also request setting up a time to discuss her case, a second mediation, an independent medical examination, and other steps needed to keep the case moving forward. Ms. Mills would be asked to respond to the email chain with some dates and times she would be available to talk. As noted in a recent email, Redden would be in town for an inspection of the bank on Wednesday October 29, 2025, and if she would like to meet before or after that inspection, that would be fantastic. The letter would close with “Cordially by me,” and list enclosures: HIPAA authorization and a self-addressed stamped envelop.

The email included Redden’s contact information: DECAMILLIS & MATTINGLY, PLLC, 138 S. 3rd Street, Louisville, Kentucky 40202; Phone 502-589-2822; Fax 502-589-2826. A reference image placeholder, [cid:2a7bceca-d452-4b90-93dc-2992ddec566b], appeared in the message.
